description:
This place is a gift from God. 
Free parking.
One of my favorite place to check out in San Francisco. Only bad part is that is really cold. Bathrooms are clean.
author: Juliette H.

description:
Spectacular view of SF! Don't forget to bring something to munch on as you enjoy the beautiful view of San Francisco. 

The only downside to Twin Peaks is that if you come on a really cold night the likely hood of you seeing the whole city light is much lower. If you come during the summer months, it's almost a guarantee that you'll see a beautiful view at night :)

Good luck to anyone visiting during winter!
author: Shua Micki T.

description:
I went to SF in May 2018 with my bestie to see another close friend of mine get married in Yosemite. Awesome trip filled with so many great memories..

This part was hands down one of my favorite moments. If you have the dexterity and athleticism make a day of it and climb the mountain (it's paved). If you are like me, have someone drive your lazy butt up. The day we went was a 70 degree day but if you know anything about SF it has over 30 different micro climates. My hair was standing straight up from the wind and I could very well have used a sweatshirt and jacket but the views were top notch. It was so quiet and peaceful, like in a movie and I could have stayed up there for hours. So glad I was able to stay in the Castro. Definitely an authentic SF experience  p.s. don't forget to play Scott McKenzie's San Francisco
author: Jackie M.

description: If you are in San Francisco on a clear day, visiting the Twin Peaks is a MUST.  It offers scenic views of the city.  If you climb it rather than drive, it's also a workout.  I recommend some good shoes, as there are lots of rocks and erosion of the paths leading up to the peaks.  There were a small group of people on both peaks mostly getting selfies.  I enjoyed seeing the sweeping view and looking down on the areas I had already walked and visited as if it were a small model of the city.  Both peaks offer good views.  Highly recommended.  Next time I would like to see the city at night.
author: Ryan W.

description: It's quite a drive up to get here but worth the view. You can see everything from the Golden Gate Bridge, the city, and the bay bridge. There is a hill with a lot of steps if you want a higher view but the spot near the parking lot is good enough for less the effort. Sit back and admire the vastness of the city.
author: Lanha T.

description:
Twin Peaks is the second highest point in San Francisco (Mount Davidson is the highest). This is a really popular SF viewpoint location due to its prime 360 degree and uninhabited view of the city and not to mention these peaks sit in the geographical center of SF. The northern peak is named "Eureka" and the south peak is named "Noe." I only hopped on the northern peak and I was able to see the Golden Gate Bridge, the Transamerica Pyramid, and the Sutro Tower on a clear day. It was so windy that I even had trouble putting my jacket on.

There are two entry points if you want to take trails up to the peaks (one shortcut at Crestline Dr [you can get here by taking the Muni #37 Corbet Line] and another one at Midcrest Way - http://sfrecpark.org/wp-content/uploads/Twin-Peaks.pdf), but the quickest way to get up here is using a ridesharing app and set the destination to the Christmas Tree Point (the only parking area for Twin Peaks - pretty limited parking). Please note that the Christmas Tree Point itself is only the viewing area and not the actual peaks - you will have to walk toward to the entrance of the Christmas Tree Point to see the northern peak.

This is simply one of the best SF views you can find and you don't have to pay a dime too (other than the money you pay for using a ridesharing app)!
author: Luke L.

description:
This place is cool to look at I guess since it's hella touristy but it's busy and parking sucks and there is trash and broken glass everywhere.

There is a 90% chance your car will get robbed here.

I really liked the pink triangle though.
author: Christine K.

description: Went on a Sunday early afternoon and the parking lot at the top was nearly full; seems like it's also a popular group tour stop based on the many tour buses I saw. Neat place to view SF. If you don't have this on your SF day agenda and you have some extra time, definitely check this place out!
author: G A.

description:
Amazing views!
I hiked all the way from Japantown to The Castro and then here. You pass many cute streets and hidden stairways in between houses that connect streets. There's a little earthy trail right at the end that comes out right at the photo spot.
So while people were taking their views, I popped up from behind them after my climb :) 
I was also the only hiker there and everyone else drove their cars up.

Once up, you have the area with binoculars but if you want, you can head a little further and climb the little hill. I did but the wind was so strong that day that it was dangerous. 

I walked down the road downhill and you have to be careful, a lot of stupid crazy drivers racing up and down the curvy hill.

I didn't give it 5 starts because after this I walked to the 16 avenue tile steps which is right under the Grandview Park. NO tourist there, literally NOBODY yet a way better view than twin peaks. And you can also see the Golden Gate Bridge from here.
author: Apple S.

description:
Gorgeous view of San Francisco and definitely a must-see if you have free time when in the area.

There's several places to park lower than the designated parking lot, but that's for people who are trying to get a workout in. You see, ya girl was definitely NOT going for that... So we parked at the top and just climbed the steps (which was still enough of a workout for me). 

The view is so gorgeous. It's so windy up there but it's whatever. Messy Instagram pictures are still in, so it's okay. Right?

If you can get here on a clear day you have to visit. The view is just perfect and a great way to see all of the city.
author: Lauren P.

description: My stay in San Francisco was short and coming to a close. I was hanging out with a friend who grew up in San Fran and he was in shock that I have yet to visit Twin Peaks. So he drove me to Twin Peaks just so that I can have at least the proof that I went here. Unfortunately the weather was foggy and windy. However, I was still able to see small peaks of the city. I definitely want to come back here on a clear day to get that beautiful 360 view. I still enjoyed the feeling of being above the city and above the "clouds." Gotta visit this place if you are in San Fran!
author: Rina I.

description:
On a whim I gave directions for hubby to zoom up the winding hills of San Francisco. Felt like we were going to visit a lighthouse. Right? LOL I always feel giddy when that happens.

Hubby was scared though (me too) bc the last time we were stuck on a steep hill!  We were inches away from hitting another car bc we parallel parked! Oh my gawd! This time we didn't need to parallel park though spaces up there were quite limited. I can see later in the day that could be an issue. 

When we arrived hubby was happy to find a couple wraparound bathrooms. I guess the Sutro bath ones weren't open yet as hubby had too much coffee & water earlier that morning!

While we were here there was a group of Marines here for training. It was the usual SF foggy morning. 

I had no idea how close I had been near here so many times before. Reminiscing family memories. Brother's in laws' home was within walking distance. Yes I still remember their kitchen view of the City. Amazing & unreal!

Just a short climb up the hill! Only 922 feet! Where else can you get a breathtaking 360 degree view of the City like this? I'm sure we will be back. Gladly.
author: Karen K.

description:
San Francisco is such a beautiful city. If you want to see a birdeyes view of the city, you need to visit Twin Peaks. Yes, it's a tourist attraction and it's get very busy here but it's worth the visit. The views are absolutely amazing!

Make sure you visit on a clear day so you can see San Francisco in it's entirety. You will be able to spot some of the famous landmarks such as the Golden Gate bridge. Bring a jacket as tends to get cold up here.
author: Glenn A.

description:
Hands down the favorite landmark for a clear, extensive, and beautiful view of SF. 

- Been here multiple times, and find it best to come early in the morning (7-8am) since it's bright enough for a safe drive, and early enough to enjoy the view w/o a big crowd. (No tour buses yet ~730 am)

About Weather:

-The sky could be a bit cloudier/ foggier in the early morning, but photos still turned out great regardless. The view is just breathtaking, and unforgettable! 

- Came here one time in the afternoon, and although the lighting was great, it was a lot windier than the time I came in the morning.

-I've encountered a few times hitchhikers asking for rides, and that's a unique experience for me as a local. I did give a ride to a carful of European travellers once, and that was a fun ride.
author: Jess W.

description: I appreciate anywhere I can bring my dog for a walk and a view! The wind gets pretty strong, even when I've visited in the summer it gets really cold so dress in layers! SF is beautiful and this is just another free place to take in the view. There's parking spot as you go up, so there's no problem parking your car. Steep but short hills, and stairs for assistance to go further up. So friendly for all ages!
author: Vannah V.

description:
Breathtakingly beautiful. It's the kind of beautiful that will make you drunk off of nothing and nostalgic for something you've never experienced.

Bring a jacket and maybe a hair tie. Go during the hour when the sun starts to set and day transitions to night.
author: Claire W.

description:
1000th review on Twin Peaks page xD 
Perfect view ever! 

Had a blast :) view at night was gorgeous! TBC
author: Donna T.

description:
Twin Peak is another tourist destination, but the difference is that it's a free experience with a beautiful city view and suprisingly easy parking (Monday at 6 pm)

Nothing else left to mention, other than it's freezing cold due to the wind, which could have assisted in the quick turn over rate of visiters. Haha

We saw cars come and go frequently, so don't fret if ideal parking spots are all taken; you'll find one soon enough if you just wait on the side (or you can park lower and walk up to the lot, then up the stairs to your final spot overlooking the city).
author: Christine H.

description: A quick and easy drive by if you're in the mood to eat your feels or show somebody who hasn't been before! Parking is free and there's a constant flux of visitors going in and out for a quick look. See SF from afar and realize how lucky you are to live in the bay area, or not! I felt something.
author: David N.

description:
Cool scenic spot with free parking. A bit touristy (oh SF, you get me every time), but very easy to get to if you have a car, and you don't have to spend much time here despite the crowds! The view is worth the journey, albeit windy due to the elevation. I've only been here twice, and both times on a really nice and sunny afternoon.

I prefer the cityscape view from Treasure Island, which is the midway point across the Bay Bridge. This could definitely be a nice date spot, and both peaks are quite similar once you get to the top. It's a pretty neat spot to check out on a clear day, regardless of weather. 9/10 would recommend if you're on your way to the Golden Gate Park further west!
author: Christina T.

description:
Review #117 - 2018

When we showed up around 5:30 PM on May 5th, it was extremely windy.  So windy, that I wasn't sure if I wanted to get out of my car.

My son was super sweet & volunteered to sit in the car and wait with his little sister while my two nephews and I climbed the steep steps up to the very top of the peak.

I remember my older brother telling us that he brought us here when we were younger, but I don't recall being here.

This place is beautiful.  You can see the entire city of San Francisco from up here.

Unfortunately, being that it was so windy, we couldn't stay for more than about 15-20 minutes.

Definitely not the right kind of weather to capture any nice photos, but we still got to enjoy the great view.
author: Sivilay T.

description: A beautiful walk with stunning vistas. The trails are steep but short (and most have stairs to help climb to the top. An excellent place for walking, biking or advanced skateboarding.
author: Seth S.

description:
Once you're up by the parking lot, you'll have to make the short climb up a set of stairs to get to your desired destination. The stairs aren't very even so if you're walking with someone who can't easily climb up, make sure to take your time and avoid going late at night because there's obviously not a lot of lighting and it's pretty easy to miss your step. 

The more crowded peak closer to the parking lot provides a stronger view of the golden gate bridge but it also has a huge structure that blocks the side view so I prefer the other peak that's farther away.

Since this is a pretty popular site for locals and tourists alike, you'll likely see a bunch of people around but everyone is generally really nice and willing to help take pictures. 

My friends and I came here in the winter and it was REALLY cold but we wanted to see the sunset as well as the city all lit up so we made the trip when it was around 4PM. That gave us enough time to really see the city in it's daylight glory and also transition over to the beautiful night view. You'll see the SF skyline, ocean, and when it's lit up, the bay bridge. Will definitely come again in the summer when it's not so cold!
author: Jennifer D.

description: The view of the city and the Pacific at sunset simply took my breath away. I'm definitely gonna be returning soon. It was a bit crowded so I didn't actually hike up but man this place was stunning!
author: Tashawa W.

description: Can You Say, "Awesome and breathtaking views!!!!"  Well, I just did and if you come and visit this place, you'll also be saying that as well.  You can see for miles and miles from here and the views that you see cannot be duplicated anywhere.. You can also be prepared for a big crowd, especially on gorgeous days.  Must see!
author: Scott V.

description: Absolutely gorgeous and breathtaking views of San Francisco. I didn't realize how grand the skyline was until I took the climb up there. There were a decent amount of people when we got there at noon, but it wasn't too bad. The earlier the better i'd say. Definitely a must-see for any tourist!
author: Taya A.

description: Windy af though the city view is soooooo beautiful!!! But "Your smiles put the city lights to shame."
author: Dee P.

description:
Honestly, this is the best view of San Francisco I've ever seen in my trip. My friend and I visited  multiple places in the city and we agree, you can't find anything better than this place. You have to see this view once in your life for sure.  The transport was easy and simple and it took only two bus for came here. I suggest you to wear a good sweater because we had a lot of wind on the top and it's a bit cold. 

Honnêtement, Twin Peaks est définitivement la meilleure vue de la ville. Mon amie et moi avons visité de nombreuses places avec une vue sur la ville et celle-ci dépasse de loin les autres. Nous avons pris seulement 2 autobus pour nous rendre et le chemin pour s'y rendre est facile et simple. Une fois arrivé, vous devez monter des escaliers sur la colline avant de vous rendre en haut.
author: Catherine L.

description: If traveling to San Francisco you have to go to Twin Peaks for the amazing view of the city. From this location you will be able to see not only the entire downtown but also Golden Gate bridge and some neighborhoods. This location can get pretty busy with tourists but there is plenty of parking in multiple locations so you should not have an issue with parking. Enjoy and don't forget your camera.
author: David B.

description: I have been to SF many times and have never been to this landmark. Absolutely gorgeous 360 panoramic views of the entire city. We went around 9pm and the sight of all the lights from the buildings were mesmerizing, but we weren't there that long because we all didn't dress warm enough to stay longer than I wanted. So if you plan to visit during the night make sure to dress for the brisk and cold weather in the evenings.
author: Cheryl P.

description:
So windy. This is maybe the windiest place I have ever been. Its crazy my hair was in such a knotted mess afterwards. They were birds that would just jump and the air current would just lift them up and they would drift off. It was crazy. 

The view was pretty spectacular. Bring a camera or selfie stick. Sure its touristy, but its fun to be a tourist every once in a while. I would highly recommend bringing binoculars. There may bot always be parking because of what a tourist hotspot this place is. But hiking up the hill is a really nice walk.
author: Marie-Claire E.

description: I probably go here every time I visit SF! It has such a beautiful view of the city. Its free to go up and has a pretty big space to see everything. You can go at any time of the day but I think the best time to go is probably early in the morning to avoid the crowd. I would def recommend going here for some cute pics!
author: Alexa-Ferl S.

description:
This is such a beautiful place to see especially late at night. You can see the whole city lit up which is breathtaking. There is room to walk along the wall. The city provides a nice backdrop for anyone who wants to take that photo.

When driving up to twin peaks, you may notice high volume of traffic. This is kind of expected as this place is so popular. I've even seen multiple marriages begin here. I've seen multiple photo shoots up here as well.

There is a parking lot available, but you may need to circle around a few times due to how popular the place is. If you need to use the restroom, they have one there. Unfortunately it's probably not as clean as anyone would hope.

As soon as you find parking though, everything is smooth sailing. Definitely a worthwhile spot to check out!
author: Brennen D.

description:
Such an amazing viewing spot in SF! 

I came here by motorcycle on a Saturday evening right before sunset and It was verrrry busy. Parking is sparse so if you come in a car during a busy time prepare to circle till you find a spot. But honestly worth it! Once you're parked there are multiple areas where you can take on the sights and of course snap your pics for the gram. 

Another thing to note, it's incredibly windy which means it's chilly up there so I recommend bringing a jacket. I'm a was wearing 3 layers + a motor cycle jacket and I was still freezing. Full disclosure I'm a Florida gal so I'm also a wimp when it comes to the cold. But there were plenty of people bundled up with coats and blankets as they enjoyed the view. 

Definitely add this to the list if you're visiting SF!
author: Carlie S.

description:
#500!

No one said you can't have any thing free except for a million dollar panoramic view of the Bay Area!

One of the reasons why I love coming to Twin Peaks is the stunning views of the city with the Sutro Towers standing proudly behind me. With many criticisms over the tower (antenna), for me it has become a reminder of Yelp's humble beginnings in San Francisco with the white and red strips painted legs to match.

Past visits have always been memorable with visions of joy and hopefulness. By car, drive up the winding road where you'll find limited free parking to take advantage of the summit. Once outside, make sure you bring a jacket/coat because it can be extremely cold and windy. On a clear day, you can point out many of the SF main attractions and see clearly across the bay. 

As I write this review, I'd like to thank all my Yelpers who have become more than just friends and the people who've read my reviews and thought it was Useful, Funny or Cool. I look forward to writing my next 500 reviews together. For now, I left my heart in San Francisco but hope it'll be returned to me one of these days. Syoy!
author: Santi T.

description:
1000th review! Breath taking view! What's not to like? 

Parking can be a little hectic. But just go around and wait for people to get out. You'll get one.
author: Tim S.

description: At the top, you can see a panoramic view of San Francisco and the Pacific Ocean. There is a lot of parking spaces but could also be very crowded at peak times. The restroom line can be over 30 minutes long. It is windy and very bright at the top so be prepared to dress accordingly.
author: Xichen J.

description: I knew this view would be beautiful, but I didn't expect it to be THAT beautiful! WOW!! My friend and I rode there in an Uber, straight to the top. If we'd had more time we would have hiked it, but we didn't want to miss sunset. The sunset was absolutely stunning, although partially out of view from where we were. I'd love to see sunrise there someday! Like everyone says, it's freezing up there! So definitely wear layers. It's also kind of crowded, so come in the morning if you'd like to avoid the crowds.
author: Francie J.

description:
What more really needs to be said about Twin Peaks? It offers a magnificent view of the entire San Francisco Bay and beyond! Whether you decide to come during the day or night, you will be stunned by the amazing view that it has to offer. So many people come to this viewpoint to enjoy the peaceful yet beautiful sights of San Francisco! You will be greeted with beauty with each turn! 

The drive up to the viewpoint is so much fun! You will be teased with the beautiful bay bridge and the sky scraper buildings as you ascend closer to
your destination! There are paid telescopes where you can enhance your viewing pleasure. This is a super popular spot amongst photographers, tourists, and locals alike. Peak times will make it hard to find parking, but if you're patient, people pull out of their spots quite frequently.

On summer days and nights, the winds feels so amazing when your at Twin Peaks so high up! At other times, you will freeze your ass off! Make sure to always bring a large coat with you because it IS the city and it will get cold up there! If you live in the Bay Area and haven't ever made it out to Twin Peaks, now is definitely the time! You won't regret it!
author: Shayla B.

description: One of my all time favorite city view lookout spots!  Can't ever get enough of the views from here... you can see 365 degrees depending on where you stand. I always have to stop here when I'm back in the city!
author: Kerith H.

description: This is the best view in the whole entire city!! Nighttime is a whole different experience. I recommend both. Great photos nice place to chill and take it all in! Must see!!!
author: James F.

description:
When you finally reach the top of Twin Peaks you will be either lost for words or aww-ing. 

Unbelievable view of San Francisco. It is so gorgeous, breathtaking, and absolutely spectacular. 

Looking at that view made me think that life is so simple from the up there. 

Definitely go up to Twin Peaks..No No..make that you better go up there.
author: Alan L.

description: A bit of a hike through windy, non-lit roads but worth the trek. The views of the bay, from the Golden Gate Bridge to the Bay Bridge to the Peninsula all from one location is breathtaking. It can get quite windy, so make sure to bring a jacket. Parking is limited, and can get full quickly.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Beautiful! It's a view of the entire city. The drive up is quick and if you decide to walk, it looks like it'll take an hour or so. Lots of tourists and very limited spots but it's free! 

It's truly a place you have to go if you're visiting San Fran. It'll take your breath away! 

There are two mountains to climb when you reach the top  of the driveway, which is why they're called twin peaks. It take about 2-3 mins to climb since there are stairs.
author: Julina V.

description:
In a city where almost everything costs money - and usually a lot of it - Twin Peaks gives you something to do for free. You can drive up here and many people bike here too. This is by far the best view of the city you will be able to find. You can see the Golden Gate, Downtown, the Pacific Ocean, the San Mateo area, and more. You will definitely get a great 360 degree panoramic view from up here.

Although it is great to see during the day, it is even better at night with all of the bridges and the city lit up. The best time is around Christmas, when all the buildings have lights on them. 

Be sure to check it out if you're in San Francisco!
author: Steve N.

description:
This is a cool spot to stop by and take pictures, but don't expect to spend much time up here. We probably spent less than 30 minutes here honestly. We just got lucky and found parking easy probably because we came here on a weekday around 1 pm.
We came on a gloomy day, so we were still able to see everything clearly. It was cool that we were able to see as far as the east bay. Will come back at night to see all the lights and planes passing by.
author: Jermaine C.

description: It is really windy there at the top of twin peaks. But one can get a clear view of the city and the Golden Gate Bridge depending upon the fog.
author: Shail P.

description:
A must visit when in San Francisco!! The views here are just spectacular. You can see the whole SF skyline from the top of Twin Peaks. This is a popular tourist attraction, so if the weather is nice and the sun is out - be warned cause you'll see one tourist bus to another, full parking lot and plenty of people trying to get that perfect panorama/profile shot.

We came here on a gloomy, misty day and it was perfect to be honest. It wasn't crowded, we easily found a parking spot and didn't have to fight other people to get a good picture. 

Definitely check this spot out if you're visiting the city!
author: Patricia A.

description:
Must go if you want to see an amazing view of the city! It's absolutely beautiful day and night. I personally like it better at night because of all the lights but it does get pretty chilly so bring a jacket! There are paid telescopes but some don't require coins, they might have made some free! Parking can be a hassle depending on what time of day you decide to go. I think it gets a little packed at night mainly because the view is breathtaking and more people come to see the city lights. I did come on a foggy day and it wasn't worth it at all. I ended up getting wet from the fog and could barely see anything, but it was still fun! 

Definitely worth visiting if you haven't already. You won't regret it!
author: Sheila C.

description: Beautiful views of the city definitely a place to put on the list while in town. It can get packed but with most places you wait long enough it will open up. Parking can get a bit tricky but if you drive a little further theres always spaces available.
author: Theodore D.

description:
The Spanish conquistadors of the 18th century called the area "Los Pechos de la Chola" or "Breasts of the Indian Maiden." Under American control during the 19th century, it was renamed "Twin Peaks."

Totally worth the drive for a panoramic view of The City by the Bay! The morning fog hovered over the Golden Gate Bridge, but we still caught some fantastic views of downtown San Francisco and Alcatraz.

You can drive all the way up to the lookout or park at the bottom of the hill for a good 1-mile hike up a steep incline. There is a public parking lot offering about 10 free stalls and two public toilets that are the European self-cleaning type. Tourist busses find their way up here, too, so depending on the time of day/year, expect a lot of visitors.

Add this landmark to your San Francisco itinerary. It reminds me of the Mt. Tantalus lookout in Oahu, Hawaii!
author: Jessica P.

description: Twin Peaks are two hills with an elevation of about 925 feet. We only went to the top of one of the hills. It was an easy drive up and luckily there was parking available. A set of stairs take you up to the peak. Unfortunately, the view was obstructed by fog. It was also windy, so make sure to bring a jacket.
author: Helen H.

description:
The best views of San Francisco.

Popular with locals and tourists alike, Christmas Tree Point at the north end of Twin Peaks offers a sweeping view of the city with the SF Bay as a backdrop. You can see straight down Market St, lined by some of the skyscrapers that make up the city skyline. On a typical foggy day, the sight of the city emerging as the fog begins to roll away is truly a sight. And at night, the city shimmers in a chorus of lights that brings the city to life in a whole new way.

Parking is available right at this lookout point, as well as along the road leading up to it. It's also possible to hike here from the base of the hills. The trail takes you up and across both peaks before leading down to the lookout point. Enjoy the views without needing to worry about parking! Just bring a jacket, because it can get extra windy and chilly up on top.
author: Anson W.

description:
Beautiful views from Twin Peaks. So close to Golden Gate Park, Mount Davidson and The Castro neighbourhood. Honestly, San Francisco is filled with these hills and peaks, it's just amazing how many options in different neighbourhoods! 

Gorgeous views up here especially on bright sunny days. Have come here only once so need to come back again ASAP!
author: Heliana M.

description:
There is a fantastic view of San Francisco from the top, where you can see the entire city spread beneath you. Another advantage is that you can drive pretty much the entire way up to the top if you don't like hikes. However, it is very windy and can get very cold at the top, so be sure to bring a sweater or a jacket even if it is a hot day outside! We couldn't stay on the summit for more than a couple minutes due to the wind. The photo ops are beautiful though.

I prefer the hikes at Land's End and the Presidio because they are more secluded and most of those hikes do not have long stretches of road, but I think this hike is worth doing for the view at least once. Be prepared though that if you drive to the parking lot, the actual hike itself is very short and consists only of a couple dozen stairs up to ether peak.
author: Amy C.

description: The views here are breath taking! Getting here is a trek but well worth the madness.  Lots of tourist up here.  There is a nice panoramic view of the the Bay Area!
author: Amorsolo D.

description:
What more can I say that hasn't been already said? 

Twin Peaks offers some of the best views of San Francisco! It feels a bit remote when you travel up to the lookout. It can be cold, windy, misty or foggy (even during the summer); however, the drive is worth taking at least once or twice!

If you're a photographer, then I recommend taking the trip in the afternoon. The Sun shining from the west provides some great light upon the city.
author: Chris M.

description:
Such a beautiful place to get a 360 view of the entire city of San Francisco. If there's only one place you're able to go while in San Francisco, then be sure to make it this one. It is a must do and it's free to go. 

I went to the overlook they had and you're able to see the bay and and San Francisco. We spent about 15 minutes taking pictures. It's quick you park take a couple pictures then you're on your way. Parking wasn't too difficult to find. You can also climb the Twin Peaks as well and they are the highest points in San Francisco.

It can get really windy up here. When we went the wind was really starting to pick up. So come before 5pm because the wind starts to pick up and the fog starts to roll in. I haven't seen this place during the  night and I've heard it's really beautiful as well so I'll definitely be back.
author: Karen C.

description:
This is one of the best experiences that I can ask for especially after a long day of travel. The food is fantastic, the team members here truly believe in customer 1st!! Every time I've visited this restaurant, management has always done their very best to ensure that I had a great experience!! As someone who works in customer service and travel all over the state its refreshing to be in an environment where the staff truly rolls out the red carpet!! I highly recommend Indianapolis, IN location.

Alvin, Indianapolis, In
author: Alvin E.

description:
This was one of the highlights of my weekend in California. If you have a list of tourist things to do - add Twin Peaks! We made sure to dress in layers and grab a cup of coffee, and up.. and up.. and up we drove until we were way above the city.

It was busy, but we snagged a parking spot and just enjoyed the view. The city lights at night are almost overwhelming.
author: Alison C.

description:
Twin Peaks is a really nice instagram-worthy spot to visit, especially if it's your first time in the Bay Area. The drive up is pretty safe, and the main sight-seeing location is easy to find. We went on a Tuesday at around 3pm, and were able to find parking quickly. Even though it was a sunny day, we found it to be quite windy, so dress with a lot of layers! When the sky is clear, you can see from the Golden Gate Bridge all the way to the Financial District and everything in between.

Next time, I'll come here at night to see the city lights of San Francisco!
author: George L.

description:
Such a beautiful place to take your family or those who are from out of the area! The view from the top is spectacular and breathtaking! 

I went at night and the view of the city lights and the bridges were just as spectacular as the view during the day. It was a little chilly and it did start to drizzle a little when I went, but it didn't matter! 

They have a couple of those telescopes if your kids want a "closer" view of the city. I don't know if you have to pay to use them, but they are there! 

Parking - I had no issues with parking at night, but I can imagine it could get busy if you went on a weekend during the day or night. The parking is free by the way! Yay for free parking!
author: Joe R.

description: This place offers amazing views of the city.  It gets chilly up there so make sure to take a jacket. If you don't want to deal with the traffic coming up, park your car in the neighborhood at the base and take the unofficial trails up. Be careful because they are full of poison oak.
author: Emmanuel T.

description:
Reviewer # 962

This area is breathtaking. Because of the beauty of the city, and how this locations allows you to basque in it, deserves a 5 star in and of its own. Above the city, you get to see all the lights and the water. It's very beautiful to take in. 

There are self cleaning bathrooms up there, too, or at least there was the time I visited before this one. This time, the city was so foggy that you couldn't see the Golden Gate at all from ground and when we got up to Twin Peaks, it was low 50's, sprinkling, and too foggy to see anything- In MID JULY! 

I was traveling from Vegas back to Boise, by way of my favorite city. I left Vegas at 113 and it was low 50's in S.F. which was a temperature shock to our bodies. WE will stop here again when we are back in the city as we always do.
author: Greg D.

description:
When you pull up to the viewpoint at Twin Peaks and see the few number of people at the top, you have to wonder: where is everybody? Why on earth do so many people flock over to huge attractions in SF like Fisherman's Wharf or touristy places like the Space Needle, but you will rarely have to fight through crowds or pay a dime to engulf yourself in the beauty of the city skyline? 

In my honest opinion, Twin Peaks is probably one of the most underrated attractions in the Bay Area. When people talk about San Francisco, you most likely won't hear about Twin Peaks. But why not? Once you visit this magical place, you'll never forget about it. And here's why.

When you drive into San Francisco, you have most likely seen a huge red tower up on the clouds. That, my friends is the Sutro Communication Tower and the marker for where Twin Peaks is located. Even from far away, Twin Peaks COMMANDS your attention. To access the top, you can either hike the one mile up or just drive. Either is fine because there probably won't be too many people here. 

I recommend coming at night because there's only few sights that can rival the beauty of the SF skyline at night. I've come here at least 5-6 times with different groups of friends during the nighttime, and each time every one I go with falls in love with the view. You can probably spend hours up at the top just picking out the different buildings in a sea of skyscrapers. And if that doesn't convince you to check this place out, my freshman college roommate took my advice and actually proposed to his girlfriend at Twin Peaks! This place is so magical that it brings people together haha!

tl;dr Twin Peaks is gorgeous and an absolute must see for both Bay Area natives and tourists alike. If you think proposing to someone on the Eiffel Tower is overrated, doing it here is definitely now.

Have fun and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
Worth the drive or hike up! Great views of SF. Need I say more. 

It can get windy up here.
author: Clarence E.

description: If you've never been to San Francisco and are debating if visiting Twin Peaks is worth an add on your itinerary, then I would suggest you add. Beautiful views of the entire city during the day and night. 100% worth it!
author: Juan M.

description: This was our first time visiting this spot after hearing so much positive reviews from friends.  We took public transportation up to twin peaks and hike up those steep steps.  We carried our heavy back pack along with us which was a major mistake.  The hike was exhausting up those steps.  The view at the top is beautiful. You get to see Golden Gate Bridge, alcatraz, down town, ports..ect...pretty much you get to see the entire SF and across the bay to Oakland.  It is a bit windy so bring a light jacket will be good.
author: Sydney T.

description:
Gorgeous views. You can see the entire city from up here including the Golden Gate Bridge. 

There is also a parking lot so parking was easy. Great for jog too if you live in the area.

Good for photos!
author: Wendi J.

description: We did not go on a good day it would appear. Went to watch the sunrise but unfortunately the entire mountain was very foggy and incredibly cold. Can see how this would be an ideal spot to view the city given the perfect conditions. Check fog forecast if possible and definitely wear more layers than you think you'll need.
author: David W.

description:
Definitely lots of tourists here but still one of my favorite places in the city. I've visited SF close to a dozen times and I still have not found a place with a better view. Parking has been pretty easy every time I went, and it's a great place to go if you don't have much time since all you have to do is get out of your call, walk a few steps and take in the gorgeous view. 

The only negatives are:
1. Sometimes it's hard to get that "perfect" picture since it is a popular tourist spot and can get really crowded 
2. Depending on the day, it can be VERY windy. I came here during Thanksgiving weekend once and the wind was so strong that I thought I was going to get blown off my feet. 

Highly recommend for anyone who is visiting SF for the first time!
author: Christina C.

description:
The pictures do NOT do this place justice. I wouldn't have sought out Twin Peaks if it hadn't been a stop on the Painted Ladies Tour Company (highly recommend). It is a steep, steep incline to get there, but the panoramic views at the top are well worth it. You feel like you're on top of the world (err, the city at least) and can get a better feel for the lay of the land. Our tour guide helped point out the major spots so we could understand the city geography better.

On a foggy day, the view would not be nearly as spectacular, but on a clear, sunny day, Twin Peaks offers an unparalleled view of San Francisco.
author: Katie U.

description:
pretty cool look-out spot ! a must if you are visiting SF! great views of the SF skyline, market street and at a distance the ferry building. 

very touristy, lots of people, everyone is pretty nice in offering to take photos. 

the park is open 24 hours a day 7 days a week and is free! 

general information: 

Hours: 5am to Midnight
Address:
501 Twin Peaks Blvd
San Francisco, CA 94114
Phone: (415) 831-2700
Accessibility: Accessible
Parking: Yes
Restrooms: Yes 

for more information:
http://sfrecpark.org/destination/twin-peaks/
author: Cesar C.

description:
Good for:
1. Great day/night view of San Francisco
2. Birthday celebration 
3. Sunset
4. View both Golden gate and bay bridge 
5. Take some great Panoramic Images 

This is a great place to see whole of San Francisco at once. There is a lot of free parking available here. You get to see both golden gate and bay bridge from this spot. Enjoy a lovely and romantic sunset. 

Do not forget to actually climb the two peaks. Have fun.
author: Nishant M.

description:
This is my go to chill spot in San Francisco!
It overlooks most of the northern part of the city and the view is incredible. It takes my breath away every time I visit! The best time to come see the view is sunrise or sunset but depending on what day of the week, it can get pretty crowded. So recently I've been going late at night. There's usually only about one other group up there with us if you come past 11pm.

If you come to visit I suggest you dress in layers because it is often windy or chilly. I don't think I've ever came here and it wasn't cold!

Lock up your valuables in an out of sight area in your car. There has been a lot of break ins and robberies recently. On that note I suggest you come here with a group. I wouldn't ever come up here alone unless it was during the busy times.

Parking is fairly limited. There's a few parking spots along the side but keep in mind there is a side lot next to the tower as well. If you are driving through, the side lot will be on the left.
author: Alyssa M.

description: Beautiful sights and absolutely breathtaking.  It's a bit of a trek getting up here, and it doesn't seem like there were that many parking spots, but if you're lucky and you're up here on a clear day, you'll never want to leave.  I've been here twice, once at night and once in the day time but on a foggy day, both were fantastic.  It's such a game changing when you're here at night, you'll get to see the city light up!  Really fun, definitely a great place to stop by when you're in the city.
author: Anna L.

description:
Magnificent 360 views of SFO - no matter the time! Day time gives a clear view of the  land, the sea and the in between. You can opt to hike or just drive all the way to the top. Please be careful of the high speed cars if you are planning for a hike.

Night time gets colder but better. City lights and the sparkle is simply spectacular. You could just stare at it forever. 

Perfect place for out of town friends. Touristy but totally worth it! Have fun!

Tips:
- Bring a jacket. Quite windy at day time and freezing at night. Better still, bring along a blanket and just nestle on the ledge.
- Get some quarters if you wish to use the telescopes
- Choose a day when fog is not dense and weather is clear for photos. Day after rains is perfect.
- Public restrooms are located at the top.
- Do not leave your valuables in the car.
author: Sudesna M.

description:
Most ideal for watching sunset and the city scape at night! And perfect for photography!

But difficult to find parking here. And be near the crowd, there has been incidents recently, robbing!! Especially if photographing with expensive equipment, don't go here alone! A photographer was killed recently here by burglars!

BE NEAR CROWDS!!
author: Deebs M.

description: If you want some good pics on a clear day of SF, this is the place.  Not to  be missed.  Highly recommended.
author: Paul W.

description:
Definitely one of the best views of the city. So good that it's getting a lot more tourist and/or visitor traffic. I remember when I used to come here years ago and people didn't quite know how to get here and/or you could still park easily in the lot. But went here late on a cold and windy Tuesday night and I had to park down the street. 

Will always be one of my favorite places to enjoy the city lights.
author: Sanz E.

description:
DOV: 11/12/16 
1st stop | 8 AM-8:30 AM 

WOWZERS. 

It seems slightly out of way from the other attractions in SF (it's smack dab in the middle of the "left hemisphere" and "right hemisphere") but DEFINITELY take visiting folks here! 

I came on a Saturday 8 AM, and it was not packed at all- plenty of parking spaces, and gorgeous (Karl is beautiful) weather. Not too cold, but I had jackets in the trunk just in case. 

Tip 1: if you want to hike...please read http://www.choisser.com/hiking/twinpeaks.html. It seemed like a lot of people were just taking the road up, which is super dangerous since cars are constantly swerving close to the end to avoid hitting the incoming traffic on this two-way lane. 

Tip 2: Public bathroom at the top! HUZZAH! 

Tip 3: Bring quarters if you want to use the telescopes! $0.50. 

Breathe in the air, stretch, wait for the fog to clear up, identify main streets, take touristy photos...great spot that is so serene before you start your day! 

Photos are self explanatory- must see attraction!
author: Hurjane V.

description:
The view up here was just amazing. You can see the whole of San Francisco from here. Bring quarters if you want to use the telescopes. 

It will be windy and chilly if you choose to come in the early morning hours. The way up to the top was curvy with turns so drive slowly.

Go before 10 AM so you'll have a parking spot since it's a first come, first serve scenario.
author: Andrea M.

description: We were fortunate to visit on a very nice clear day.  A friend showed us around San Fo and I can say this was one of the highlights.  We pretty much saw the whole city with the bay on each side. You can also see the Golden gate bridge from afar.  So make sure to bring your cameras and selfie sticks because this is surely a picture perfect place. Make sure to layer your clothing as it gets really windy and cold specially at this time.  A word of caution though... make sure not to leave valuables inside your car because apparently theft is rampant in this place.
author: Lani P.

description: Beautiful view didn't want to leave but it was cold.. worth the trip to view an awesome sight.
author: Vien L.

description:
Amazing views of the city!

We took public transportation to Twin Peaks, and it was very easy.  Just take bus line 37 and it should drop you right off at the bottom of Twin Peaks.  Then just climb the dirt stairs all the way to the top for amazing views of the city.  

Just a word of advice or a warning, if you will, it gets extremely cold and windy up there.  I will repeat it for emphasis, it gets extremely cold and windy up there.  I had read a lot of Yelp reviews saying that it's freezing and windy so I at least was prepared but still, it's pretty damn cold and windy.  We got there when it was close to night fall and pretty much froze and almost got blown over by the wind, but it was all worth it for some incredible views of the city.  

I would really recommend visiting, especially if you're only in town for a few days.  It's pretty easy to get to via public transportation or car.  Just remember to bundle up and be prepared for the wind.
author: Pricilla D.

description: This place has been on my list since forever (I grew up in a city about an hour southeast of SF, but I've never been until really recently). I finally got to go, and it's pretty great! We walked up which wasn't bad at all, and the view was really nice. We came on a really sunny day so we could see the city and even the bridge! Awesome (free) place to go in the city; definitely recommend it. I want to come back at nighttime sometime so I can see it. I also need to bring my proper camera next time!
author: Andrea W.

description: We came here on Sunday evening, but there were still a lot of people in there. It was a beautiful view on San Francisco, on downtown and Bay Bridge. We parked our car downhill and climbed up to the hill from there. The weather was good enough, a little cold but that actually was cool! There is a stairs going up to the 2 hills, free clean restrooms, and nice view for photographers.
author: Sofya K.

description:
I have only been here once (4/1/2017) and let me tell you, it is absolutely ridiculously amazingly insanely beautiful up there. If I lived in SF I would go as much as I could and I can guarantee I would never get sick of it.

My boyfriend and I went around 7:45 p.m. it wasn't crazy busy (not that I have anything to compare it to lol) and we were able to park at the very top of the peak. It was only slightly foggy but it was windy as HECK. I made the dumb move and didn't bring a jacket with me so I was a popsicle in less than 5 minutes. IT GETS FREAKING COLD. My gawd, bring a jacket.. don't be stupid.. like me. lol but thankfully thee boyfriend had an extra jacket and I only froze to death for a few minutes.

This is one of those landmarks where ANY photo posted here will NOT do it justice. You need to see it for yourself. Its absolutely breathtaking. Seeing the fog ingulf the golden gate bridge, the beautiful lights, the buildings, cars, the water, and an endless beautiful night sky.. good Lord I fell in love with the city from up there!

We went at a perfect time but I would love to see it during the day and when its covered in fog.. I can only image that both are just as beautiful. So if you live in SF or plan to visit... GO.. GO NOW. HURRY!

Overall:
Drive up: 4
Parking: 3-ish (We didn't have a problem but I can imagine it on a busy night.. from what I saw there aren't much places to park)
View: 100000000000+
Would I come back: In a heartbeat.
author: Abbey M.

description:
Unbelieveable view and picture opportunities.  
Parking wasn't too bad surprisingly. A must stop if visiting. Very windy...dress accordingly
author: Rick C.

description:
I've lived in the city my whole life and this priceless spot is a great reminder of how beautiful it is. 

Make sure to check the microclimate weather before going. On a sunny, fogless day you can see a clean sweep of the city and the bay. It's definitely a nice place to take pictures and take in the fresh air. I spent about 20 minutes here with my friends viewing and chatting. You can hike up or drive up. There's limited free parking.
author: Cameron G.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here to watch the sun set over San Francisco one day. While the view was truly amazing, it was so windy and so cold that we couldn't stay longer than an hour and I can't bring myself to give a rating with more than 3 stars.

I do think we would have been more satisfied if we were better prepared for the weather and thus dressed more appropriately...so let this serve as a warning to BRING A SWEATER, or three. Someday I'll come back knowing what I know now and possibly feel the need to up my rating. Until then, stay warm Yelpers.
author: Julianna W.

description:
The views from here are stupendous and it's one of my favourite places in the city! If you've ever visited San Francisco, Twin Peaks should definitely be on your short list of places to visit. These two hills have an elevation of over 900 feet and only surpassed by Mount Davidson by a couple feet.

As you drive up to the top, you can enjoy the residential architecture on the way. And when you reach the top, you can savor the spectacular views of the Bay Area with 180-degree views! Some advice before visiting:

- It is very windy on top of Twin Peaks so bring a hoodie and something to secure your hair unless you want to take those selfies with your hair whipping around.

- If it's foggy, Twin Peaks sits in the middle of it and you won't see anything except fog all around you which makes driving up to the top a little dicey with the turns and twists. Drive slowly and be safe. 

- You can visit up until midnight. The views are beautiful when the view is clear with the city lights twinkling below. 

- Pets are allowed, just keep them on a leash when outside of the vehicles.

- Parking is limited so be patient when you arrive. You might have to wait in a queue to pull into a space. If you are up for a challenge, take the stairs from the bottom and get a great workout.

- There is a public restroom at the main parking lot but I can't comment on its cleanliness because I have never used it.

- Many of San Francisco's landmarks are visible from the viewing area next to the parking lot. On a clear day, you can see the Golden Gate Bridge, Bay Bridge, Alcatraz, Transamerica Building, downtown skyscrapers, Market Street, the Pacific, Golden Gate Park and more.

- Lastly if you visit during April and May, you might see the Mission Blue Butterfly. Twin Peaks is only one of two places in the entire world where you can see this endangered butterfly so keep your eyes open!
author: Kristine H.

description: Nice view. Took my mom and my little son  here . I think it would be better if you go at night . It was nice in the morning but better at night . Next time I will take my sister in law since it's close to my mom's house .
author: Miok C.

description: The view at this location is amazing!!! We got there just after the sun had set and it was beautiful! The sky was still blue but you could see all the beautiful city lights! Definitely worth the drive and the freezing temps and high winds!!!
author: Missy H.

description: Great place to go to get a good picture 360 degree view of the city!! The drive and parking is no charge.
author: Cynthia Y.

description: Weekends are the perfect time for me to head over to Twin Peaks, especially when the weather is clear.  Cool, warm, and breezy make no difference to me.  I'm taking the trail leading towards one of the peaks to see the extremely endangered rare Mission Blue butterflies.  I had my chances on a second day, but no luck.  To me, it's like searching for an rare Pokemon.  What I see so far are other common butterflies.  I've seen a pair flutter so quickly in a spiral version.  If you happened to be on one of the peaks, be sure to look at the shadow on a ground for a fluttery butterfly.  You also feel the strong breeze while at the top of the peak.
author: Jimmy C.

description: Simply the most stunning views of San Fran. And I mean 360° views of the city. We rushed here to catch the sunset. Caught the last bit of it before darkness. Even in the dark it was amazing. There are plenty other views you can get if the city but this is great. I never knew Twin Peaks was an actual place that existed in San Fran. I've been to the restaurant and always thought it was a place in Denver or some mountainous region. But wow. Glad I made the stop! This is a permanent addition to my list of places to go in San Fran. Take the extra little hike up that mini hill and you will be impressed and it's very worth it. Just ignore the field mice! Absolutely gorgeous.
author: Pam M.

description: So pretty!! It was windy when we went and our hats flew off lol. The view was to do for. A little across the way, we found a little hike with another view. We slipped a few times. Stair would have been nice.
author: Yasmin J.

description: One of the best spots SF has! Must go if you're travelling to SF, the great place to see SF in one frame. I recommend going there after March when there are no clouds and less windy.
author: Maulik S.

description: Dope spot to get a photo of the cityscape. Easy to get to. Free 99! Lots of other people around, but so worth the shots if you're a tourist. Check it out!
author: Kimberly B.

description: Easy "hike" more like climbing a couple flights of stairs. Parking can be limited so be prepared. The views are fantastic and going during the early hours or evening is gorgeous.
author: Jessica L.

description: what an incredible sight!! this spot really makes you take in the amazing nature of the city #blessed!
author: David A.

description:
Twin Peaks is tourist central. This is mainly due to the phenomenal views.

I asked my wife if she wanted to go to Twin Peaks and you should have seen the look on her face. "No, not that Twin Peaks."

This was one of our last stops on our trip to San Francisco, we actually Uber'd up. 

Most of the other people here were on large tour buses. I could see them as we approached and immediately became sick to my stomach.

There are two peaks here, hence the name, the northern most peak has good views of the city and the bay and the southern peak has a views of the rest of SF and the ocean. I preferred the southern peak as this one was not inhabited with tourists.
author: Rawlins R.

description:
750+ feet above sea level at the parking lot, more in hilltops, this is a view no other American city can compete with. Toursists are up there pretty much 24/7 and on a good day you can get a sunset on the ocean. 

The geographic center and highest point in SF this is a must see once in your lifetime.

Parking is a little limited and it can be frigid with the wind, but with ample time and clothing it's breathtaking.
author: David A.

description:
I cannot believe I have been missing out on this view! I have never come here until my last visit and it was awesome. 

Hands down the best view of the SF skyline I have seen. 

Easy to drive to and free parking.

Again, that view though!
author: Kevin W.

description:
PREP be ready for a narrow windy curvy road to get up here. Also bring jackets! It's very windy up here like mess up your hair and in your face windy. Only gets more cold as the day and night comes in. Parking available and no charge.

VIEW is really expansive. Was clear when I came with a shadow because the sun was setting. They have binocular stations too. Since it was so windy my friend and I opted to take a few pictures then go back to the car ASAP and look at the view and sunset from the warmth of the car and shelter from the high winds. 

OTHER there were Asian people standing around with flyers and poster boards to educate people about organ trade selling. Kind of an odd place to post up but sure why not. I took a brochure when it was offered to me. I give them props for standing outside in the wind and cold! 

OVERALL I am a fan. Could be a good date spot to check out view. Get selfies together. Maybe bring a selfie stick. Or ask someone else. Do ppl still ask other ppl to take pics for them nowadays? Haha. Then hang out in the car and get to know each other. Good spot to bring family and friends from out of town. Just be sure they bring a good jacket!
author: Michelle M.

description:
What's not to love... 

Twin Peaks is the place to visit whether you're from the city, from the Bay Area or from this earth. 

Twin Peaks has some of the best views in the entire Bay Area. 

Come here in the morning and you can see the fog rolling over the city by the bay. 

Come in the evening and you can see the city lights and the bay bridge in the distance.


Come here, take in the view, snap some pictures for social media and enjoy life.
author: Steven T.

description:
Can't believe I never visited here previously.  I even made myself bookmark this place so I can finally check out all the hoopla.  Over the weekend, my husband and I were nearby to pick up something and I made him stop here to I can finally see for myself the view.

And it was great.

Helped that we were blessed with a great Sunny afternoon.  I'm sure a clear evening would even be more magnificent.

We parted at one of the stops and walked up towards the main viewing site.  All of the view were great.  There is plenty of parking around this area (such a huge plus for SF).  

Here's where you want that instapic!  Totally glad I got to finally see it to remind me why I love the Bay Area.  I want to drag my husband up here on an evening next time.
author: Kim D.

description:
Initially, Twin Peaks was near the bottom of our list of places to see in San Francisco. I still don't have a clue why we almost missed out, but I'm so happy we decided to go in the end.

The view on a clear day is spectacular. One of the peaks is definitely more popular and scenic than the other, so if you only want to climb one of them, go for the hill that's closer to the Golden Gate Bridge. And like a visit to the Bridge, the best time to make the hike is when there's a minimal amount of fog obscuring the city below (although this isn't really a tip if you're familiar with San Francisco's typical weather conditions). There are wooden boards along the side of the hills that mark the path leading up and down; however, it's still somewhat challenging for the average person who isn't comfortable walking on an incline. Bring walking shoes and a light jacket, as it can get very windy!

Some of my favorite pictures were captured at Twin Peaks, and it was unquestionably one of the highlights of our trip. While it's technically considered a tourist attraction, I'd urge everyone, including SF natives, to drive up here on a nice day and take advantage of the beautiful scenery.
author: Daniela L.

description:
My goodness this place is so awesome. I have to say it's really addicting. Why? If you come here once you will want to come here again. I love it so much with the great views and the calm. If you are a hiker then give this place a shot as well you won't regret it. During the day the view is really clear. My ex came here at night and the view is even better during that time of the day. I heard about this place from her and a few friends at my old church. This place is best part of San Francisco as with the Legion of Honor too. You can also go on both hills as well. I took the bus here and it was a great trip with my mum. Many people spend three hours here.
Drawback: the bus can be real slow if you come here. You may have to wait awhile after your hike. If you drive parking can be tough. Come early
author: Michael W.

description: Best views of the city! Be mindful there are stairs going up both sides of the hill but there is no handrail. If you're not in shape you'll be out of breath once you reach the top. There is a landing down below if you can't climb the hill but the view isn't as great. Great spot for first time visitors to the Bay Area.
author: Rae S.

description: Great view of the golden gate bridge and SFO skyline. Stopped by here just shortly. There is a ledge where you can sit and hang out but there were lots of debris (even broken bottles) on the ground. Be careful.
author: Lily C.

description:
If I lived on the hill that you have to drive around to get to the top, I would totally come here every day to see the sun set. The view is breathtaking at night; you can see the Golden Gate Bridge AND the Bay Bridge, and watch the glittering lights of the city below. Climbing to the top of the hill is not difficult, just take your time! 

Looking at the gorgeous homes on the way up is part of the experience too for me; the architecture of many were very contemporary!
author: Amelia J.

description:
The place to go when you see all of San Francisco. 

We went up here at 11:30pm on a cold, clear night. The view up here is gorgeous. You can see the golden gate bridge, bay bridge, market street...pretty much the entire city. This needs to be on the to do list for everyone wanting the complete SF experience. 

Tip: Forget the camera, just take it all in and take a mental picture. 

Pro tip: We went on a cold night and brought a thermos of hot chocolate and just sat up there admiring the view. Perfect.
author: Jen P.

description:
Best Landmark...or Really Landmarks I've ventured to in 2015!!! First time was myself flying solo...hiking up many steps, from concrete till dirt till wooden steps, till asphault. Getting semi lost, then getting back on the right direction. LOL 

It was a Sunday morning in September 2015, where I finally enjoyed time to myself, just me alone, amongst the high attitude and white morning fog surrounding me. Paparazzi time! Haha, I took so many pictures once I reached the top of the 2 Twin Peaks! Of course, I took pics & videos to document my first trek towards and up to Twin Peaks! Also, I only had my flip flops on hiking up and down all those rocky steps! 

Another second time, I was lucky to be with my son and even more blessed it was on a clear SF night where my son could enjoy the lovely sunset! I love sunsets! I'm more of a sunset girl than a sunrise person. Yet, who knows, maybe one day I may change my mind. LOL. I prefer staring off into the sunset, with all the piercing rays seeping through my eyes and innermost dark spaces & awake my soul. 

There were so many people above the peak we were on by the time it was ready to view the beautiful sunset. All the clouds above strewn and reflecting the multitudes of the sun rays as the sun was making it's way down the horizon. Many people were taking pictures & also I saw a group video the entire spectacle with a tripod holding their cellphone up in the sunset's direction the entire time. Smart of that person. I also had the delightful pleasure to see many monarch butterflies dancing fluttering around in front of me above the rocky dirt ground. They were sooo pretty! ^_^

In general, most people either are locals who hike, run, or walk up, down, and around the peaks OR are tourists! I was fortunate to play both parts. First time as a local neighbor and second experience as a tourist. LOL.

This is definitely one of my favorite destinations in San Francisco, CA. Until my next adventure... Miss breathing in the cool foggy mist...I bid adieu.
author: Andrea S.

description: Love the view!!! :) It is a tourist hot spot. The first time I tried to go, they closed up the peak for maybe road maintenance! :( But I'm glad I got to see it this time! You can actually see the Golden Gate from here too! :)
author: Michelle C.

description:
I get to see Twin Peaks every day from my kitchen window.  I also try to drive up there once a month to see the views of the city and surrounding bay.  I especially like to find the GGB on a clear day---like yesterday.  As people have written before, it's a beautiful view.
Yes, if you are visiting or if you live here, you must come to see what others have seen.
It can be windy, cold, sunny, warm, foggy etc--dress in layers and shed appropriately if need be!
Parking is an issue--don't let that stop you, you may have to wait for a parking spot--no biggie.
author: Thomas D.

description:
The amazing city view can be seen on top of twin peaks! Came here before the sun was going to set. There was a good amount of people walking around but luckily we found a park spot right in front of the sunset! It was honestly breath taking, one of the best views you will see in SF.  Good thing was that it wasn't foggy so I took some nice clear pictures. 

P.S DRESS WARM, it was freezing!
author: Natalie L.

description: 2nd time here but always on a rush to go else where so I did not get to spent quality time here. A somewhat rainy day today, but still the views are great and it is free. What more can you ask?
author: Keo N.

description: WARNING: Only come here on a clear , sunny day. If you don't, you'll find yourself in my position, which was chasing after my sunglasses after they flew off my head. Yeah. It was that windy. As for the view, I have nothing to say about it because it was so dang foggy!
author: Jade L.

description:
Outstanding view of San Francisco that you cannot get anywhere else in the city! 

The drive up to the view can be challenging, I really hope you own an Automatic transmission vehicle... You can see the downtown skyline, the bay/ocean with a mountain backdrop and the Golden Gate Bridge, what more can you ask for?! A free view that is priceless, make the trip up to Twin Peaks, you will not be disappointed.
author: Jessee L.

description: PHOTO OPPORTUNITY: Another SF view you should not miss. I go to SF now and again and am always looking for places with an amazing Bay Area view and this SF visiting area with convenient parking is quite easy to get to. Don't leave your car unlocked with valuables in your car for very long as there were plenty of break-in warnings when I visited the place.
author: Tuyen P.

description:
I wish I would have seen this during the day, 2 days ago was the first time I got to venture out to twin peaks.  Heard many great things about it.  Its such a great view of San Francisco, and the bay. We went at night, so the city lights were nice.  

Seems like the spot to get your hippie-on. If you know what I mean.
author: Jenny L.

description: A moderate walk/"hike" up a hill of you're coming from Miraloma. You get fantastic views of the city and I highly recommend it. You are also able to drive and park, but keep in mind weekends are super busy.
author: Lupita D.

description:
I would love to give this place 10 stars... This place has an amazing view and just being there is so nice and relaxing... 
I love going here at night and at sunset... 
Its always a little cold and windy but I love going to this place...
author: Rupa S.

description:
Went to middle school remotely close to this spot..... but never really learned to appreciate this stunning scenic spot. Have been here on a couple occasions.... great for hanging out with friends, thinking about life or even for napping in the car. 

Usually very crowded at night during weekend nights so parking spots can be filled up easily but don't worry, you can just park on the side curbs of the road. 

The Scenic spot shows pretty much the majority of the city lit up at night which makes it one of the most noticeable spots in the city. There have been occasions where i see police patrolling the area too so becareful in what you do there but at the same time... you can feel safe appreciating the late night sessions. 

5/5 location.
author: Auden W.

description:
Such a beautiful view of the city! We went up on a Saturday around 6pm after the fog burned off. Parking wasn't a hassle, and there was plenty of places to see a great view. 

Paid $0.50 for the telescope, and I was able to see my house (and the houses of other friends too!). Really fun way to spend an hour.
author: Priya B.

description: Beautiful but sooooooo windy / cold. We got there at 7pm  and by 7:05 were calling a Lyft back. We couldn't handle the chill, even with sweater, jackets and scarves.
author: Joanne R.

description: Twin peak offers great views of San Francisco on a clear day or night. Half the time, the views can be marred by haze or mist so count your blessings if you happen to visit when the weather is good. We happened to be there on a clear night and the view of the city was simple awesome. Would definitely recommend. Parking can be difficult during weekends or on a clear day/night. Two restrooms are also available.
author: Raj G.

description:
Whether it be a tourist roaming San Francisco for the first time or a San Franciscan native just trying to enjoy a good night out with friends, this is the place to go to see the beautiful San Francisco city light! No matter where you are or where you go, once you get a look at the vantage point that Twin Peaks has to offer you will be hooked! 

Overall, this is the place to go whenever you have time to spare in the city. It offers a great scenery for romantic dates, tons of open space for a gather of friends to just chill, or even cold windy air for late night joggers. This is truly one of the many treasures that the great city of San Francisco has to offer!
author: Benson M.

description:
Loved going to Twin Peaks! It's a wonderful place to get the view of San Francisco. I went there with my family and had an amazing time during New Year's Eve. It was nice to get some fresh air and relax there. I heard it's really pretty at night, so next time I will definitely try to go there at night. I went during the day, it wasn't too packed. Although, it does get windy so bring a jacket. 

Good place to chill and there's parking there too!
author: Neelam M.

description:
San Francisco, CA: Not to be missed views! 

Undeveloped land in almost the geographic center of San Francisco! THAT bit of trivia I was not aware of at the time I visited. Nor was I aware that this was only one of a few areas in San Francisco Bay that provides habitat for the Mission Blue Butterfly. (Thanks , Eric Robert! )

We had only a short time to spend here, but what a well spent hour. Scoring a parking space in their visitor's lot, we quickly got out of the car to explore the spectacular views of The City and its environs at mid morning.  We were lucky that this day was clear. It was predictably windy. Others have already posted great commentary and visuals. A family member took a quick hike up one of the peaks.
Make time to take in the unmatched views from this great vantage point, any time of day or night. Much thanks to kind yelp friend Edwin R. for having suggested that my family and I see this almost overlooked, outstanding viewpoint in our San Francisco visit last March! 

ADDITIONAL VISITOR INFORMATION 
http://www.parksconservancy.org/conservation/plants-animals/endangered-species/mission-blue-butterfly.html

http://www.inside-guide-to-san-francisco-tourism.com/twin-peaks-san-francisco.html

http://sfrecpark.org/destination/twin-peaks/
author: Shal W.

description:
I went up around 2 PM on a Saturday in early December and the view was lovely, crowd was manageable, and parking plentiful. We must have come up from the wrong side of the road, because I didn't see the parking lot until we climbed up the peak and looked down on the other side. Instead, we parked at some of the pull-aways at the base of the peak.

From the car to the top of the peak, down and up to the other peak, took barely 45 minutes. It's a sunny hike though, so I was pretty glad we went during the winter. When we got to the top, it actually wasn't as windy as I'd feared it would be.
author: Sherry Z.

description:
I came early morning and unfortunately it still left the city under a blanket of fog, but it was still a lovely experience anyways. There's no real parking so find corners to squeeze in. 

It's incredibly windy, so even though the temperature wasn't too cold, you'll still want a jacket. Leave the hairspray at home; the winds will dictate what hairstyle you have. 

The view is gorgeous like no other place so it's a must see. Only other people there at the time were joggers, walkers, and cyclists. 

There was a couple in the car beside me getting their bidness on, so if you bring children or prudes, you'll want to give a looksy left and right first before stepping out. 
There were broken beer bottles strewn about near the entrance to the walkway so be keen of your surroundings, but by all means, enjoy the open air and the view.
author: Kay C.

description: This is an awesome location with awesome views of the entire city. I went with my brother to stop by and beat the crowds so show up before 11. The mist was clearing just as we got there, but we had to wait a little bit for it to fully be clear. I definitely come here again with my friends to show them the view if they've never been to San Francisco. I would hike up this peak if I had time, as many people were doing it for their morning workouts. Amazing!
author: Makio P.

description:
Equivalent to LA's Griffith Observatory - you get a view of the whole city on an elevated area. I think what makes Twin Peaks more unique though is the spiraled drive up - tons of turns on the way up, but it's definitely worth it to get a great view of the whole city.

I would suggest coming on a clear day since we all know SF is always foggy and cold and this makes it difficult to drive up, especially when it's dark. You feel like you're driving in a cloud and can't see what's ahead of you. Make sure to bring a jacket or dress in layers if you're coming late at night because SF tends to get extra cold at night...and if you're not used to that, it might feel like Antarctica. 

Definitely a place to visit whether you live in SF or not. I've only been once in the morning, so I'm not sure of this, but I know at night it's pretty hard to find parking because it gets super busy. City lights are so much cooler to see anyways. If you can't find parking where the telescopes are, you can always drive down and park somewhere on the side. 

There's a bathroom here but I think you have to pay for it...
author: Sydney C.

description: anytime we are in San Francisco we have to stop and take a few pics. We got to bring my sister's family this time around and got to show them the spots we like to go to. They loved it and kids got some good videos for the snap
author: IslandGirl 3.

description: The best way to see San Francisco. It may be difficult to get to, but it's so worth it! Especially at night!
author: Deserry A.

description: It's a beautiful gem, what more to say? Came here at night time and enjoyed the beautiful city lights, the view, and the cold weather. Drive up and parking here was super easy. Lots of tourist and locals which is nice to see as well. I always enjoy Twin Peaks- there's definitely a really positive type of zen when coming up here that's for sure.
author: S S.

description: Honestly the most breathtaking view I have ever seen! I came here on a Saturday morning with my friend and it was definitely full of tourists but we were lucky enough to find a parking spot right where the best view was. I love how you get to see the entire city and even the Golden Gate Bridge. I've been on skyscrapers and landmarks, but Twin Peaks is definitely my favorite. I don't think I'll ever get enough of this view! I'm so thankful my friend took me here!!
author: Cathy M.

description: There isn't much to say about Twin Peaks that can't be said by the hundreds of pictures fellow Yelpers have uploaded! The views of the city are absolutely spectacular - visitors and locals alike should make it a point to visit at least once! It does get windy, so be sure to bring a jacket and maybe pack away your hat. I was lucky enough to visit on a sunny day, but I would love to check out Twin Peaks on a foggy day.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Came during the night time when the moon was right. To be honest, best legal view I've gotten since! It's a hotspot, but the scene doesn't steal away your privacy.

Make sure to bring small throws because it gets chilly up here.
author: Linda X.

description: Absoltely breathtaking view, and one of the affordable San Francisco attractions. FREE :) Keep in mind it's very windy because of the high altitude and parking can get tricky but worth the trip. Not to mention hubby re-proposed here so I'm a little bias. ;)
author: Stephanie A.

description: My boyfriend and I were in town visiting from SoCal. We had some time to kill before dinner so we decided to stop by Twin Peaks. It was raining a lotttt that night so it was definitely a little scary driving up the road but the view was definitely worth it! It was extremely windy that night but still a sizable amount of people.
