We loved it so much that we came back the next day during the day to check out the view (and brought dim sum to eat while enjoying the view lol). There's a parking lot and we didn't have trouble finding parking either time, but we also went on a week night/weekday.
author: Amanda N.

description: It was closed for fireworks.  It was far from where I live but it didnt seem like it was that great to rationalize the drive when the Oakland Hills are closer to me.
author: Carrie S.

description:
The drive up here is through a neighborhood near Castro. It isn't a difficult drive and parking is fairly easy. There are two parking lots for both of the peaks (hence the name, TWIN Peaks)..Once you park, snap a few photos of the SF view and then take a quick hike up the stairs of one of the peaks and enjoy an even better 360 view of all of SF.

The stairs are uneven, some much higher than others so it may be hard for little kids or elderly people. There are no rails or anything to hold onto so it's best if you are steady on your feet.

It does get windy as you get higher up so dress appropriately, no dresses/skirts, and bring a jacket!
author: Minh-An C.

description: Great views! Lucky to be here on a beautiful and sunny day! I imagine the sunset and night views would be awesome as well.
author: Ron R.

description:
Sure gets crowded nowadays.  Ah, the joys of social media...

Beautiful views of San Francisco and the bay.  Both day light and dusk are great shooting times.
author: Tim L.

description: This place is a must tourist stop! It has amazing views of the city and it was so easy to get too. There was even a bathroom just incase. There was a lot of tour busses here but everyone is really ind and you can get anyone to take your picture! Try to come if you can!
author: Sara S.

description: Watched the fireworks on New Years here. It was beautiful. You can see the entire bay from here!
author: Breanna L.

description:
Newsflash:

Twin Peaks is NOT just a SF neighborhood or a cult TV show.

It's an actual place where you can get a bird's eye view of SF.

You can see quintessential SF landmarks like Auto Tower, the Pride flag, Market Street, and a red bridge 90% covered by Karl the Fog.

Oh you already knew? 

And you also know that it's near Christmas Tree Drive?

Are you judging me because I've lived in the city for many years and this was my first visit to Twin Peaks?

(Actually, I'm kinda with you there . . . )
author: Amy C.

description:
I've been here several times on several occasions.

The view up here cannot be beat. But SF has so many view spots which is pretty awesome. Twin peaks is definitely one of the better ones.

I've been here for sunrise as well as sunset and also at night. All views are equally amazing but I prefer night views in general.

Parking is tricky because this place is crowded. To get up here, you drive up a windy road. Haha

Great place to take friends, family, a date lol anyone! Haha

Definitely a must see in SF!
author: Jasmine N.

description:
YOU REALLY NEED TO GO TO THIS FABULOUS PLACE

when you visit the Twin Peaks you have the most great view of San Francisco

I can just recommend this place it's worth it
author: Franzi S.

description: Good photo place with the whole view of the city. The views are awesome and a must when you stop by in sf.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Gorgeous. 

We were coming back from Outer Sunset and our GPS decided to take us to Market to try and get back to Oakland (101/80)

Then we saw a sign. Twin Peaks.

Oh noes. It couldn't be. Could it? 

SO with 10% left on my phone battery, we trekked up to here! Be careful driving up, and follow the signs, they don't lead you astray! Parking wasn't too hard to findl there were plenty of spots here.

The lower peak gives you a view of the city. Breathtaking? Merp yeeee. You can probably see what that person all the way over there is doing. There's a lighted street, and idk what street that is, but it's a great picture shot. You can *barely* see the Golden Gate Bridge and definitely see Downtown! Great shots are definitely to be found here, along with the 16th Street Tiles/Grandview Park as well! 

The higher peak gives you a wee more height advantage to get a better view of everyhting else. Be careful though- the steps here, some are steeper than others. Don't trip don't fall! You can see almost the entire city of San Francisco.


It's a great place to just stop what you're doing and see what nature is bringing ye.

Unless it's raining and hailing. Don't come up here when you gets that.


I do have pictures but so do everyone else, so I may or may not upload them xD

Remember 10% battery, 7:30pm arrival. The pictures were getting dark, as the sun had set~ Sorryyyyyy
author: Raymond L.

description:
Though San Fran is so well known for its food, once I booked my plane ticket, I immediately looked up hiking spots. This came up first on my search. At first I was feeling super impelled to hike all the way up to the summit and then hike back down. That quickly changed after a super fulfilling breakfast and I began to feel sluggish. Plan B: Take an Uber to the summit, then hike back down.

Great idea! The uber driver brought us all the way up and we walked up the steps to the peak. It was such magnificent views of SF. Though it was a little bit cloudy, I still got a stunning view of Market street and I caught a glimpse of the top of the Golden Gate bridge. Be warned, it's very very windy up there so your hair will be flying all over the place when you take your pictures. 

Now the hike back down wasn't as bad as I thought. We just kept following the roads downhill and didn't really google anything til we got towards the bottom cuz we wanted to go to Dolores Park afterwards. The walk probably took about an hour down b/c we took our time. 

Definitely a must do for anyone that visits SF.
author: Lisa C.

description:
On my previous visits, I had gone to Twin Peaks but glad I did this visit.  It wasn't very busy with cars travelling on the road up to Twin Peaks on a weekday morning  We were part of a tour and it seemed to be a popular stop with tours as there were a number of buses parked here.

It offers great views of San Francisco and a great spot for photos, especially on a clear day.  It wasn't too busy that we couldn't find a spot for photos.  We spent about 10 minutes here and it was enough time to walk and take photos with different views.  There was a line up for the self cleaning toilet but with nothing around, nice they have one.
author: Violet P.

description:
#86/2016

Gorgeous views, family-friendly neighborhood offering plenty of parks but a dearth of restaurants. Twin Peaks has a much lower walk score than most neighborhoods in San Francisco.

But for the views alone, you can take a little extra fog, wind and a hop 'n' a skip to get somewhere: Twin Peaks has a forlorn beauty that appeals to me.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
LoveloveLOVE coming to Twin Peaks. It's just so gorgeous to gaze out onto such a beautiful city and bay - and it's beautiful at all times of the day. For years, I only came up here after dark, but I finally got my act together and started coming during the day and at sunset. OH MY. Such glory. 

I finally also got around to climbing the actual peaks (only took about 10 years...) - they're a lot easier to get to the top of than it looks from the bottom and the views are just as breathtaking!

Just be wary of how cold and windy it can get up there! It also gets super crowded pretty easily...and there are tons of pot smokers around...but aside from that, absolutely gorgeous!!
author: Charissa L.

description:
It was so goddamn cold, windy, and it was sprinkling when I was there. Rob and I had a cheat day together in San Francisco so he wanted to show me this spot. We were there for no more than 10 minutes because I was so cold. 

I'll probably hit this place up next month to see the city from atop. I am certain Gavin will enjoy it. Hopefully the weather will not be an issue this time around. 

Review unfinished*
author: Tram N.

description: So breathtaking!!  It was super windy here and we are so thankful for the option to take an Uber or Lyft up here.  You can definitely spend a few hours admiring the view of the city and watching as the sun goes down and the city lights turning on at night.  This is worth the visit, but just make sure you wear a few layers as it gets cold and windy!
author: Loretta C.

description:
My boyfriend and I took an Uber here, fully intending to hike it all the way from the bottom, but we accidentally got the address wrong and ended up pretty much at the top before we realized where we were. D'oh! We were still able to climb up the twin peaks themselves and....fog. Fog everywhere and bitterly cold winds. Oops. We decided to huddle for warmth and stick around in the hopes that the fog would clear and we'd be able to see anything, and half an hour later, we were rewarded! The views were spectacular, and if anything, they were even better half shrouded in fog. 

Long story short: check the weather conditions before coming, bundle up, and be prepared to stick around and wait it out or come back another day if the fog seems impenetrable. Getting to the top of the peaks requires climbing a bunch of steps, but it never felt steep or dangerous. I would wear sneakers or boots though, purely because of how cold it is up here, even in the middle of summer. And don't forget your camera!
author: Katie H.

description:
beautiful views of san francisco city and all the way to ocean beach.  riding a bike is a fantastic work out and your reward is chilling on top of San Francisco with "the cool breeze in your hair".  it's also safe to hike/walk up to the view point  on the side of the two way street.  

driving is the easiest way to the top but a word of caution :
if you drive, DO NOT leave anything in your car because there are thief's waiting to steal your camera and whatever you have in your car.  

enjoy the view!
author: Justin G.

description: Decided to come by here after attending a wedding in SF.  Needless to say, the view was amazing at night! It was cold and windy but looking down on the city was amazing. It's nice to live in the Bay Area and play tourist once in awhile. Just remember to lock your car doors and keep valuables out of sight, a lot of desperate people out there!
author: Dee S.

description:
A nice stop to get a good view of the city. 

There's 2 hills (erego "twin"), but one hill seems to be more popular than the other. It might be because it's closest to the larger parking lot.

The hill closest to the windy road is my favorite hill (also the less crowded hill) because you get a great view of the roads. You'll feel like you're in the mountains, although you're in the middle of SF. 

It gets chilly when you're so high up! Have your jacket. 

There's man-made steps to help you up the peaks. They're sturdy wooden-log steps. 

--PARKING-- Depending on how popular it gets, you may have trouble finding parking. There's limited street parking and 2 lots. One lot is large, and there's one small lot located in between the 2 peaks.
author: Telena V.

description:
Twin Peaks is considered to be one of the highest points in the city.
So if you want a better outlook of SF city, check this place out!
Free of charge, drive uphill and there is parking along the Lookout point.
Tons of tourists, as well as locals hiking and getting their exercise on.
It's really windy here, so bring something that will keep you warm.
There's also automatic bathrooms that wasn't really working when we tried using it.
At 935 feet elevation, it's a must visit since it offers amazing views of the bay!
author: Laramae E.

description: Love this place! I went before NYE and the crowd wasn't bad. We got parking right away and walked around a bit to take picture. Such a great location to see the beauty of this city. It wasn't foggy when we went, it was actually a perfect day, just really windy. Anyway, my favorite city is SF and this place is the place to go to take a memorable picture.
author: N D.

description:
I haven't been here since I was really young up until this past Saturday [August 15, 2015]. Once again my love took me here!! I loved it!! 

Breath taking view but it's crowded by many people so be careful, lol. 

I would love to go back to see the beautiful San Francisco at night! I love this place even more since now I experienced going here at this age. :)
author: Trina R.

description:
Its amazing the things people take for granted when living in beautiful San Francisco! Twin Peaks offers a great view of the whole Bay Area for FREE!

I have came to Twins Peak multiple times and EVERY visit is beautiful no matter what time of the day you come. For people that have never been here before the drive can be a challenge but trust me you'll be fine.

The view of the Bay Bridge and the Coit Tower is breathtaking.

You will find a lot of tourist coming here to take pictures and enjoying the lovely view. 

Parking can be tricky on a busy day. Its best to come here when the weather is nice and clear because if not you can barely see the view of the whole SF mostly because of the fog. (Bring a jacket because it can get VERY windy).

Its a beautiful view at night when the lights are all lit up and truly gives San Francisco a beautiful name!
author: Porsche C.

description:
Would you like a stunning 360 degree view of San Francisco? How about a place where you can make out with your love in your vehicle like that one scene from Titanic? If you haven't checked out this San Francisco local spot, then you're truly missing out.

Twin Peaks attracts all photographers, tourists, and locals of alike. While it feels like you're on top of the world, it's actually piping cold once you step outside of your car.

I'll never forget when Brian, my sister, best friend, and I watched the sunset throughout the SF Bay Horizon. It captured the perfect kodak moment that many Yelpers alike rave about. Although parking is free, it can be tricky to find a decent spot because of all the people it attracts. Nevertheless, you're granted with a breathtaking view of the city itself and that's something that's priceless the city has to offer.

On the other hand, it would be good idea to dress in layers and of course use the bathroom before you reach up the top for modeling sessions. Even if there are two bathrooms towards the tourist photo-taking areas, I would assume they're not the cleanest of the bunch. 

Overall, this is definitely one of the tourist traps you have to check out! It's free and you get Facebook and Instagram bragging rights for snapping a piece of this beautiful scenery.
author: Aubrey D.

description:
I had always wanted to come here but it was always more of a back burner idea. Fast forward to this weekend while my best friend and I were in SF and had nothing but time, so we decided why not?
And now, I think this may be the best chill spot in SF. Gorgeous view, plenty of street parking on the way, and a small lot up top. Its very serene being up top and seeing the whole bay around you. Take lots of pics!!
author: Kaylee H.

description:
Cities that have peaks or mountains are truly lovely. Twin Peaks reminds me with some of the peaks in Los Angeles and with Qasion mountain in Damascus. It's really nice to visit this place during a sunny day and nicer during the night if it's a clear sky.

Of course this place is a must if you're visiting San Francisco for the first time.
author: Ahmad A.

description:
First came here towards sunset, big mistake. It was just fog & rain (even tho nowhere else in the city was raining). Haha. 

Next attempt was during lunch hour and though there's still fog there's moment of clear skies, perfect for a snap shot of the ginormous city. Def worth coming here. Next time I would bring hiking attire because I saw a hiking trail here that goes higher than the cars are allowed that I would love to do. I'm sure the scenery & view is killer.
author: Grace L.

description: This place has an incredible view. Definitely worth checking out for 1st timer in the city. Parking is difficult to find.
author: Nioosha T.

description:
I went here for the first time since being a kid with two out of town friends. I told them to prepare for a tough hike bc that's what other people had told me also. I thought this was going to a few hour long thing uphill. I guess I didn't do my research, or idk, but this is quite... unimpressive in terms of a hike. 

You can either walk up from Castro Street through the residential neighborhood (this will def burn some calories, but you'll just be walking through homes) and climb your way up the peaks themselves which is like 10 feet high. The views are definitely quite pretty and you get a 360 view of the city including the water, GG bridge, Bay Bridge, Market Street, etc. 

For a lookout this, place is great. For a hike, not at all.
author: Aria S.

description:
One of the best touristy places to visit in San Francisco. We drove our car up early on Sunday morning so that we could beat the crowds and the sun. There was just a slight breeze when we went to visit. (We can in late January)

We got amazing shots of the entire city up here. It's just one of those places where you can sit and just take it all in!
author: Michelle S.

description:
A MUST for all tourists and locals alike.  Beautiful, sweeping view of the city from above.  Easily accessible.  Easy to find.  Lots of parking for a Saturday midday.  Glad the weather was clear.  Very windy, so bring a jacket.  Once you get to the top, you can park alongside the road.  Easily parked & walked up toward the restrooms (2 booths - long lines) and the telescopes.  

Gorgeous!  Use the panoramic option on the iPhone.  I could sit here all day just to take in the sights.  There are also more parking spots as you continue to the main viewing area.  Breathtaking panoramic from the GG bridge to the city skyline to the opposite end of the bay.  Continue to walk along the edge.  Everyone taking selfies, group photos.  Professional photographers lined up to take their shots.  This is definitely a spot you don't want to miss.

There's also a small hill with a long, easily accessible stairway to an even higher vantage point.  No handrails, so don't chance it if you're not stable.  It could be dangerous.  Didn't have to cling this bad boy today.  Next time for sure.
author: Angie N.

description:
The hike up here was a little arduous because of the hills, and extra scary for me because of my fear of heights. BUT, the view I got to see made it totally worth it.

First of all, it's SUPER windy and quite chilly up there, so make sure you're dressed in layers (nothing flowy), and have all your things secured. Ladies with long hair, have a scrunchy ready because your hair will be all over your face! 

As I mentioned, it's a bit of hike to the top, but once you actually get there and see the 360 views of SF, it'll all be worth it. Luckily for me, it was perfectly sunny when I went, so everything was in clear, perfect view! Don't go if it's cloudy/foggy, otherwise you'll be missing out on the stellar views!
author: Tashnuva E.

description:
Did a quick drive-by of Twin Peaks earlier this week, while visiting my husband's friends near UCSF. It's still as gorgeous as I remember it, and a great way to spend some time seeing the fabulous views of the SF Bay Area. It's been over 10 years since I've been to Twin Peaks, so it was nice to come back again and take some photos. :)

Limited parking, you may have to wait a bit for cars to leave in order to get a spot.
Tour buses come here too, so you know this place is famous!
author: Yonnie C.

description: Twin Peaks is definitely one of those place you must go to if you're new to or visiting SF and want to see a killer view of the city. If you're coming here around sunset and planning to stick around to see the city lights, I suggest bringing a blanket or extra jackets since it gets really chilly up there! But other than that, parking wasn't all that bad - people are constantly going in and out so chances are you'll find one within 5-15 mins of arriving at the peak.
author: Guinivere A.

description:
Twin Peaks is absolutely beautiful.

The overlook of San Francisco is just breathtaking. It is so relaxing and peaceful. It truly allows you to soak everything in and appreciate everything.

I definitely love coming here, it just eases you. It makes you feel like you're on top of the world and nothing matters, but to just enjoy life. :)*
author: Julie N.

description: It can be really windy although it doesn't seem that high up. We came here late up at night to see the lights of SF. Parking could be hectic to find if you come during the peak times (no pun intended). We kind of made our own parking spot in the area where you finally up into the top and walked. We dropped our jaws due to the view, snapped a few photos, and then took off due to the high wind.
author: Gary L.

description: Perfect place for views of the city.  I bike up here all the time, it's a decent little hill to climb up but it's not too bad for a semi-experienced biker.  If you're a newbie, you might find yourself walking up some of the ways.  Worth it though!
author: Giovanni M.

description:
Definitely breathtaking at night when it's clear. You get to see the whole city here! The Golden Gate Bridge, Market Street, and the Bay Bridge are all visible here.

This is the perfect place to take someone to if it's their first time in San Francisco. 

Parking here can be difficult and expect a lot of tourists to come here. Also, make sure to check the weather because when the fog rolls in, you won't see anything.
author: Aj C.

description:
You can see the view of the city here! It was very breath taking and refreshing when I first came here. It's a nice way to end the night (: 

The second time, i felt somewhat off. Probably because so many people were goofing off, blasting loud ass music, blah blah blah. I just wanted to enjoy the view without being interrupted. Maybe the first time I came here was very calm and soothing? Nonetheless, that was just a wrong time wrong day. Twin peaks still deserve five stars.
author: Tilia L.

description: Beautiful, gorgeous views! A must see in San Francisco! Take a sack lunch or some coffee. You will want to stay a while.
author: Ang M.

description:
Took a few years with a few other peaks in between but finally made it here!

Absolutely beautiful, especially on a clear day without fog. There is a panoramic view of the city, the bay and its important bridges. There is no lack of beautiful mountain trails in the bay area with fantastic view into the bay, but the city view from the twin peak is definitely something unique. An on-top-of-the-world feel. If you took the climb/run/bike there, you'll be quite proud of yourself! The houses that you pass on the way up also have quite eclectic architecture/design and interesting to look at. There are a lot of people here and one way to get unobstructed view is to stay on the lower platforms next to the roads so you are not battling for photo time with the city!

A view worthy of many clicks of the camera.
author: Sharon Z.

description:
Beautiful views from the lookout, on a clear day you can get great views of the city, 360* around. 
If you are an out of towner, don't forget to bring a jacket, as it's cold and windy up there.
author: Anjee D.

description:
Great views at night! I've never been during the day, but at night, it's nice driving up here to enjoy a view of the city: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/twin-peaks-san-francisco#Kf2xZsqQubWQ8iqahBhKdg. Seeing SF all lit up is still one of my favorite sights! It can get windy if you decide to walk around, but just bring a coat. Or a significant other to snuggle up with. Whatever works for you.

Enjoy the beauty of the city!
author: Elena N.

description:
We came here after a long day of exploring San Francisco. To be honest, I didn't have the power to go, but my husband convinced me we should check it out.

I was pleasantly surprised. We had a clear day and the view was awesome - you really see the entire city and you get a totally different view of it. It was beautiful.
We didn't spend much time, probably about 15 minutes, and I got the sense that everyone around us were doing the same - taking pictures, admiring the view, and moving on.

I would definitely recommend going if you are travelling to San Francisco.
author: Yael M.

description:
The 18th-century Spanish conquistadors referred to them as the Breasts of the Indian Maiden because of their "natural shape". Or maybe the conquistadors were just horny since they didn't have the Condor Club back then. They stay up all night in Spain after all. Come to think of it, those mammary mountains do remind me of Bette Midler's take on Sophie Tucker's joke: "I was in bed last night with my boyfriend Ernie, and he said to me 'Soph, you got no tits and a tight box'. I said to him 'Ernie, get off my back!'" Rimshot please. Twin Peaks. My 2,800th review. No, I haven't run out of restaurants to review. I just use these 100-mark milestones to celebrate something that I probably take for granted. Twin Peaks is two of those things...I mean "are" two of those things.

Leave it to Jamie W. to remind me to tool up here every once in a while to remind ourselves what a grand city San Francisco is from this vantage point. Remember when the apes stampeded down the hillside in "Rise of the Planet of the Apes"? Well, that's not the Twin Peaks I remember. The one I recall was the fake backdrop in "Flower Drum Song" when James Shigeta took Nancy Kwan out for an innocent spin in his open convertible. The view still looks like a fake backdrop, but it is real. The view down Market Street to the heart of downtown can still be gorgeous in the daytime (photo: http://bit.ly/1swAEEF) or at night (photo: http://bit.ly/1uYjd6O) if the fog doesn't roll in (though that can be magical as well).

It's crowded up there no matter when you go. Expect a line of cars and a whole lotta tourist buses waiting for the few parking spaces up there. I've always had luck with the lot as I think people forget it's there. I have yet to touch one of the aged telescopes that require two bits to peer through. Germs, y'know. Did you know each peak has a name? No, it's not Laverne and Shirley. It's Eureka to the north and Noe to the south. They're 200 meters apart, and Twin Peaks Blvd. does a figure eight around them which I have to admit has led me in the wrong direction (photo: http://bit.ly/1zJxzcV). So come see the maidens when you're in town if you can bear the traffic. And Ernie, get off my back!
author: Ed U.

description:
Twin Peaks is easily one of my favorite places ever. What's better than being on the top of San Francisco where you can overlook EVERYTHING? Here are some things to note if you plan on going up there:

- There's plenty of parking so don't worry about that!
- It's super duper windy. Make sure you layer up! 
- Just go to the area where there's a wall, don't bother climbing up the hill. The view isn't as great on the hill and going up and down is scary since the stairs are covered in dirt and aren't even proper stairs.
- There's restrooms up there but they are single stalls and the line's pretty long. 

I went during the day so I saw a clear view, but I would love to come back at night one day.
author: Chanel H.

description:
This place is amazing the best views of San Francisco from a hillside. I've been here several nights and on most nights it's pretty clear out so you are able to get some amazing shots! This is a popular tourist attraction and you come across people from all over the world, photographers taking shots for their portfolios, city people hanging out/smoking, couples taking memorable photos and the like. 

Getting up here is quite straight forward and the houses leading up to this place are over a million dollars which goes to show you this place is famous for the view. The parking here can get quite tricky. I've seen some people walk up, bike up or drive up. Most people don't park and just get out to snap and leave but if you are lucky enough, you can find a parking spot. Make sure to check the weather before you go, otherwise you might be looking into a sea of fog, which is not that exciting but still cool!
author: Anne R.

description:
Resident or tourist?

If you're a resident, it's 5 stars. If you're a tourist, it can vary based on what you're expecting.   If you're a resident, it's just an awesome occasion hangout spot or shortcut between market and haight.
author: Marcel S.

description:
I'm not really sure how anyone could not rate this 5 stars? Did they not see the view?

I will say my uber driver told me I could walk up to twin peaks. If I ever see him again...

Even hiking up you can see how beautiful the City is almost instantly. That sky is amazing plus the breeze equals the best feeling ever.

Once you make it to the top you're breath is literally taken away because it's that damn beautiful. I could have spent hours just sitting and staring at the city.

Is it a tourist trap, yes. Is it beautiful, absolutely. Would I do it again, in a heartbeat.
author: Andy V.

description: Pictures don't do this place justice! Amazing view on a clear day!!! Definitely recommend going here at least once- you won't be disappointed! Bring a picnic, bring a loved one! Enjoy!
author: Kathleen S.

description:
Beautiful view of the city practically any time.  You can see all the way from the Golden Gate Bridge to downtown and Alcatraz is pretty easy to spot top.  Scenic, good picture spot, and you can relax here for a while too.  

Parking can be tough when there's a lot of ppl(tourists and locals come here) and definitely watch out for you stuff in your car; these tourist spots are hotbeds for theft.
author: Jay B.

description: One of the best views you get in San Francisco. I didn't have this on my list of places to go, but my friend absolutely recommended it. We ended up coming here late at night and it's quite a hot spot even at midnight. It's quite windy up here so make sure to bring a sweater. The view is unbeatable on a clear day. I could see the Golden Gate Bridge to the bridge to Oakland and beyond. It's quite popular so watch out for tourists who don't pay attention or just aren't mindful of others when it comes to walking about or parking in the area. Definitely a spot to see and get great pictures of day or night.
author: Abbie C.

description: One of the most beautiful views I've ever seen. It makes you feel like you're on top of the world. There was way better parking than I was expecting. There are neat little trails you can hike up if you're into that. Definitely worth checking out if you're in the area. I have only been at night, wonder what it looks like in the day time.
author: R G.

description:
The most incredible view of all of San Francisco!!! The ultimate lookout point! 

There are 2 areas with about 8-ish parking spots each, but they are full most of the time so be prepared to battle for parking.

I went on a pretty clear day and the view was stunning. However, it was hella windy!!! I'm not sure if it's always that windy, but definitely bring a jacket and maybe tie up long hair so it doesn't get all tangled up like mine did haha.
author: Joanne Y.

description: A must do when it's a clear day out in San Francisco. Incredible view of the city during the day and at night.
author: Karen M.

description: I'm not sure if I hiked the right way, but the view was amazing. I think I hiked up the opposite side of the hill but it was still fun. It's a great way to see the whole city.
author: Kit B.

description: Very nice view to watch the sunset or sunrise! Gets chilly at the top of the hill and sometimes windy but over all the view is worth it!
author: Paulina C.

description:
I always come back here when visiting! I moved to Kansas but every time I come visit I have to come and take pictures !! JUST COME ON A CLEAR SUNNY DAY so fog isn't in your photos and the view is visible ! 
There are also small trails To go even higher !!
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
This is the free version of the Coit Tower minus the actual tower. 

Breathtaking views and I saw Fred the Bulldog here. He was in high spirits so it was a welcome treat. 

Parking can be a problem at times and don't get me started on the wind. There is a lot of wind here that could knock your grandma off her feet and sweep her all the way to Oakland. 

Still, it might be worth it just for the views because it is amaznig. During the morning, day, or night, they all present a unique experience that is worth the trek up to this location. 

Without a doubt, a worthy of the high praise it recieves.
author: Benny H.

description: This is a perfect place for those who look for a whole view of San Francisco. Day and night visits have their own beauty. At day, you can see everything clearly. At night, the city lights up and it would be a gorgeous scenery. Even though I live in San Jose, I always come here at midnight to help myself relax. Don't forget to bring a jacket with you if you want to come here. Don't suggest going there alone especially at midnight. You know
author: Justin F.

description:
Oh Twin Peaks. It's one of those places that you have to visit at least once. I mean, where else are you going to get an overview of the city? Think panorama. On our most recent visit to San Francisco, my sister insisted we go to Twin Peaks for my parents and it did not disappoint. There are a couple of ways to get here but for the sake of time, we just drove up here and walked the last hill up to the top which is the highest peak. I heard you can hike here from the twin peaks highway though if you're into that. By the way, it was absolutely freezing so make sure you come bundled up especially if you're coming at night.

You're probably not going to get a better view of the entire city and for free. Parking isn't too bad neither since most people don't stay up there for more than a few pictures worth because of the weather. It may be a place where tourists go but I've been to the city many times and still can't get enough of this beautiful city. Twin Peaks made me appreciate it more for sure. Be careful of all the cars and driving because it is a very curvy road up and back down. 4/5
author: Michelle L.

description: Twin peak noo not the TV show from the 90's . This is actually a place in SF . Most beautiful view of San Francisco !! You can see the entire city from here!!! .. Stunning 360 views of the SF city. Night time views are spectacles !! There are coin-operated telescopes available around the twin peak .. It's really steep and high just shy of 1000 feet above sea level. There are free parkings around the area ., This place is almost always extremely windy so bring a jacket...or two, and a scarf! If you need to go to the bathroom, theres one public bathroom and its the type that cleans itself...yeah, you have to check it out! Its great! Check this place out -:)
author: Nadia R.

description:
Twin Peaks offers a breathtaking view.  It is especially magical at night when the lights are all lit up.  This place comes alive!!  If you look straight ahead, you will see bright lights, and if you follow those lights, you will see Market St.  On a clear night, you will see the San Francisco Bay Bridge and the view of the whole city.

Driving up here can be a challenge.  But, if a 44 ft diesel pusher can make it up here, cary a load of tourist, so can you! LOL You just have to know how to downshift.  

If you come during the day, avoid high noon from 12-2PM as you will get too much sunlight or too much glare.  I think sundown or sunrise is the best time for photo shoots!

When I used to ride my bike, I would take my 250cc Yamaha up here during sunrise before school started. It helped clear my mind and planned my day.  Whatever Twin Peaks is for you, this place is magical and has something for everybody.  

Until then, Cheers! ~ :p
author: Edwin R.

description: I don't know how you can give this place anything less than 5 stars. Always a must when friends are in town. I like to drive my friends here and insist that they close their eyes until we reach the very top. Their reaction is priceless.
author: Grace V.

description:
Best views of San Francisco and the bay area.

Came here during a beautiful sunny day so we were able to see everything!

Must-see place for anyone visiting San Francisco. I will definitely come here every chance I get to go to SF!
author: Long N.

description:
One of my favorite spots in the city...but I'm not the only one as you can tell from other Yelpers. I take all my tourist friends here and all of them leave amazed...unless the fog rolls in and you can't see anything. I actually prefer the view with the fog and the rain...it makes SF..SF! Also, when its raining the crowd is actually smaller. Only crazy people like me go up there when its raining. But its super super pretty when you watch the city getting rained on. It makes me calm.  

Ok enough with the fog and rain. On a clear day you can see the entire city and across the bay. The view is amazing. You can also climb up a small trail up the other hill for another view. Not a lot of people know this but there is a small trail to the right of the entrance where people usually park. Parking can be a hassle on a busy day but I've always found parking.
author: Tommy L.

description:
It's worth the hike up if you can handle the hills and pack lots of water! We followed the directions from 
http://www.choisser.com/hiking/twinpeaks.html
and ended up with some great views, easy directions. The best part of our trip to San Francisco!
author: Margaret M.

description: Grandma takes her grandson to Twin Peaks when he visits San Francisco, California. The feeling is as majestic as when you sit on top of the world in San Francisco. Twin Peaks is a memory to save for a lifetime after a single view. No other view offers a visitor more of San Francisco than Twin Peaks, which is why our family takes all our visitors from out to town to the top of the peaks.
author: Thomas Chase Leo S.

description:
the views from atop the peaks are breathtaking.
it is by far one of the best places to view the city line.
author: Ella A.

description:
One of the best views to get of the city. 
On a clear day you can see the golden gate, bay bridge, Marin and Oakland. It does get a little busy on the weekends with the tour busses but parking never seems to be an issue.
author: Vika N.

description:
We got really high on 420. 

How high?

Well, higher than just about everyone else in San Francisco (even the stoners at Haight Ashbury) because we were up on Twin Peaks! Yes, on Easter Sunday, 4/20.

Now, many will say Twin Peaks is just a quick stop for some pics and then you can be off on your way.  The views are obviously astonishing and all you need to do is click "see all" photos to easily understand why people are attracted to Twin Peaks.

But for me, I was there almost an hour, and only spent about 5 mins or so of that time taking pics.

Personally, it was about the feeling I had while up here.  Although many tourists were around, there's a way to enjoy your time up here while blocking all that out.

So, take your pics, selfies, groupies, etc. then put your phone or camera away. Hit the "off" button (trust me, it exists).  Sit back, relax, reflect, and enjoy where you are.  Look down, look around, take it all in.

If you're not only into peace and tranquility, then get to the highest point! I was especially thrilled to walk up some steps to get "higher" that most. Very few actually go up these steps to get to the peak, as most stay in the common areas. As I was ready to revel in the moment, I took my phone out first to snap a few pics. YES! I couldn't resist.
author: Brandon C.

description: What a view of the city, pretty windy and foggy when we went but still got some good glimpses of the city.....great place for pictures and just a nice little stroll up to the top off the side roads
author: N And N K.

description:
Love, love panoramic views of cities. Friend took me here in early August, we went late at night and sadly there was pretty much zero visibility. Not sure I could have even made it up there if I had been driving (bad eyes at night)! There were still some people there when we went, even though we couldn't see anything besides fog and darkness.

I decided to come back the next day on my own, it was slightly overcast but very decently visible. Great view! I can see why it is such a popular scenic viewpoint, and I do recommend checking it out. Got a bit windy up there and at one point parking looked full.
author: Pamela S.

description:
A perfect romantic getaway from SF! This is a popular spot to check out on a nice clear night. It has the best view of the entire SF bay! The drive up is easy and takes about 10-15 mins to get up. There is a parking lot at the top from the view point. But if it gets busy, you will need to park at the side of the mountain.  he destination is a good spot for 30 mins. It does get crowded but the view is spectacular and one of my fav spot to SF!! 


Tip 1:  Make sure to bring a jacket. It gets pretty cold and windy even on during the summer.  It's freezing in the winter time.

Tip 2: If you have a nice camera, make sure to bring it. You will be able to take some nice shots while you are up there.
author: Julie L.

description:
ATTENTION: do not leave your car out of your sight for more than 30 seconds. If you do, make sure you take all important belongings or lock them in a trunk where they are unseen. There are a ton of reported burglaries. Please watch the news link attached below. Yesterday, (7/7/15), my friends and I got our car windows smashed into and all of our valuables were stolen, so add on another one to that. 

Otherwise, twin peaks gets a 5 because of the beautiful view. 

http://abc7news.com/travel/sf-tourist-attraction-is-hot-spot-for-thieves/337039/
author: Athena B.

description:
Down Right AMAZING View.  "But, Cap.  Why only three stars?"
This is like the French Laundry of views for San Francisco.  It is amazing if you can get in.

Twin Peaks is amazing, no doubt.  But more times than not it is covered in a thick cloud layer.  Even when at a slightly lower altitude is clear, Twin Peaks will be obscured.

There is a lot of parking.  Still, on busy days it can get full.
author: Cap P.

description:
One of San Francisco's greatest attractions. Get amazing 360 degree views of the city while atop this double peak. 

Relatively easy to get to, plenty of free parking, and a nice little climb up a path to either one of the two peaks.

A must see for all visitors.
author: Kevin F.

description:
Don't get me wrong, as a Californian native, I do love this place. You get some of the best views of the city from up here, and you really can see just about everything. If you have a car, it's super easy to get here. If you don't ... I'm not really sure what to advise. Guess you could uber here? There's always a ton of people here regardless of the weather, but despite that, you'll still be able to find parking because people tend to go in and out pretty common.

BUT. Why not a five star rating if it definitely gives a five star view of SF? Because of the weather. The weather is literally such a hit or miss with this place. Maybe I'm just really unlucky or suck at choosing good days, but the last three times that I've been here have all been terrible. It's either super foggy, or super sunny and not cloudy and perfect but then really really windy, or something else. When the weather gods strike, the magic of this place is definitely not so great. While Twin Peaks gives great aerial views, many of the smaller hills in SF give you equally beautiful views. Sure Twin Peaks is at a higher vantage point, but it's more or less the same view from a different altitude. On a bad day you could enjoy it from your car I guess... but the fun is just sitting there and looking at the beautiful city by the bay.

tldr; solid five-star view but weather is always a mess. just be aware of weather conditions because if it's foggy/windy, you won't have that much fun
author: Jasmine X.

description:
Everytime I go to San Fransisco, I will find an excuse to come up here!

I usually drive up the Northern side pacing up the hairpin turns to where I eventual;ly reach the summit. At the peak, you are able to see the famous Sutro Tower nearby. You are also able to see San Fransisco, and in the distance to the Northwest, the Golden Gate Bridge. All of this is visible if you are on a rare clear day. Also, the winds do pick up, violently sometimes where I would definatly recommend to bring a jacket!

Overall; It is a wonderful place to view such an iconic city. The drive up isn't difficult at all. The parking can sometimes be an issue. Bring a camera too!
author: Bruce's A.

description:
I can't believe it took me so long to find out about this view point!  Amazing to see the city from this view - you can see Market street pretty much cut down the middle of downtown.  

Upside:
- 360 degree view of SF (downtown, golden gate, etc)
- Lots of parking available 

Tip:
If you're on this side of the city, stop by Lands End to watch the sunset.
author: Sophie L.

description:
Went up to Twin Peaks the other night right around sundown and it was super challenging getting up to the top while needing to stop at stoplights at an angle in a stick shift car! ...after burning the clutch a few too many times, I finally ended up the top with the smell of clutch throughout the cabin.

The view was breathtaking...it was super windy and cold though!

...there is no admission charge either!

...tip: Bring an automatic vehicle or a stick shift w/ auto-hold
author: Derek S.

description: Oh wow! What a beautiful view. This is consider the highest point in San Francisco, so you can imagine the views.   This is a must go place if you are in San Francisco. I think everyone deserves to see this beautiful view.
author: Asenath N.

description:
I'm in love with skylines and heights so this place is the perfect place for such a beautiful view of SF. 

I came here in Janurary two years ago for the sunset and a little bit of the night. It is really cold up there and I would recommend a blanket if you plan on staying for a bit. Parking would just be along the streets and even the drive up is lovely.

You can see the golden gate, alcatraz, and a lot of other notable SF landmarks.

Do check the weather though because I tried coming here again in April of 2015 and it was too foggy to even navigate the roads. It is possible to hike up here too but I would recommend a drive if you are just visiting SF.
author: Jessica Q.

description:
Twins Peak is always a must when we come visit SF! Though it's SUPER windy and cold, it's a great escape from the valley heat!

This recent visit was SUPER packed for some reason. We had to park outside of the viewing on the road. It was weird. I've never seen this many people here before. I usually just stay on the main viewing point because...well, if it's SUPER windy down there, climbing to the peak would be even windier. I've only gone up there once and it was bad! Sun was out, but all you feel is cold, cold gusts of wind! You can barely hear yourself think, it was that strong!

If you don't mind the wind, and a small hike up, go for it. You get a much better view of the city from there. Not a lot of space, so if everyone decides to go up there at the same time, you will be squished. I'd stay stay on the main floor. Roomier and less windy.

Fog rolls through pretty fast on most days, so if you want a photo-op of the city, do it fast, or you'll miss it. I've gone here both day and night, and I like the night view better just because you can see the city lights shining everywhere. Its's much prettier. It's much colder and windier at night as well, so, again, bring a jacket.

If you're visiting the city, I highly recommend coming to Twin Peaks to get the whole view of the city! It's gorgeous! Parking might suck, but the wait for a spot isn't too long. Park on the road or wait for a parking spot in the little lot.
author: Kristen B.

description: A must do when you are in San Francisco. One of the best views of downtown SF during both daytime and evening. You can get there via car from either the clarendon side or the portola side. After driving up you will eventually run into the turn off into the view point with parking. It can be hit or miss as the weather varies so much. In the evening I would definitely bring a jacket or blanket!
author: Ryan J.

description:
Definitely come here at night and just take in the cool breeze and gorgeous view! It's super cold up here at this time of the year, but once you see the view, it's absolutely breathtaking and priceless. =)

1. Free parking! YEAH!
2. There's a windy pathway up to the top and there's barely any lights, so drive slowly and use your head beams.
3. Bathroom is available.
author: Eva L.

description:
I don't know what it is but every time I'm there I see a broken car window.  People, do not leave valuables visible in your car. Nowhere in San Francisco.

Imagine coming back from a 360 degree experience of overlooking this beautiful city on a clear day - you won't get any better views - and you see what some idiot schmuck has done to your car. Not worth it.

However, visiting this unique and beautiful spot will be worth of your time.

Be safe, people.
author: Sebastian F.

description:
Nice view of the city.

Twin Peaks is a nice place to go to get a great view of the city. We went up to the top of one of the hills and took photos from there. Make sure you wear a wind breaker because it is extremely windy. The view is great but there isn't much else to do and the view gets tiresome after a few minutes. It's probably a place you stay for 10 minutes or less to soak in the view but not much else. There are some tourists from bus tours that stop by and there are 2 glorified and luxurious looking portable potties for your convenience.

I wouldn't rate this a must-see in the city but if you have time, it's a decent place to stop by.
author: Tim L.

description: Twin Peaks is definitely the premier sports bar in Sacramento.  The most HD TVS in one place.   84 large screen tvs, with tvs outdoors & also in the individual booths.  Beer is frosty to the degrees measured on their digital sign diaplayed in the front. Besides having the most tvs in one location, they also the most beautiful women serving you food & drinks.  The staff is helpful, pleasant,  & always a pleasure to interact with. One of my favorite servers is Christine, she does a great job of always taking care of my friends & I when were here.  Even when she's not helping us she insures us that we will be taken care of.  The quality of food is decent, its bar food which helps absorb all those super cold beers!      To be honest when your here its not about the food.  Its about Cold beers with your buds, sports, & beautiful women to gaze at.
author: M J.

description:
It's Twin Peaks... must visit if you're in San Francisco and want an amazing view of the city... you definitely need a jacket, blanket, someone warm... 

You do not want to climb up the steps to the very top... super windy... I thought I was going to be blown away. I almost peed myself... lol I saw some guy later jogging up there too like it's just a regular thing... like what the hell...

There were some stupid BMWs drifting on these road... dangerous for other people too... you're not Fast & The Furious.
author: Kiyo M.

description: Another MUST spot for anyone who's coming to SF. The view is gorgeous with tons of space to take pictures. I've been here many times either it's daylight or night time. This is a popular tourist attraction and you come across people from all over the world. I met a couple who is from Australia.
author: Danny L.

description: The most gorgeous view of the city. Twin peaks is the highest point in SF, so you can literally see everything. Definitely recommend to anyone who is visiting, or if you have never been up to the top, YOU MUST! beautiful views of the whole city
author: Ross S.

description: Twin Peaks is/are the highest point in the city! Gorgeous winding road up. Has bikers around and a giant parking lot on top to take pictures, where you can see all of SF.
author: Nora L.

description:
This view though.
Been here a handful of times, all at night & the view is ABSOLUTELY freakin' AMAZING! The city lights are gorgeous. Takes your breath away.

The drive up here isn't too bad. GPS takes you right to it.
Parking isn't too bad but we always luck out with VIP (up front) parking.

They have a place where people can sit & gaze.
They have telescopes there too.

I could stay there all night, such a pretty spot to just admire the city lights.
I will definitely be back!

Oh! Dress warm or bring a blanket! It gets really windy up there!
author: Camille C.

description: Twin peaks is beautiful!! Best view of the city but bring your warm gear cause boy oh boy do you catch the wind chill at the peak. Beautiful view of the Bay Bridge and the Golden gate bride. I thought it was a small trail walk and it was just a drive to the top. Nice drive not walk remember. And bring your camera
author: Joseph G.

description:
I love the view from up here. Absolutely gorgeous. One of my first visits to somewhere in San Francisco during one of my initial visits to the bay area. I loved it. The wind is whipping though and be prepared for the tourists at the top. They are usually stingy with the telescope and I never got a chance to look through it, but that's okay. I live here and can go anytime. 

But I am telling you, the drive up is beautiful, the windy road down is a lot of fun, but mostly the view is so cool of the bay from the top. Check it out.
author: Tanya C.

description:
I can't believe I was born and raised in the Bay Area and waited until my 56th birthday to come here!  There is quite a bit of parking as we went in the middle of the week during mid day.  I will return again for the sunset hour and night shots of the skyline.  The views are breath taking!  You can see our photo's and video from our day here: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CbYDgJWPIUg
author: Grace N.

description:
First successful sunset I have ever been able to witness with my own eyes! 
Beautiful view as you drive up the curvy roads leading up towards twin peaks.
Windy, coLd, and packed with cars and people so come prepared. 

It's a journey up the steep hill, at least for me it was. LoL. Be extra cautious because the wooden steps are small and narrow. Rocky & unstable conditions make it difficult to maneuver around people going the opposite direction that you are going in.  

Believe me, it's will be worth your time and effort! Next time, I'll try to come later in the evening to take in the full effects of the city lights .
author: Ter L.

description:
Not really sure how to rate a natural landmark, but the one time that I've been up here was extraordinary (trust me, take a look at my photo). Lucky for me, I happened to be visiting SF on the one day that the sky was completely clear!

Normally, when I decide to go hiking or make an effort to watch the sunset or sunrise, I would have to work for it. Here's some good news for those of you who'd rather stay away from physical activity; you can drive to the top of twin peaks! Not gonna lie, I would rather drive to the top than hike it since it was freezing that night (mind you that I went in early September). 

Whoever designed it thought things through - Twin peaks offers a large area solely for parking and sight seeing. You get this amazing view of SF and if you're lucky, you can even see the new bay bridge. 

I don't really know what else I can say, but hey, if you're in SF and you're trying to pass the time, you should definitely come here to get away from the city and enjoy the nice view. Next time, I'll be sure to check out Twin Peaks when the sun is still up!
author: Wiseley F.

description:
Twin Peaks is probably the best known place to get a gorgeous 180 view of the city from most of Downtown all the way to the lights of Candlestick Park, so long as it still exists. The one caviat? It's windy as hell up here. Bundle up.

The pros:
1. Parking! People are constantly moving in and out, so just wait a moment.
2. The view.

The cons:
1. Little lighting on the curvy road up...sometimes you'll get the idiots that walk around at night without a light...so drive slow.
2. The view...many people come when there are fireworks....you'll be so far that you'll barely be able to see the show and hear the sounds...and you'll most likely freeze your butt off doing so. 

If you're looking for a romantic place, I guess this could be an option. But I can assure you that there are many more vista points around the city if you know where to look. That said, I'm usually up here getting my night shots.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Easy to get to by car, but just drive a bit slower when you're going up and down the mountain at night because there's not really a lot of light to show you the way so you're gonna have to depend on your car's headlights.

The view from up here is amazing especially on a clear night when you can just see the city and the stars. There's also tons of parking up here, but it could get crowded on a Friday or Saturday night so just be aware. Best part? I mean, aside from the view and what not... there's a bathroom up here. Yeupp. You read that right. A bathroom. It'll be right where you enter the top of the mountain where all the parking is. 

Not much to say about this place. It's just somewhere you have to go at least once to enjoy the city. :)
author: Venus L.

description: Breathe taking view of the San Francisco skyline, this spot is Perfect. Can get foggy in the mornings or cloudy days, If you go here during the day choose a bright and sunny day so you can get a lot of photos in. There are curvy roads on the drive up but it is worth it. It is also a beautiful spot at night with all the lights from the city below. twin Peaks has an incredible view of San Francisco, not much to do here but gaze at the city and take photos.
author: Tina M.

description:
As the name implies, they are twin peaks. The two hills are approximately 925 feet high in the middle of the city and south of the Mission District. There is plenty of parking so definitely drive up there. You can walk to the top of either peak. They are exactly the same. Since you are on the top of a big hill, bring a coat because it could get windy and cold up there. The Peaks provide a spectacular, breathtaking view of the city.

If you are visiting San Francisco and looking for recommendations, feel free to message me through Yelp and I can share my itinerary, which includes my Yelp reviews. The information for an electronic copy can also be found via my Yelp profile.
author: Patrick W.

description:
Fantastic view of the city, on a clear day you can see forever. Yesterday was a good day to show off the city, it was sunny and clear but at Twin Peaks it is cold and windy. It was 50 degrees out yesterday afternoon.  The parking lot was full but cars moved in and out quickly. Even a tour bus came out here. There are two public toilets which is a good thing. Seemed that everyone up here was having a good time with the view. Lots of tourists!
Highly recommended for the view!
author: Dirk D.

description: Twin peaks is a must when you're in SF visiting. At the end of your day come up to this lookout where you can see the entire city of SF from the very top. Breathtaking. Be warned it gets quite crowded.
author: Tuyen H.

description:
I've lived in the bay area my whole life... But this past month was only my first two times here -_-

THIS IS A MUST SEE PLACE!!! It's soooo damn beautiful. Daytime, sunset, nighttime, it's all amazing.

I didn't have trouble finding parking. Make sure you dress warm though because it gets really cold and windy.

Tip: For a cool picture, stand behind the stone edge, and make it look as if you are holding on for dear life!
author: Lincy H.

description:
I've heard people saying how serious the hike is to get to the top as well as people talking about how there's nothing to hike at all.

Well if you only consider going on top of the peaks themselves 'the hike', then yeah it's just a couple of stairs. But if you would rather take the summit from the very beginning - the bottom of the resort where the trail officially starts, then the hike can be challenging for some people. 

I would recommend the summit, though. As you are walking, definitely mind your steps, but do remember to stop once in a while to enjoy the scene. It gets better as you are higher up. When you get to the viewing deck, you will see the crowd taking photos. Then you can see very clearly the two peaks, follow the stairs to get to the top of them if you will.

A lot of people may be driving, but walking to twin peaks can be fun as well. I walked from the mission, just google map the route. The walk is safe and peaceful, you can also have a feel for the residential area in Castro. 

I saw girls wearing short skirts there. If you are not familiar with the windy weather in SF, or the concept of 'it's usually more windy as it gets higher up', here's a tip - don't wear a skirt unless you want the entire San Francisco to see your underwear. Litterally,  it's the highest point in the city!
author: Wanqi C.

description: A great place to get a view of San Francisco. Parking is limited. It can get crowded with tour buses and hoards of tourists. Of course you should really bring your camera, a good one. It's very nice here at dusk when the lights begin to take effect in the city.
author: Eddie C.

description:
Gorge.

First recent time here was during a day trip with the girls, Hi-Speeds in hand (if you don't know, you should go find out). Breathtaking views, amazing weather, and good company = good times.

During the evenings, the twinkling lights are breathtaking for sure (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/twin-peaks-san-francisco?select=LUcRN9emTBnOlZ6ytHnXbQ#6lF0aPHtaFk_7c4MVemLtQ) but it does get kind of nippy. It is SF, after all. I literally got out of the car, took a photo, and hopped back in, it was THAT frigid! I'm thinking blankets and wine might help out the situation, but I'll have to save that experiment for another visit.

*Starts planning*
author: Vi T.

description:
I was freezing here during a windy early evening to get a super wide panoramic shot of the bay area - it was definitely worth it. You can see almost the entire peninsula from this very large hill. If you have a bit of time to kill as a visitor to San Francisco, this is a must since it's not too far from the urban center of San Francisco. 

Needless to say, if you've seen any other pictures of the amazing view Twin Peaks provides, you don't need my enthusiastic endorsement to convince you!
author: Albert L.

description:
The views are just breathtaking.  Truly.  Simply stunning.

My friend and I purposely drove up to twin peaks to watch the sunset.  The weather was beautiful, the sun was shining, the sky was clear and pristine, BUT it was COLD!

Quite cold actually.  

I lasted as long as I could up on the hill overlooking the city of San Francisco and surrounding areas.  But alas, the cold won this battle and I had to head back down to the car with only a mere 20 minutes left till sunset.  

Sadness.

I shall strive not to let the cold get the best of me on the next visit.  

Bottom Line:  It's definitely worth the drive, time, and effort to travel up to twin peaks.  hmm...perhaps a visit at night on the next trip.  hopefully.
author: Michael C.

description:
117. Twin Peaks is something you have to do if you visit SF.  How can you say no to seeing this (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=lwPYiLt64r8bbdfyzcZdAQ&userid=qEdxnnadZ2tcU9JOXjnGdw)?! 

It might be a bit confusing if you're coming from the Mission.  The bus will drop you off somewhere before the serious incline begins, so you sort of have to figure it out on your own.  But it's not that hard.  You will see apartments here and there.  Just find stairs that go UP.  Keep going and going and you will get there.  If you reach a dead end, go back down the stairway, and find another and keep on going!

Once you get past all the buildings, you'll see some grassy hills, which means you're almost there!  You'll get to see breathtaking views on a good day.  It can get windy up there, so bring a jacket.  If you forget to bring water, it's not a big deal.  This is an easy hike, so no excuses!  I saw an infant being carried by his dad here.  If an infant can survive Twin Peaks, so can you.
author: Katherine C.

description: What a view!!! Nice quick stop that allows you to see most of San Fran! there are bathrooms there too (didn't use them so can't comment on how clean they are)... Definitely a place to check out if in the san fran area!
author: Dana M.

description:
My sister came across this vantage point while searching through Yelp. It does give you the most amazing view of San Francisco during the day. The drive up to Twin Peaks isn't the easiest, but there are parking spaces at different locations of Twin Peaks. 

There will probably always be a lot of tourists taking pictures up here, but because there's different photo op spots, it won't be too hard trying to get that perfect picture of San Fran. There's a normal bridge area that overlooks SF, with artists selling paintings, telescopes, and bathrooms. If you drive up further, there are the two peaks that have stairs that give you access to climb to the top to get an even better and different view of San Francisco. 

I think it's worth it to come to Twin Peaks at least once, especially if you're a big photo person. Sometimes the city gets cloudy and gloomy, and may not give you the best backdrop for a photo. But if you're lucky, you can capture that gorgeous blue sky and all the buildings and houses that make up San Francisco.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I recently just got a dslr and I wanted to practice taking landscape shots. I had been here before just to see the entire view of SF but never with a camera, so I was hoping to capture the beauty. Parking is limited at the top of the mountain but people come and go so hopefully you snag a spot. I came here last weekend an hour or so before sunset so around 6-7:30pm. My friends and I just took shots of the beautiful view and waited til closer to 8 to take the money shots since the sun was still pretty high in the sky. If you go down to the dirt area in front of the rock wall, you can take some really pretty shots with the sun peering through. It is like America's Next Top Model down there so I would check it out. 

I went a second time and I guess you can actually hike up the peak so you can view the other peak. There are stairs leading to the top and I was wearing flats so it was slightly uncomfortable but still doable. It took me less than five minutes to get to the top and since it is an incline, you may be a bit tired. Good thing the wind is blasting in your face at the very top. I think the view is wayyy better at night. I went during the day the second time and the view was alright but the best time is before, during and after sunset. 

It is pretty freezing up there since it is SF and when you add the wind, it makes the photography adventure quite intolerable. But you have to suck it up to get a pretty shot! You have to stay until sunset to get the best shots. If you want night shots, you will have to stay up there in the cold for another hour or two. 

**TIPS**
1) For photographers, come an hour before sunset for a great shot.
2) Dress warmly! It gets super cold!!
3) Enjoy!
author: Amy H.

description: Wow! The views from here are AH-MAZE-BALLS!! Twin Peaks is THE BEST place to see the city. If you want to see a picturesque, panoramic view of the city come here. It's absolutely breathtaking! There a few parking lots up top and a hike to the tippy top. Not a place to hang out to long because it gets nippy up there.
author: Angela R.

description:
Spectacular view of the City!  It was a nice day when my friend and I came to Twin Peaks on 12/13/14.  I've been here many times in the past, but it was my friend's first visit.

My plan for my birthday was to drive to the Bay Area, and have a leisurely day with random things to do.  This was a perfect spot to hang out for a while and enjoy the beautiful view of the City.  The view at night is also amazing, but we'll have to make another trip one day for my friend to see it.
author: Leonard A.

description:
I wanted to let out of town visitors know the San Francisco Municipal Transit Agency is going to implement a test project on Twin Peaks which will limit personal vehicles to only one side of the hill (away from the view) so the good side (with the view) can be used for hikers and bikers.  This is due to some bad accidents up there which injured pedestrians and is an attempt to address problems of those who want to hike or bike up there.

This will probably result in traffic backing up there when it is implemented in the very near future.
author: Dalt W.

description:
Have been in the Bay Area for almost 3 years and I had heard of this destination.  I am soon glad I went - but wished I could have gone about an hour earlier!

Got to the vista about 8:30pm and the night was amazing.  The city was crystal clear and there were lots of tourists!

I brought my camera gear and was able to get some amazing shots!!   Follow me on Instagram kchassiephoto_landscapes or email me at kchassiephoto@outlook.com for high quality prints!!
author: Kathy C.

description: Do not go on a foggy day... Otherwise this is the spot every tourist or a local must go to experience the view and feel San Francisco for its beauty.
author: Victor D.

description: Twin Peaks delivers on iconic views of SF. Couple that with a beautiful windy road, and you've got a great experience for both residents and tourists. The weather can be dramatically different up here, so just be warned. We came on a day that had some spots of sun and warmth downtown, but the top of Twin Peaks was a frigid cold and foggy. Bring some extra layers!
author: Nic Z.

description:
If you want an absolutely FANTASTIC view of San Francisco, This is 1 of 2 places that immediately come to mind - the other being the N end of the Golden Gate Bridge.

To locate this park, look for that absolutely HUGE tripod antenna - you can see it from miles away.

If you want a good shot of downtown San Fran, be sure to bring a telephoto lens.  One cool thing about this location is that it's almost directly in line with Market Street.  It's like staring down the Champs-Elysses in Paris, minus the Arc at the end.

I would suggest coming here earlier in the day, as the nearby mountains cast a shadow around sunset, which darkens half your landscape.
author: Edward L.

description: Great place for sunset lover. You can enjoy watching the city at night.
author: Team M S.

description: I have been here a few times and it's so nice. It's a Great place too go if you're visiting SF. The city looks so pretty at night.
author: Lsxo S.

description: Beautiful view. No, it's actually AMAZING. The wind was incredibly strong though so hold onto your camera/phone, and your children pets before they fly away haha.
author: Natasha K.

description:
One of my favorite spots in the city! You can see about 75% of San Francisco at just one glance. I advise to come during the day and during the night to see SF in all its glory.

It can get super windy so make sure to have extra layers with you!
author: Angela L.

description: Amazing views that just made me fall in love with sf. If I lived here I would love to live near here.
author: Tamara C.

description: Worth every minute. The best view of the city you could possibly get and for free. The drive is really easy and the views are amazing. I think this will be a go to spot any time we visit the city. Can get crowded on weekends, but that does not have any impact on the experience. You can see all of the amazing sites of the bay (golden gate, bay bridge, sky scrapers, Alcatraz, etc.). Go go go go!
author: Josh D.

description: Absolutely stunning view. Bring a warm jacket and a hot cup of tea or coffee because it gets very windy here! The sunset view from here is breathtaking and will leave you speechless. Perfect for pictures and panoramic shots. Amazing.
author: Alla S.

description: Views not to be missed! Not just the San Fran side but the view of the sun hitting the pacific ocean is just suburb as well. Even the drive up and down is fun :) Pack a jacket..or 3. It's really cold. And if you actually climb one of the peaks, don't take your little kid up there! I could barely maintain stability due to the extremely strong winds..i don't wanna see no kids up there start flyin!
author: Shayer S.

description:
I'm feeling a little bit shocked by the fact that I have yet to come here and I've been living in the bay area for over a decade.

I guess I always knew about it, heard about it, maybe or maybe not seen some photos ... but in the end I've never been here!

I finally had a chance to come here on an absolutely gorgeous SF day in October. And yes, I said October, it was 78 degrees! There were no clouds, no fog and the experience couldn't be more perfect.

The drive here is a little windy, but totally worth the hike up. Once you get up there's a pretty decent sized parking lot, but you will find tourists here of course. I think it must be amazing to come during sunrise or sunset ... or even at night like some of the photos here depict. I came during mid-day. Regardless, the view was still breathtaking. 

This is such a highly recommended, SUPER free, activity. It's a must!
author: Lorrie M.

description: Great view but it can get pretty windy and cold. Photographer should use heavy tripods because the wind can easily blow
author: Joe T.

description: Love this San Francisco Spot, the view is beautiful, even in foggy days looks so nice, romantic and windy.
author: Jessica D.

description:
360 view in the City. It is essential when visiting San Francisco, because there aren't that many places from which you are able to see the entire city. Few suggestions:
- Come early to enjoy a light that is better and get finer image. Also can get hot.
- Blustery. If you intend to stay more than 15 minutes out in winter, bring a jacket.
- Check the weather before going up! You will not see anything otherwise.
- Try to find: AT&T Park, Golden Gate Bridge (simple), Coit Tower, Alcatraz Island, US Mint Building, Civic Center, The Castro flag.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Great views of the city! We walked from Alamo Square because we don't have a car while we're here. The walk wasn't bad and you get to enjoy the views along the way. The highest peak is super windy and cold. Defiantly a must see while visiting!
author: Michelle S.

description: So happy I visited Twin Peaks for the first time during a very sunny day with the most pleasant company and not even cold weather. Visibility was awesome and I didn't want to go although the parking situation (people waiting for others to leave and also get a piece of joy with this view of San Francisco) was not ideal. The very modern restrooms are a little bit tricky: a woman could not properly operate the door because did not follow the instructions of wait a little for the restroom to be self cleaned and then enter, so she got almost caught in action. Well, at least there are restrooms and everything is perfect in this point, where I also had the opportunity to meet some tourists from Venezuela and chitchat in Spanish. I don't think of other place where you can get this view of San Francisco.
author: Carmen V.

description: There's little I can say that hasn't been said already. However, GO HERE! The views of the city are expansive and beautiful. We always seem to find parking fairly easily, too. And yes, bring layers - it's windy here!
author: Amber L.

description: My car window got broken and nobody seen or heard anything around noon. Twin Peaks became a high crime area where people get robbed on daily basis. What is SF police doing about it? I think its time to change a leadership. Most of the crimes go unsolved and nobody cares until something happens directly to them.
author: Michael H.

description:
It is a great place to hangout. 
You could see the whole bay area if not Foggy. 
I enjoy the Fog too. 
Feels like Nagarkot in Kathmandu.
author: Dylan R.

description: Gorgeous views on the top of SF, lots crowds during sunset times. Plan ahead of time and take the nice spot if arrived early.
author: Maruko X.

description: A beautiful place to spend with a loved one - and likely you wont have cell phone distractions.... at least mine doesn't work here. Clear views from afar... perfect place for a romantic evening. Parking can be tough on Valentines day as one could imagine. There are probably other less known corners of the city that are just as enjoyable and not as well known. A nice view is easy to come by in the city given a hill everywhere you look.
author: Stefan T.

description: OH MAN so freaking cool. If I had to recommend one "must see" spot for visitors, this would be it. The parking can get a bit full but it's totally worth it for this FREAKING VIEW! Even from the lower area you can see an incredible panoramic view of SF, but if you climb up to either of the peaks, you get a full 360... stunning!
author: Justine J.

description:
There's definitely a lot to see on the way up to twin peaks. The curvy dark roads at night, all the lost tourists, and the periodic vehicle bouncing up and down with heavy tinted windows and the lights out ( I doubt they're fighting). 

Once you get to the top the view is breath taking, not literally because you aren't high enough to be deprived of oxygen but you get to see SF from all angles. It can get breezy at night so bring a jacket or someone else's gf/bf  to keep you warm.
author: Loc N.

description:
Amazing view. Basically a 360 degree view of the entire city. I've only been at night, and I don't think that can be beat. 

I took my girlfriend up here for our 1 year anniversary, eating some creme brûlée we got from a fancy food truck. Perfect. It's a great place for clearing your mind, cuddling with that special someone, and complaining about the weather. 

The drive up there takes 10 minutes or so, with its sharp turns and actually reasonable 15 mph speed limit. Just follow the ginormous television tower and you're there.

It's breathtaking to be honest, and a place I plan on stopping by every single time I'm in the city.
author: Jonathan H.

description:
It was a cloudless and fog-less night with a full moon in the sky (there was even a lunar halo!). I looked out the window as my friend drove up to the top and I was left awestruck by the view. Some adjectives that really don't do the view justice: epic, amazing, breathtakingly beautiful. Twin Peaks is even better at night!

There's really nothing like sitting down with some friends to admire the city I grew up in, all lit up in its glory. Gotta love SF! :')
author: Emily L.

description:
We were going to do a drive by because I read parking was awful, but someone was pulling out as we were driving up the hill. The view was pretty awesome and when we went it wasn't too crowded.
