The view was great and it's wonderful to see the city from a different perspective. I didn't climb up the actual peak because that section was crawling with people and kids and I wouldn't think that a few more feet in the air would make that much of a difference. 

There was a random photo shoot going on on twin peaks which was kind of hilarious. There are also two toilets up there but I would suggest going to the potty before getting up the peak.
author: Mallory E.

description:
Ive never been to Twin Peaks even i have been to SF for two times. We drove up around 630pm and it was already super dark. 
The way up to twin peaks were kind of dangerous, many curves on the way so better drive slow. We found a parking super fast as soon as we got there. It was freezing outside so I literally just took several picture and ran back to my car since i was freezing!

The night view was amazing, you get to see Bay bridge, alot of tall buildings and lights..like every other night views. Suggest to dress warm when you come here though!
author: Yushan W.

description:
Great view of the city and a peek view of both the Golden Gate and Bay bridges.

Tip: There are two smaller hills next to the peak, both have different view points of the city, although the actual peak have the best view point, but it is still worth it to do a quick hike.
author: Mike G.

description:
Gotta come here at night for the sparkling view of the city lights.
Can get pretty windy, so bundle up...but its SO WORTH IT
author: Katie Y.

description:
I have been to this beautiful lookout quite a few times and every single time it takes my breath away...

From a blind date at night to a picnic during the day, to my most recent trip of being able to share this beauty with my daughter, the breathtaking view is one to be cherished. You can see from Marin to the south bay and everything in between. 

They have two bathrooms you can use for free that are kept clean. However, when I went last time one of the bathrooms was out of service so the line for the one bathroom took quite awhile. 

I have never been here on an overcast or foggy day, so I can't give much insight on the view for those kind of days.

Lastly, going here really makes you appreciate all San Francisco has to give and  gives you take a nice break from the fast paced life that everyone is experiencing below. Truly, a great place!
author: Andy S.

description:
It's a great view of the city. Drive to the top, don't let your passengers cheat and look around on the drive up. Take some photos. Point out some landmarks. Then drive down to the bottom and go check things out.

Bring a sweater. You don't KNOW windy and foggy.
author: Sean B.

description:
Amazing!

Came here during Superbowl 50. Took pictures with the famous "50" sign. There were a lot of people when we went but we were lucky with the parking fairy :)

It was a nice clear day, I am so grateful to live here!

I will come again on a random drive.
author: Jay B.

description: Beautiful!!! The view is just amazing!! This place is a must! Tip: it's super chilly and windy, so later up!
author: Gurleen K.

description: Absolutely breathtaking. Extremely chilly up here. Pack a few layers maybe a scarf. We only got to stay up there for a few minutes because we couldn't handle the cold but it is so spectacular up here. Definitely a tourist attraction. Not too long of a drive up. And not towindy of a road. You can see the Oakland bridge from the vantage point.
author: Krista P.

description: Great view of everything in San Francisco. Find a nice bright, clear day and make the walk up the hill. Can drive too but parking lot looked crowded. Was super touristy and busy but didn't take away from the view at all. Highly recommend this spot
author: Nick H.

description: Twin peaks is a good starter view or if your just in for a little chill spot. If your looking for something next level you'll prolly want to look else where. But I Will admit I do love going up here for that fast view and chilling.
author: Anthony A.

description: Twin Peaks is a great place to see. We easily found parking even though there was a good amount of people there. It's an easy hike up the hill(s) and very nice views even on a foggy day. We went on a foggy day and it was extremely windy walking up the hill, to the extent where I almost fell down. I carried a child on my back on the way down and it was very safe and somewhat steep at parts. Very windy at the top and cold, bring a jacket even if it's sunny!
author: Ethan H.

description:
It's 3 AM and I can't sleep because my sleep schedule's f*cked up so, here I am. LOL I'm so lame ^.^ (or a committed Yelper)

My first time at Twin Peaks was over summer (2014). My bf and I were leaving LA, our mini vacay, and before coming home, I wanted to show him this place. 

The drive was super long so we were pretty tired and sleepy, but once we reached SF, it got better because the cold air woke us up. I remember you keep driving up and up all these streets and then eventually you go up a spiraling drive towards Twin Peaks. 

There's several parking spots so we didn't have to worry about parking. Then, we got out the car and...BAAAMMM the freakin' wind hit us so hard LOL. It was freezing, but ok at least we're awake now right? 

The view was spectacular!!! Maybe I suck at operating my iPhone's cam, but ugh my pictures kind of sucked. I'll post them anyway ;-) 

Hmm I don't think I have much to say about this place, since you're just up here to see a beautiful ass view of the city haha. But of course, everyone should come here at least once!

I'm gonna consider coming back again next time I'm in SF because...I think we came here around 10 or 11pm, but ugh there's your typical group of "cool" teenagers who are being loud and obnoxious up here, smoking weed and drinking alcohol. Or at least that's what I experienced when I came here for the first time.
author: Tran M D.

description:
No not the TV show from the 90's. Yes I'm that old and remember it. This is the literal and almost figurate center of the city. It is the highest geographical point and a great viewpoint for 360 degree views of the City. On a clear day it's windy, on a foggy day it's windy, actually it's windy all the time up here. Bring a jacket because it's like going to Alcatraz, colder than you'd think or expect. A couple hundred feet elevated from the sea it's not a massive peak, but there are 2 of them, hence the name. The more public one is lower, but if you're of able body and balance you can scamper to the higher peak, but it's like being on the end of a speed boat except the wind comes from all sides.

Beautiful and the north side exit is a very popular shot for many movies done in the SF region. It's really not as steep as you'd expect because it's really not as high as you'd think at just shy of 1000 feet above sea level. Apparently it's a lovely ride on a bike, but I'm never up here with mine. Come see for yourself it's a tourists paradise for pictures that go to the relatives. It's a little grungy up there with the spray can artist and kids smoking the reefer thinking it's so windy no one can smell it.
author: Walter M.

description: Is like heaven up here.. But very cold and windy at night!! So wear thick warm jacket..!! Or cuddle with someone u love hahaha!!!
author: Crisy G.

description:
The view is one of THE BEST things I've seen!! I was amazed. @ first when I heard about the place I was like yeah, I'm sure it's a good view like other places have, but when I got up there it was breathe taking. We got there right when the sun was going down, and saw the city lights come on. Also we went when the Giants were playing a game so it was easy to spot where everything was. We saw the Golden Gate Bridge, Bay Bridge, GIANTS Stadium, to all the places in between, we saw it all! 

The night we were there was REALLY cold. Bring more than one jacket if you're planning to stay awhile. 

Even though it will always be the same view to see each time, I would and will go back again! :D
author: Akemi H.

description:
The best view you are going to get of the city. You are truly on top of it all but you have to make sure you are there on a clear day which is pretty rare in San Francisco. When the fog rolls in, you can't see anything. 

Only downside is that everyone knows about this spot and it is a tourist attraction.
author: Evan L.

description: BEAUTIFUL spot overlooking all of San Francisco to the bay itself.  The only downside to this spectacular view is driving up that hill.  Maybe it was just me, but I felt really uncomfortable on the ride up the hill as I saw approaching cars coming down the hill.  This should definitely be a major tourist attraction of the city, but for whatever reason... I don't think many tourists know about it.  Definitely worth the time and energy to get there!  I would recommend going on a day where the sky is pretty clear so you can take great photos!
author: Allison J.

description:
If you want the view of all of SF from a bird's eye view, this is the place to go. It can be a dangerous drive since there are a lot of unexpected turns, but drive slow and carefully, and you should be fine. 

There's plenty of parking at the top. The view is breath taking, literally! It can get really cold up there, so dress warm! I've been here day and night, and I can't say which is more amazing. You can see everything from the top; the Bay bridge, the Golden Gate bridge, basically most of San Francisco! 

Definitely worth coming to at least once in your life!
author: Tiffany W.

description: Just a nice park area to view all of San Francisco from above. Better to go when the san francisco fog is gone maybe around 2pm. Then you'll be able to see everything clearly!
author: Kathleen O.

description: Awesome sight of SF. Pretty fun to drive there and when u get out, just wow!! A place to visit again.
author: Johan E.

description: I can't believe I didn't come to this place before. The place has the most stunningly awesome views of the entire city. You can also have a very good glance of the Golden Gate Bridge. The place was crowded with tourists and I bet locals too on the Sunday afternoon I went. Parking is very limited, but we got lucky to found one spot right in front of the marvelous downtown SF view. I absolutely can't wait to go back during an extremely hot summer day so the views are clearer. I saw tons of people hiking to the top so that seems such a good idea for all the hikers out there. You should definitely visit this place when in the area if you want awesome shots of the city by the bay.
author: Nubia O.

description:
Easily the best view in SF         ..........when it's not foggy. 

You can see so much from the 240+ degree view: both the Golden Gate and Bay Bridges, Market St., to City Hall, to Alcatraz, the Embarcadero, and to the Transamerica building. A what's what and whose who of SF landmarks. Post card views can be found here for free. 

Twin Peaks is so versatile; I've been here so many times throughout the years....

In high school, we'd come here to hang out in the parking lot bumping our music. 
In college, it would be a good "date spot" after a movie. And a good spot to clear your head after that eventual breakup. 

Most recently, took my cousin from Switzerland here to take some photos and take in the scenery. He loved it. 

A definite must visit while touring SF. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WV2fVK6OJfzn2BkRGpbP7A?select=LUcRN9emTBnOlZ6ytHnXbQ) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WV2fVK6OJfzn2BkRGpbP7A?select=g08JwPYxS6BZ2b0FAYWiyA)
author: Earl G.

description:
Can you say ultimate StairMaster workout? The ascent begins before you actually reach the beginning of the trails...gotta conquer the hilly sidewalks first! 

Don't be despaired if it looks like you're wandering through ppl's apt. complexes...just follow the staircases up and eventually you hit the base of Twin Peaks (don't use the car route or you're in for a reaaaaally long, albeit, scenic walk). 

Bring:
- Good walking/hiking shoes because the steps are uneven and there's a lot of loose gravel on the dirt paths.
- Water...gotta stay hydrated while you sweat your way to the top.
- An extra layer for wind (SF weather is really unpredictable). I went up mid-March and the weather was really gorgeous! Temps were in the mid to upper 60s F.
- Sunglasses
- Snacks if you want to eat at the top. There are big rocks you can sit on.
- Camera for the breathtaking views

Hiking up Twin Peaks then grabbing food in the Mission for a picnic in Dolores Park afterward makes for a perfect day trip out to SF.
author: Bonnie Z.

description: Came here last night while the rain cooled down and it was sooooo foggy!!!! Came again tonight and yay! Finally got to see it. Worth the trip again and was definitely debating whether to go or not tonight. Thank you for the weather change Mother Nature! Last night in SF & lucky to see this killer view.
author: Alexandra D.

description:
Seriously my favorite part of SF. 

Last time I came here, it was so foggy so I wasn't able to see anything. Another trip to SF, we were lucky enough to come on a clear day and it blew me away. Literally, the winds are so strong here I was pretty sure I was gonna get blown away.

The view is amazing. You could literally see the whole city right below you. I've only been here during the day but I would love to come back at night one day. 

I always have to come here when I'm in SF because it never ceases to take my breath away. 

Remember, bring a jacket!!
author: Samantha C.

description:
Wear a jacket and not anything too flowy! Definitely stay away from dresses and skirts. 
This place is super cool to hang out and take pictures at but its VERY windy and it can get quite cold. 
Definitely one of the highlights in SF!
author: Catherine L.

description:
I moved to SF because I fell in love with its culture, architecture, and the overall feeling the city exudes.
Seeing the whole city lit up at night makes me fall in love all over again.  Perfect view (when it's a clear night.)
author: Josh S.

description:
Gorgeous view of the city!! It seems to be quite the hike to the top, so I drove. Parking was ample and easy to find. I could have stared at the city for hours it was so beautiful! 5+ star view, for sure!

The spot was decently saturated with tourists, but it it a place that definitely deserves to be on everyone's must see/must do list of SF. Only complaint is that both bathrooms were out of order. 

One more thing, fellow reviewers. Are you really complaining about this place being cold? Yes, it's high above the city on a large hill, so expect a breeze. But it's a BREEZE. Chill out.  I came in late November and didn't need more than a light sweatshirt. It's a tiny bit brisk, yes, but not cold. Come to Wisconsin in the middle of winter with below zero temperatures so cold it can't snow, and then you'll know what true cold is. :)
author: Marissa M.

description: Great place for a city view. Came here at sunset on a Sunday, and it wasn't too crowded. There's a small hill to climb for a better view of the sunset, but the best view of the city is right where the parking lot is. I recommended ubering here even if you don't have a car.
author: Grace K.

description: Definitely not a hike, but the 360 degree views of the city are incredible. Everyone should check it out at least once.
author: Brooke S.

description:
This is a great place to come and visit. You can see everything in San Francisco from here. I have been here 3 times in the last 10 years and it has probably been my favorite spot, and yes, that includes places I've gone out to eat. 

Sometimes I bring my food here and eat it because it makes everything better.
author: Aakash S.

description:
Been here a bunch of times and the view will differ depending on the fog. Came here Saturday with the family and it's windy and cold as heck. Parked away from the crowd and was welcomed with broken glasses all over the pavement (says something about the activity around the area) so park at your own risk. As we embarked atop the peak we were welcomed once again with the sweet smelling of fresh cannabis in the air. The view was beautiful and not a fog to see that day. We didn't stay for long though as the wind and cold were inevitable and our noses started running. 

Anyhow, it's a great place to bring visiting family that wanted a good view of San Francisco and take some touristy pictures. Dress in layers as the weather can be unpredictable up here. Enjoy the hike and take in the scenery.
author: Joy P.

description:
Yes, this is a tourist spot. 
No, I am not a tourist. I live in the Bay Area.
But yes, I still love this spot.

How can I not? I'm on top of the world overlooking the city I was born in, the city that I grew up in. And I love it.

Here are some awesome pictures my friends and I took. Vote if you like them! :
- with friends: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WV2fVK6OJfzn2BkRGpbP7A?select=1DlWmU2JZuY1kg7aNSL-_g

Advice/Opinions: 
- I love it more at night than during the day.  It's still nice during the day because you can see everything, but night it's just spectacular with the city lights and bridges. 
- Don't come when it's foggy. 
- Wear lots and lots of layers! It's high in altitude so of course it's going to be windy and freezing!
- Bring a camera. You won't want to miss it :)

Beautiful, isn't it?
author: Raquel Y.

description:
Hands down, absolutely the best place to bring an out-of-towner! The views here are absolutely breathtaking!

I discovered this place when my son and his friends posted a picture of themselves with the city of San Francisco in their backdrop. What I saw was a silhouette of the "bunch" with the lights of the city in their background. What? A place I had never heard of? Twin Peaks? What?? Never heard of it! 

After seeing those images, I had to go there myself and it's as incredible as the images I saw. Absolutely incredible! I don't think that it's one of those places that's on the sightseers radar screen, which may be a good thing. I have found my way here during the day, and I have to say that whether you come here during the day or night, it is absolutely worth the drive up here, and it's all free!

Make sure to dress in layers as it can be quite windy or cold.
author: Micki M.

description: Bring a warm drink, a blanket, dress warmly and enjoy the view! One of the best spots over looking the city of San Francisco.
author: M R.

description: A must see while in SF. The views are gorgeous and it's a great place for a photo op. The view and weather was perfect
author: MarcCrystal C.

description:
So amazing - what fabulous views of San Fran! I could spend hours up here just staring out at the city.

Watch your hats though - the gusts were so intense up here, the wind took my husband's hat right off his head and into the abyss!
author: Kim K.

description:
This is a nice big park that caps Twin Peaks on of the mountains (with two peaks at the top) It is a clime, but not two bad. With great views along the way and even better at the end on one of the tops.

I have gone to the top a couple of ways.  Which way just depends on how much of a hike I am wanting.

The easiest way is to take the Muni's 37 Corbet line from the Castro.  It will take you up to the park then you can hike to the peak.  Note: this still leaves you hiking the steepest part.  

The longer hike is about 2 miles from Castro station. All most all uphill according to Wiki you climb about 200 feet.   Most of the hikes will be through nice neighborhoods on their narrow roads.  There are lots of nice views to wet your taste for the views from the top.  Finally you will reach the park where you hike on narrow trails through the park to the top.

There are also tour busses that take you close to the top to an observation point.  Missing only the step climbs to the peaks.  You can also drive here,  I have seen the cars and busses.

The park is nice.  It is not planted and groomed leaving it to the plants that were here before San Francisco was reclaimed from the sand and scrub.  You may also see small wild life.  While lots make it the the observation area, few seem to come to the peak.  

Tip: you earn the views,  the hike is steep so if you see it is a nice clear day,  that is the day to come!
author: Mark B.

description:
Absolutely stunning views of SF! Ever trip my husband wants to do something involving views of whatever city we are in. I'm so happy I found this! It was perfect and no stair climbing needed!! 

We had a 3 month old baby with us and the lower peak you can easily do with a stroller. The higher peak you have to do a bit of a steep hill on dirt so unfortunately I didn't make it up there with the stroller. The views are incredible regardless what peak you decide to visit!
author: Jena D.

description: Twin peaks ..!!!  Really its a great view from top of that.. 360°view there.  Awesomeness .
author: Vidaa S.

description:
AMAZING, dare I say best, view of the city.

A ridiculously gorgeous, impressively romantic, and unsurprisingly windy, tourist destination in San Francisco that even the natives visit once in a while to remind ourselves (not that we need it) how amazing San Francisco really is.
author: Patricia K.

description:
It's indefensible to give Twin Peaks less than 5 stars. If you wore shorts, that's your fault. If you go for fireworks and can't see them, that's your fault. If there is no playground at the top, so what. If you couldn't find parking, isn't it better that there are a limited amount of stops at the top of this landmark instead of having a rest stop parking lot with a Jack in the Box on top? None of these things make Twin Peaks any less breathtaking. It's a phenomenal double 360 degree, if you climb both peaks, view of a lifetime - a cityscape that will be embedded in your dreams for years to come.

Bring a camera, bring a jacket, wear pants and open your eyes. There is really nothing else you need to do to be amazed. Climbing both peaks is definitely worth it.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
Head in the direction of Sutro tower to Twin Peaks for a beautiful view of the entire city (unless it's covered in fog, it is SF). 

If you are a local or a tourist this is by far one of the best views to be had in the city.
Make sure you layer up because it can get windy up here, even when it's 20 degrees warmer in SoMa.  

It's worth a view during the day and night.  During the day, take the extra little hike across the street from the parking lot. 

At night on the weekend there's a lot of steamy windows, loud music and underage drinking, but you can still snag a spot pretty fast. People will often look, pose for a few pics and jump back in their car if they are not partaking in any of the activities listed above. 

Good for sunrise, sunset, wedding & engagement pictures, falling in love and such.
author: Kristi G.

description: Came here at night wearing shorts and a T-shirt (and a weird vest my friend let me borrow). Bad idea. It was super cold, windy, and foggy. I was shaking the whole time as soon as I stepped outside the car. The beautiful view is undeniable. You can see the entire city. Very clear at night despite the fog. However, the cold was unbearable and I couldn't enjoy it as much as I'd like to. Parking could be hard but just circle around since people don't tend to stay too long. Must come if you are visiting SF.
author: Juan F.

description:
I have to agree with everyone else! Twin peaks is an awesome place to take tourist so they can see how beautiful San Francisco is in eagle eye view. 

I've been here at all hours of the day since I am a local bay arean. Whenever life got confusing through out high school. My friends and I would spontaneously come here to just clear our head and enjoy the beautiful view. I've been here during sunrise. Beautiful. I've been here on a clear sunny day. Beautiful. I've been here at night. Amazing! It's even better after 11 because there's less of a crowd. Also don't come on a foggy day... You won't see much. On a cloudy night. It's still beautiful.

P.S. Bring a jacket and beanie because it can get chilly and windy.
author: Ashley T.

description: Twin Peaks is the vantage point for one of the best views of San Francisco. We came there on a tour and I was getting a little car sick from the windy roads. I wouldn't want to drive there myself. I snapped a lot of excellent pictures there and was happy that this was one of the stops. Get there when you're in town. I would go back for sure.
author: Janet F.

description: San Francisco is a beautiful city. No one can ever deny it. Yeah it's small. We know...but that's what's nice about...its intimacy. Twin Peaks is one of my favorite place to check out the view of the city. Nothing can beat the view on a hot, clear day in SF. No matter how many times I go here...I always marvel at how fortunate I am to live in such a picturesque city.
author: Ralph N.

description:
Awesome view of the city without having to hike much (unless you didn't drive).

Pick either peak and you get a great 360 degree view of the whole city, which is really nice. You can see DT, Mission St. Alcatraz, the bridges...

Bring a jacket though. It can get SUPER windy! But overall, a great view and a great place to bring someone to check out the city, without having to hike miles just to get a great view.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
Woo! One of my favorite spots to take people in the city, whether they're out-of-town visitors, or local residents who've never visited. Probably one of the best views in the city, as you get to look down on everything in a 180 angle north of this point, allowing for fantastic views of the Bay Bridge, the Golden Gate Bridge, Downtown and Market Street, and much, much more.

The downsides? It's cold up here. Like, really cold. And windy. Also, don't make the mistake of coming up here when the fog is really heavy: not only is it a much more dangerous drive up the dark, windy road, you also won't be able to see much up here anyway!
author: Johnny W.

description: Gotta give Twin Peaks five stars for its SOLID view of SF/The Bay.  I'm always a bit weirded out by the creepers sitting in their cars (what the heck are you doing in there?  I know it has nothing to do with the view - at least the view of SF.)  Despite the mobs of tourists and assorted trolls, the view is stunning!  TP is a must-see for all - one of the coolest spots in The SF Bay Area. F-I-V-E stars.
author: Patrick L.

description:
Fantastic view of the city.  

When I want a view & we're more in the mood to drive we go to Twin Peaks.
When we're in more of walking mood we go to Bernal Heights.  haha.

(our M.O. with guests too.... sometimes people get tired from all the city walking!!  So TP is a nice departure from that!!)  hehe =)
author: CatwomanRoar M.

description:
Twin Peaks is a great spot, but it's certainly not a secret! Expect crowds, but thankfully, cars come and go quickly, so you won't have to wait too long for a spot. Make sure to enjoy the drive on the way up; it's great too!

This spot is great day or night, but be sure to come when it's not a foggy night or you won't see much. 

As per typical San Francisco weather, It's quite cold at night, so bring along a blanket and/or a warm jacket. 

There's always kids chilling up here smoking and drinking, so don't expect a private romantic tryst, but do expect great views. 

We always take out of towners here for a nice surprise, and on a clear night, here's what I usually point out for visitors: the length of Market Street, the Castro theater, AT&T Park, the Ferry Building, the big dark patch -- that's Golden Gate Park, that interesting mosque building, Civic Center, the Bay Bridge and whatever else you can see depending on the levels on fog. On a clear night, you can see the Golden Gate Bridge too -- visitors love that, obviously.

So come day or night and take in the views.
author: Rebecca G.

description: Even though it was very foggy when I visited (took bus transportation up to a point, then a brief Uber ride to the top), it was still a nice experience being on top of San Francisco and enjoying the wuthering-heighty winds (which made me feel like I was in the Juliette Binoche film "Sils Maria"). Great views (which, I'm sure, are mind-blowing with nicer weather) and romantic winding roads. Bring a jacket, or you will be cold!
author: Rick B.

description:
Second review coming up:

Whatever the weather is. We keep ending up going in here... Just coz we love the view and whenever its daylight or nighttime it doesnt matter. But if i were to choose ill rather go up here at night for a perfect view of city lights at the city!!
author: Begz B.

description:
I'm gonna first state my bias, as I'm close enough to walk there; but it's never a bad place to visit. (Personally like Tank Hill better)

Don't leave valuables in plain sight - that's a great way to get robbed; oblivious tourist, you!
author: Joshua L.

description: Very nice place to bring visitors who are visiting the bay. Its a romantic feel but if you have buncha friends who want to just see SF on a hill this is a great place to go. Ample amount of parking since you can park around the mountains and there's a small lot.
author: Allan W.

description: I go here every year and it's always the best place to take panoramic photos and appreciate the city! Roads aren't that steep. Wooden steps on trails needa be fixed. Biking or trekking it would be great, too!
author: Omar M.

description: One of the best views of the city , you can see all of downtown , bay bridge, Golden Gate Bridge . No sunset district though. They also opened up more parking spots. Just a 5 min hike from the parking.
author: Jones T.

description:
The view....... I have no words to describe how beautiful it is! I feel like such a tourist here and when you go hiking the views even better lol


There's a self cleaning restroom but bring some napkins or something! -tip****
Also a pair of sunglasses and bottles of water! Keep hydrated people! Enjoy!
author: Grace G.

description:
My quest for a perfect date spot has led me to here. 

This place is really easy to find (just follow signs and the road), and best of all, since the road has many twist and turns, you can impress your date with your mad driving skills. 

Once you do manage to reach the top, the view is spectacular. Its amazing during the day and just breathtakingly awesome at night. You can see all of San Francisco and on clear days, the entire bay area.

There are also steep hills for you to hike up near the site so its a perfect excuse to hold someone's hand while going up one of these...and going down!

This place is almost always extremely windy so bring a jacket...or two, and a scarf!

If you need to go to the bathroom, theres one public bathroom and its the type that cleans itself...yeah, you have to check it out!

Its great! Check this place out :)
author: Shawn S.

description: Great views of the city. I advise to bring a jacket as it can get pretty chilly and windy.
author: Twila O.

description:
Beautiful, beautiful views. Make sure to go on clear nights or you won't be able to see anything. Or go a little before the fog rolls because watching the fog crawl through the cracks and alleys of San Francisco is probably the most chilling, but exquisite and captivating city view I've seen. 

Make sure to climb up the rocks/hill to get an even BETTER view. There are steps so you don't need to bring special hiking shoes. Tennis shoes, like vans or converses, are just fine as long as they're closed toed.

If you're bored of the lights, still go up to twin peaks so you can climb the hill to lay there are star gaze. Again, go on a clear night. It's so relaxing. Bring a cuddle buddy too!!
author: Annie T.

description:
One of the most scenic spots in all of the bay area. You essentially have a 360 degree view of the Bay Area, and depending on how foggy it is, can see for miles. You can either park down the street and hike up, or drive all the way to the top. A few friends and I recently chose to hike it. It's not super strenuous, but be wary of people driving quickly like Vin Diesel for maximum cool factor. 

There are bathrooms, and spotting scopes (which for some reason cost 50c to use) at the top. If you go during the weekend, on a nice day there is usually an ungodly amount of tourists there who are usually pretty ruthless about taking pictures. 

My only qualm with the place is the amount of garbage people leave around. Not surprisingly, it is pretty windy on top of a large hill with minimal coverage. If you put your newspaper down, there is a high probability it will fly away. Do not do this, or locals like myself with hate you. 

Really is without a doubt one of the best views in the entire city, and should not be missed.
author: Chris S.

description:
Wait, how does Twin Peaks have a half star missing? They have the fancy cleaning bathrooms up there.... HOW? 

Haha anyways, if you're looking to do something touristy, romantic, adventurous or just need to make up your mind on if you want to move to SF or not - me, then go to Twin Peaks. 

Breathtaking view of the entire city! The drive up is a little windy and scary, so slow dowwwwnn! Parking isn't so bad as well, tons of street parking and a few lots if you are lucky. Also check the weather, we went when it wasn't foggy and it was gorgeous! 

Traveling Tip: They have clean bathrooms.

Twin Peaks Verdict: Moving to SF!
author: Brittany P.

description:
This place is popular for a reason: it gives you one of the best views of San Francisco, in which you can see the Golden Gate Bridge, Bay Bridge, and the city lights. This place gets ridiculously crowded at night due to it being a local and tourist hot spot, but it is well worth the trouble. The drive up is easy although parking may be difficult during peak hours. 

Recently I have discovered that my favorite time to come is for sunrise. We got there around 5 am while the sun was still down, and there was no one else there. We were able to take a few night shots due to the darkness, and then stayed there to watch the amazing sunrise. Sunrise here is one of the best since it is rising from your view of the city, and if you're lucky and find yourself there on a clear day, this will be one of the most breathtaking views you'll have of San Francisco. Be sure to layer up, though, because regardless of it being winter or summer, it's freezing up there!
author: Ada C.

description: Perfect scenic view. Chilly winds but a great opportunity to cling onto your significant other / crush to keep warm and enjoy the breath taking view. If this scene was in a movie it would be the happy ending after a storm and everyone meets back up smiles and hugs one another. Enjoy life. Love. Peace.
author: Andrew W.

description:
This was my second time here and second time here in SF!! 

The second time when I was here with my Fam, it rained in SF.. N I was afraid that my parents would not be able to view the beautiful SF night lights.. But was wrong! The rain stopped n the view was so beautiful as much as I saw on my very first time here! 

If you love the beautiful night lights.. U will love n enjoy the view from here.. But be aware.. It's superrrrr windy n cold up here!! So bring a sweater or hoodie or a blanket even! 

A must stop if u r visiting SF!
author: Cony L.

description:
Possibly the high point of a visit to San Francisco, both literally and figuratively.

It provides an almost 360 view of the city, although points to the west require that one walks around the sidewalks to capture more views.  It's fun to go up here with out-of-town people and pick out all the major thoroughfares and landmarks.  Market Street becomes prominent in that equation, as do all the famous structures in the city.  This is another nirvana for photographers ... and both bridges are visible from this unique viewpoint.

Another bonus is trying to identify all the different languages one hears up here along the main pathway with the limited parking, the telescopes, and the primary views.  It's a testament to the fact that San Francisco is one of the world's most popular tourist destinations.
author: Robert G.

description: Best view of SF hands down! Perfect for panorama pictures or just your typical touristy photo. Don't forget a sweater, it gets really windy
author: Nerissa M.

description:
This seems like a great spot for alot of things although the fog gets in between an in the way at times.   The zodiak killer seemed to like this spot and when I was younger I remember rolling deep and having get togethers at this spot. 

Great place to check out the view. 
SOmetimes I've actually taken my shoes off. 

The air feels really nice up at the peaks. 

One time I had a picnic up here with a girl I thought it would be romantic. 
It was but I didn't quite make out like I wanted.

If you come up here in the day I suggest you bring something to take photo's and take lots of em.
author: Luke S.

description:
I have been here a handful of times because it's absolutely beautiful up here. Whether you're a local or tourist or a local showing tourists around, try to fit this in your itinerary, I recommend coming here during when the sun is setting (see The City both day and night plus the gorgeous sunset. Also, you're still able to take decent pictures without flash). You can see the view of the whole city, the Bay Bridge, tip of the Golden Gate Bridge. My favorite is the city lights.

There's free parking but depending on the crowd, might have to wait for cars to leave (especially on a fogless night). I took the bf here on the most recent trip (his first time), a clear Friday night, lots of visitors, but parking didn't seem to be a problem as we saw a lot of cars coming in and going out. The bf speculate that most people tend to stay two minutes to take in the view and leave very soon after due to the freezing cold San Francisco weather (not exaggerating!!), so there were plenty of parking haha. I agreed, because that was us! Being a native San Francisco for most my live, I still cannot stand the coldness! So don't say I didn't warn you, BRING A THICK JACKET!

Random note, there's a public restroom that you can pay for if you really have to go.

Enjoy!
author: Winnie T.

description: Great spot to take visiting friends for a gorgeous view of the city... or just to remind yourself how beautiful San Francisco is. I've always just driven to the top of Twin Peaks, though you can look up hiking trails online. There is usually plenty of parking right at the peak or in nearby dirt lots. There are multiple vantage points that prevent touristy crowding so bring ALL your friends! It's a different (but equally awesome) experience during the day versus the nighttime but only when the sky is clear. Don't forget to bring a jacket or blanket, because it can get cold and windy.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
This was one of the last places my bestfriend and I took a picture together before she passed. 

... twin peaks will always be a happy place in my nostalgic memory.
author: Jane A.

description:
Oh My Freaking Gawd!!!! How come it's just now that I found out about this place? Was I really that sheltered or for the past several years I have been living under a rock, boring myself to death? Either way,  I am just glad that my friend brought me and my lovey here http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=W8bEdo4l6YDPgupqRf-5fA&userid=BDHDu2gEcRS6d4qz8yf7zg.

It was a short drive from South San Francisco where I picked up my friend Karen. I think it was just a 15minute commute going here. We took 280 to Highway 1. We are supposed to stay on Junipero Serra Blvd but she stayed on 19th Ave so we had to make a right turn to get on the right track. You can't get lost here. There are signs going to Twin Peaks. Actually, if you don't have a smart phone (if in case you don't, shoot yourself or come to me, i'll sell you one...JOOOOKKKEEEE) you just have to follow those tourists bus you see on Junipero Serra because 100% they are going that way...That's FOSHO!

So, we played tourists that day. The view was just BREATHTAKING! http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=UdCKvhwZcY_F1FgF6yKTFg&userid=BDHDu2gEcRS6d4qz8yf7zg. It was not a foggy day so we had a very good view of the city. This place gave me a very good idea for a future date. Like seriously, my future boyfriend (he is out there i know waiting for fate to bring us together! Weeeeeee! *giddy* LOL) will appreciate me if I bring him here or if he is smart enough to bring me here first before I do, while my romantic country music playing in the background (Cheesy much Yelp?) hehehe

Bring your jacket and If you have a date with you STILL, bring your jacket because hugging eachother will not be enough to keep both of you warm unless of course you guys are hot and heavy for eachother. Now, you may want to bust your 2 quarters out if you wanna use those telescopes there.  Also get your baby wipes. No, dear, it's not for wiping your a$$! It's for those germaphobes (you guys knows who you are) coz you may want to wipe those lenses first. Please do not drive here if you are already under the influence of whatever alcohol. The road is kinda winding but if you are kinda psychotic, then go for it! Don't tell me I didn't warn you.  

I will definitely bring relatives from out of state here next time.

and 

I will for sure come back here at night when all the lights are shining bright.

You feel me? :)
author: Kevyne R.

description: Must check this place out if you are in SF! On a clear night you get the entire view of San Francisco and you can see the Golden Gate Bridge and the East bay bridge. The view is best at night because you can see the entire city lit up. It's also pretty chilly so bring a sweater.
author: Alison T.

description:
Must to come place when you visit to SF. Even local should come to take a look this beautiful scenery. I recommend at the night time and take a look of the fireworks info of the SF Giants. You an see fireworks form this top!

You can find other locations to take photograph from here.
http://www.pashadelic.com/photos/87354
author: Kenji Y.

description:
I've been looking at it all wrong. But not really.

I am a born and bred East Bay girl, so when I think of San Francisco it is always with my beautiful Bay Bridge in the foreground and those gorgeous skyscrapers rising up from the bay on the horizon. But it is good to see things from both sides.

After spending a lovely afternoon traipsing through the Castro district, the lovely Rebecca H. took me to see the view. Before this my only connection to Twin Peaks was the quirky David Lynch movie/TV show. "Would you like some cherry pie, Agent Cooper?" I had no idea it was one of the best views in the city.

If you can find parking at the top, definitely stop and climb the hill for a stunning view of the mighty Pacific Ocean to the west, the Golden Gate Bridge to the north and then look straight up Market Street with the roof of the Ferry Building acting like an exclamation point in front of the bay.

The day was perfectly clear and I imagine the only better scenario would be as the day turns into night and a rosy haze envelopes the city. There were hikers and bikers taking a more challenging route to the top, but for us it was a pleasure cruise.

My childhood visions of 'The City' are still the ones I carry in my heart, but San Francisco continues to unveil herself and enchant me in new ways at every age.
author: Jen K.

description: THE BEST PLACE TO SEE ALL OF SAN FRANCISCO. This has to be one of the most beautiful sights I have ever seen. The best days to go are on crystal clear days. You can literally see all of San Francisco from here. This is a must do when you're in San Fran. Have your cameras ready and happy sight seeing!
author: Michael Q.

description:
The view is ammmaazzziinnnggg!  Keep in mind that on a foggy day you might not be able to see anything, but on a nice day, the view is to die for.  You can see everything on a clear day.  Market street, the financial district, the bay bridge, the golden gate bridge, etc.  Beautiful panoramic views.  It's cold and windy so bring a jacket.  

There is a parking lot with a good amount of parking (20 minute parking, although there are no parking enforcement in sight).  There is also one restroom at the top (I think you need change to use it).
author: Lisa G.

description: The best view of San Francisco! It's breathtaking. The drive up takes a few minutes but once you get there it's so beautiful... It wasn't too crowded when I visited and the fog cleared up before I arrived so I had a perfect view. A must-see when visiting SF!!
author: Melissa C.

description: Cool place to take in the sights. Make sure you know how to drive because the road to the top could seem challenging for some. If you have a special someone in your life it's a spot to take them on a nice evening to take in a v view of the City by The Bay.
author: Robert F.

description: If ever visiting San Francisco, Twin Peaks is a must!!! The view is break taking! The best time to go is late evening so you can experience both the day and night view. It is very chilly!! Make sure to dress warm because it is also pretty windy!
author: Sarah H.

description:
Took Uber to this site during the day and it was crazy busy. You get a 360degree view of the city. I've heard people hike to this vista but is there a trail or what? I don't know. It was just so many people, cars, and busses that it was overwhelming.

It's definitely something to see. 

Getting an Uber back proved very difficult. I dont know if its a phone reception thing or what but it worked out in the end. It just took a great while.
author: O M G.

description:
Very San Francisco! 
First time I saw nice night view. Only a few months after I came to the U.S. 
The second time, early in the morning like 7 a.m., I ran up to the peak with running mates.
Foggy and couldn't see ANYTHING. But that was also Very San Francisco!
author: Kaori M.

description: I think the view would be much better at night. It was a very nice view of SF. There are multiple peaks (I think there are 3) so you can go to all to get different views.
author: Lillian N.

description: Spectacular view of San Francisco. I came here with my boyfriend during the evening a few weeks ago. Although it was quite foggy we were still able to see the lights down below! I was quite nervous driving up here (I'm from the east bay) and am not used to driving up steep hills. There wasn't major incline the drive up, just a bit winding. However the drive through the neighborhood before going up Twin Peaks was a little steep for my liking, but was manageable for someone who doesn't drive in SF often.
author: AJ B.

description:
This is the highest elevation in San Francisco, at 922ft (281m). The views are exemplary on a clear day.

The major drawback is lack of paths, necessitating walking along switchback roads without sidewalks (do not attempt at night) and complete lack of anything along the way or at observation level, including bathrooms or water.
author: Andrew D.

description: Twin Peaks is a definite MUST SEE if you go to SF! You can see the whole city, and surrounding cities. The air is light and it is completely quiet up on top of the hills. However, if you aren't used t climbing, it may be difficult for you as there are steep stairs to climb. There's only one bus coming up and down the hill, so you may wait a while. Thankfully, there are restrooms, but only two of them so you may wait a while.
author: Margaret P.

description:
I learned K.I.S.S.  in elementary school...so here's a throwback.

Twin Peaks has the most incredible views of the city.  Bring a jacket though because it gets breezy up there.  And guys, this would be a perfect spot to take a date to, as a matter of fact, my bf did on our first date.

THE END.
author: Cat C.

description: Made he mistake of going on a super foggy day so couldn't see much. Definitely lock away any and all valuables or just take them with you. There was one person lurking around our car peering through our windows but luckily we had all of our bags with us.
author: Gabe C.

description: Today we went to twin peaks and I thought the views were quite amazing the only problem was that it was really windy but the view was worth it.
author: Michelle L.

description:
I was recently brought up here at night because it was on my San Francisco Bucket List.

My impressions were as follows:
SO COLD. Wear appropriate clothing.
Tourists are annoying.
Children of tourists are even more annoying.
Gorgeous view.
Did I say that the tourists are annoying?
AWESOME VIEW!
author: Tara H.

description:
4 stars for the view, 1 star for the wind and freezing cold and the fact that 7 out of 10 days you can't see anything because of the fog.  
Parking can be tough and they always seem to have cops up there to hand out tickets, so be careful parking.
author: Greg B.

description: What a beautiful view! One of those places you have to stop to see a birds eye view of San Fran
author: Maria V.

description:
This is one of the rare 3 star reviews of Twin peaks. But lemme lay it down for you of how my experience was:

COLD
FREEZING
MISTY
FOGGY
MASSIVE-EL NINO LIKE-WINDS
all at 4pm. 

The day I come up north to visit this infamous-jaw dropping view of SF is the day that it had to be cold and foggy. I was literally blown away by the wind, and despite the attempts of taking a picture of the view, there really wasn't a view, unless you want to count the ground I was literally standing on or the fog that covered up the view. It must be a really nice view under all that fog, but I guess we'll just have to see it on another day.
author: Marthie D.

description: Great views! Terrible crime spot! If you leave valuables in your car your window will be broken, and a thief will take everything. The sad thing is the SFPD is aware of the problem but does little to fix the issue. If you are touring the SF area and want to visit the point, do so, but keep the things you care about back at the hotel.
author: Kent W.

description:
One of the best views of San Francisco. It's not super close to the skyline but you can see a lot - basically 360.

The drive up there is pretty easy, go through a little bit of residential then up the hill. There's some stairs on the other hill if you want to get a little bit of an exercise.

Never disappoints whether you go in the day or at night, love it.

For a better view of the skyline check out treasure island.

They also have a free restroom (but it cleans itself after each use and the line can take a while. But worth it for a clean free bathroom?)
author: Saya Y.

description:
This is a beautiful lookout place overseeing the entire San Francisco city. I've been here at night and also during the day. Both were beautiful views. Worth the trip anytime of the day. 

Suggestion: Bring a snack and have a picnic up here. =)
author: Zar A.

description: Best view of the city. I come here often when I'm home to watch the sunset over the city. You can see all of the city, including the golden gate on one side, and the ocean on the other. I always take friends visiting from out of town here and they love the view! While the main parking lot is crowded with tourists, I recommend parking on the street and hiking up one of the two main hills. The views are even better from higher up and allows you to see both sides. Definitely a must do when in the city!
author: Christina G.

description: Best time to be there is around 5 when the sun is beginning to set and the sky is changing color
author: Sam C.

description:
I grew up 50 miles from San Francisco, and somehow never made it here -- this is what you get when you're the youngest and your parents just assume you've seen everything that your older siblings have! ;)  

So, finally, my boyfriend was visiting my parents with me, so we took him there.  We arrived right as you could view the moon rising from one peak, and the sun setting from the other.  Oh, the choices!  We ended up enthralled with the moon, and my mother ended up in line for the bathroom for THE ENTIRE TIME (because it's a one-room public bathroom that, you know, takes about a minute or two to self-clean itself between every person in line, and there are huge bus fulls of people everywhere).

In the meantime, we took a million photos, and enjoyed a great street artist who was hanging out making WONDERFUL pieces of art using spray paint and some dishes.  I was very impressed. 

So -- bring a coat, and gloves.  Go to the bathroom before driving up.  And be prepared with your camera.
author: Molly M.

description:
The city. 

(Especially on a clear sunny day)

--
PHOTO:
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WV2fVK6OJfzn2BkRGpbP7A?select=RIb0j7sCmkHNlur3QhRq8A#RIb0j7sCmkHNlur3QhRq8A
author: Kevin L.

description: So beautiful I'm so glad we stopped here before we left San Francisco it's so worth it it's really cold and windy you need your sweater there's a restroom there which is great a lot of people taking pictures we got some great pictures and it's worth the trip because you get to see all of San Francisco.
author: Nona W.

description: Definitely one of the best places I've been to in SF.  Not only is it free, but it offers breathtaking views of the city.  You can see both the Golden Gate Bridge and the Bay Bridge as well as the whole bay and city.  It was a little cloudy so it was slightly difficult to see the Golden Gate Bridge (especially in pictures) but absolutely worth the short and easy drive to this area.
author: Sapna D.

description:
I don't know why I haven't been here sooner. My boyfriend and I were in the city for dinner and didn't want to head back to the East Bay just yet. We made a stop here (quite easy to get to) and found parking right away! There's a ton of people, so just be careful when driving at night. 

The view is incredible. You can see everything from this vantage point. GG bridge to your left. Bay bridge ahead of you. Bring a light jacket if you're going here, as it can get really windy. We were fortunate to come on a hot night (70+ degrees) so the slight breeze was preferred. :)
author: Kim N.

description: The first time I went, it was the typical foggy city but I knew I had to come again. The second time I went was a sunny and clear day and it was both beautiful and a great way to spend time with friends and family! The view is truly breathtaking and I would definitely come again! :*)
author: Emily W.

description: The view from here will give you a good perspective of San Francisco city and bay, with the whole area opening out before you. Two view is unimpeded and interesting. Be aware though, given its height and the geography of the area, it's quite likely to be blustery and possibly cold up here, so be ready to put on more clothes when you visit!
author: Ali H.

description:
Twin Peaks is for lovers... and clueless tourists and party people
arriving on party buses too.

Twin Peaks is more than just a great hook up spot. It's seriously one
of the most spectacular views you will ever see. On a clear day you
can see forever. At night, the bright lights of The City by the Bay
mesmerize for miles all the way out to both the Bay and Golden Gate
bridges.

If you're a Guy and you can't get some after taking a girl here, you
have issues. Either you didn't hold her or offer her your jacket while
she was shivering cold from the chilly SF weather while wearing a
mini-skirt to impress you. Or you let her nearly fall down from being
blown over by the wind without reaching for her. When you come to Twin
Peaks it's time to man up, grab your woman and keep her warm and safe.

I've never been here on a clear weekend night before. This place gets
packed! A couple of party buses showed up later and stayed around
pumping out beats that the whole parking lot could enjoy.

In a city that is known to nickel 'n dime you to death, Twin Peaks is
a revelation. One of the few sights that may be worth paying to see. I
just hope members of the Board of Supervisors don't read Yelp...

Pro Tip: Bring your significant other here on a foggy, chilly weekday
night and you'll probably have Twin Peaks all to yourselves. You'll
get to see the beauty of Twin Peaks in a whole new light.
author: John B.

description: Whenever I have to be a tour guide for San Francisco to either friends, family, or even a date once, I would end the night on top of Twin Peaks. You can see almost every major destination from here and it has a beautiful view of the street lights during night. Bring a warm blanket and sit on a step and feel the nice breeze on your face and enjoy the moment.
author: John S.

description: Amazing view! When I went it was super windy and cold it felt that we almost were about to roll down the hill. You can see the beautiful city.
author: Fabby C.

description: So, the equivalent of walking up 62 floors. Have you heard of elevators? Also it would expected that you could get a snack once you get up there. No WiFi, either. But worst of all: everything covered in clouds once you get there. No view at all. I would give it 0 stars if possible.
author: Henning B.

description:
I've been coming here as before I could drive, and that's saying something!

Whenever we have friends/family from out of town, this is a must-stop for us in order for them to get the whole SF experience. I like to start off with Twin Peaks (something easy since it's just on the other side of the Bay Bridge to downtown/Market St. (near Powell Street BART) to Twin Peaks. From there, Lombard Street (windy road) to Coit Tower, then wrap up with Pier 39, and the Golden Gate Bridge. 

Also for the locals, nice (albeit usually windy) date spot to hang out in seclusion! 

Tip: Looking for a place like this one in the East Bay Hills, try Grizzly Peak!
author: Charles K.

description: what can I say about a beautiful San Francisco what a great view have been there so many times even as a young teenager.but it can get very windy especially at night so make sure you bring a jacket
author: Lizzie G.

description:
Definitely a vista point worth checking out if you're in SF. We drove up here around 4:30PM mid-September. Sun was still up so we could see the magnificence of the city. It was a bit foggy at times, but there were a few minutes where it cleared up and we snapped away with our phones.

Parking is free. There's a good view right next to the parking lots, but going up the stairs on the other hill.. beside the parking lot is a fantastic view as well.

Tip - SO SO WINDY AND COLD, so bring a jacket or thick sweater. I knew SF was windy that you should dress in layers, but coming up here is next level. I was freezing my butt off and had to run back to my car and turn on the heated seat function in my car.
author: Yentl T.

description:
Back in high school, I came to Twin Peaks for the stunning "VIEWS". 

A decade later...

I STILL come to Twin Peaks for the stunning "VIEWS". 

Dad, Mom...if you happen to be reading this, "Hi!!! You should come to Twin Peaks for the stunning 'views' too." 

*BOW-CHICKA-BOW-WOW* VISUAL 

Ummm, on a second thought, PLEASE don't... :X
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I come here every time im in san Francisco, usually at night before we drive home, the view is breathtaking, You can see everything. At night the city looks so bright and magical. 

Bring a jacket the wind is usually very chilly.
author: Mmmber M.

description: My friends were helping me get through my SF bucket list.  I had a few items left from when I used to live in the bay area.  I didn't have Twin Peaks originally on my list but quickly added it when my friend suggested it.  Twin peaks is the best view.  You can see everything!  It was a clear night luckily so we had a good view and saw the golden gate and the bay bridges.  I saw tourists and a few couples there.  It was cute one guy had a girl blindfolded.  Im sure there are other beautiful spots in the bay area that are less crowded though.  Boys should take their girls elsewhere.  It's still cute to see but I wouldn't like to be around a crap load of people on a romantic date.
author: Chrissie O.

description:
Great location to watch the sunrise. So glad we woke up to see this!  This trip to San Francisco was all about experiencing the must see views and this is not one that should be missed. Be sure to get there on time to see not only the sun but the fog over the city as well. Such an amazing view!!  

Then be sure to stop at Zazie in Cole Valley as they have amazing breakfast (see my 5 star review on the cafe too).  

Also check out Lands End Trails for some great views and a nice day outside!
author: Julia V.

description:
Must see visit while in the Bay Area!

As other Yelpers have said, you get awesome views of the city.  A bit of a pain getting up to the top, in addition to fighting for a parking spot but otherwise worth the visit. 

Today was the perfect day to come up here. It was clear skies and fairly warm. Great day for pictures!

I'll definitely come back for another visit.  Maybe during sunset or late evening next time.
author: Christine G.

description:
I am so proud to be able to call San Francisco my home. WARNING: This will get sappy.

I have been all around the world, explored 23 countries and counting and still the view from the top of Twin Peaks takes my breath away every time. 

I am a born & raised Bay Area girl. Let me tell you, you cannot truly appreciate the immense beauty of the Bay Area until you see the entire span of it, (North, East, Peninsula, South, SF, and beyond) from the top of Twin Peaks on a clear day. The joy I get pinpointing locations and landmarks from the top is indescribable, but I will do my best.

Firstly, if you find yourself at the top of TP on a clear day, just know that the entire universe is on your side. In my opinion, prime time is just before sunset, when the skyline begins to dim and blush pink at the thought of what the night holds.

Google when sunset is for that day and arrive 20 minutes before so that you can also see in broad daylight. You will be able to see clear through to the Golden Gate and beyond unto the vast Pacific, up North to Sausalito and Tiburon where tiny yachts look like toys in a giant bath tub. San Rafael bridge is visible, the Bay Bridge, to the South, the San Mateo Bridge, if you can squint hard enough you'll also find the Martinez bridge towards the East. You can also spot Mt. Tam towards the North. To the west, Ocean beach looks like a dream especially when the fog starts to blanket Daly City. Towards the East I can pinpoint the location of my hometown, along the waters edge of San Pablo Bay. The entire East Bay sitting along a beautiful coastline. Farther out towards the East, on a clear enough day you can see Mt. Diablo. SF city looks timeless, it shines bright with hopes and dreams even before the sun completely sets. Don't even get me started on the views during actual sunset. I'll let you figure it out on your own.

When I want to feel and see how small I am as a human, I come up to TP. The view puts everything into perspective. Things just make sense up there, that maybe I can't normally think about at home in my cave of an apartment. Maybe it's the clean ocean breeze, higher levels of oxygen, or maybe it's just magic. I'd bet on the latter.

I love it! I know you will too. 

TIPS:
Be very careful driving up to TP, especially at night. Drive SLOW, people are often crossing the road up there because there isn't a true designated Pedestrian crosswalk which the city should really have put in by now. 
Go potty at home! 
Be courteous, don't ruin anyone's good time please.
Don't be silly, always bring a warm jacket, it may be 70 out and look clear in the valley, but on TP it's always chilly. 
The secret hill at the back of the viewing location is worth a hike up, especially before sunset. Be careful, don't slip, there is no true path except for wooden boards placed loosely in the dirt, and it's pretty steep!
author: Alexandra C.

description:
I really enjoy coming to Twin Peaks. Such a glorious view of SF, either on a clear, sunny day or during the evenings when all is dark but all the lights are aglow.

The crowds are different between the daytime and evenings. Most of my visits have been during the day, where you are one of many people camping up top to admire the view and take pictures. Despite all the people, it's still pretty tranquil at the peak. There is a smaller peak across the street, that has it's own pretty view at the top. Although I'd say it's the perfect place to get away from the crowds and have some alone time, there is a steady trickle of curious visitors that climb to the top of this secondary peak, ruining any chances of quiet solitude.

At night it's a bit different. Don't be surprised if you drive to the top, and upon stepping out, you run back in because it's super cold! (My friends and I did that once. We only had time to take a picture, before almost freezing to death :P ) On those not-too-cold nights, there is a smaller crowd of people admiring the view compared to the day crowd. One thing I don't like about being up here at night is that there is usually little pockets of people that are up there to smoke their weed, normally towards the southwestern side - creating sort of a dodgy atmosphere. :(

Overall, I will always return to Twin Peaks for a bit of solitude away from the hustle and bustle of downtown SF (one could say even that of life). It's a nice spot to enjoy a bit of quiet with friends or that special someone!
author: Kevin J.

description: Excellent view of SF Bay area. We went there on last day of 2015 and crowds were less. Police stopped cars from going to Christmas tree spot but we go parking on the streets going down. It was cold but not as windy as we had thought. The next time we go to this spot we would try to go in the morning to get a day view . Highly recommended.
author: Manoj N.

description:
This place is a hike up the San Francisco hills but totally worth it. Parking can be a pain but once your at the peak, it just rubs off and are amazement of wonder of ohh's and ahh's looking over this hilly city. 

Photographers are all over taking pictures from different angles and some people painting the San Francisco skyline was just breathtaking. 

Next time when I visit, I'm bringing some redwine with pate and crackers. Mmm
author: Paul B.

description:
One of the very few places to all of northern San Francisco and the Golden Gate from one spot, Twin Peaks is the pinnacle of sightseeing in San Francisco. This is where many people from everywhere stop by for photos, dates, views, or just enjoy a nice day out at one of the highest points of the city. During the daytime on a clear day, all landmarks of the northern part of San Francisco are seen along with possibly up to 4 bridges. During the evening on a clear night, the lights of The City illuminate the streets for spectacular photos opportunities.

There are 2 ways to get to Twin Peaks, from Diamond Heights (south) side or from the Clayton Street (north) side.  The parking lot is usually not full on days and nights, though we imagine that this place is usually full or closed on holidays such as 4th of July or evenings such as New Years Eve night.

A must-visit for tourist & a place the natives should visit every now and then.
author: Rob L.

description:
So you want to go to one of the most awe inspiring vistas over a major metropolitan city in the entire world and it just so happens  you are in SF and not Rio... well guess what! You my friend are in luck!

If you make your way up to the top of twin peaks next to the giant antenna structure, you will be given one of the most gorgeous views on the face of the earth IMHO...

after winding your way up the curvacious road to the summit you will roll up on a two tiered parking lot complete with pay binoculars. And over half of San Francisco and the rest of the bay area just about is laid out below you. 

The view of SF is like you are on a helicopter. This is one of those places you just have to experience to truly understand. So next time you are in the bay, take your booty up here and check out this special place... Just be careful not to take the express way down to Frisco! That would kinda hurt.

But the best thing about this place is that it is free, never closed, and sometimes you see some very interesting people.
author: Schel H.

description: Beautiful place to take in San Francisco in all its glory. I've come here twice, once by walking and once by driving. I'd recommend against the walking, since it's a pretty strenuous trek up the hill, and there isn't a pedestrian sidewalk. The view was gorgeous at night! We parked and as you're walking up to the railing, the entire sparkling landscape just unfolds in front of you, and it's breathtaking. I wish I'd had more than my amateurish iPhone camera to capture the view. Of course, when it's foggy or rainy, which the City tends to get, there isn't as much to see. Also, the wind up there is merciless, so layer up!
author: Sophie W.

description:
This is one of my top three places to be a tourist in SF.

I am a major fan of skylines and great views and Twin Peaks perfect combines both of these. It is such a great way to really distance yourself from DTSF and appreciate the full beauty of the city. My friends and I bought lunch at Ike's, drove ten minutes up to Twin Peaks, and ate our sandwiches while taking in the view. I have been here twice in the day, but I have heard the view at night is even better (how is that possible?!). I WILL be coming through at night in the future.

Parking:
-I have never had a problem with parking here because there is an ample amount of street and lot parking at this site. I have come on both a Saturday and a Sunday.

To everyone even considering going here...do it! This is a decision you will not regret, I promise :)
author: Maria V.

description: Absolutely stunning views of the city. Be prepared for extreme wind. This is a must stop for people visiting the Bay area!
author: Courtney M.

description:
Went at night and it was super windy, cold, and not entirely worth the scary-narrow drive up.

Cool to be able to see all of SF though
author: Kathy W.

description:
As long as you have expectations in check, this is a great short weekend activity. This isn't a peak where you'll get a meaty nature hike in, but rather one to take in a near perfect view of SF. It's easy to access directly via car or you can walk up along the winding road as well. Note that if you decide to drive up, where you will park isn't really on the "Twin Peaks" it's another peak'ish hill that also provides really great views. So if all you want is a view, you can literally drive up, park, look around, take pictures, and leave. 

The actual Twin Peaks are right next to that hill. So you'll have to ascend that hill, and ascend up to the Twin Peak right next to it. The actual Twin Peaks have large wooden steps, so it's not bad at all, and probably safe for a late-elementary aged child. Like other Yelpers mentioned, it can get pretty windy and chilly on the peak, so do pack a light jacket.
author: Steve T.

description: This place is beautiful . Amazing view of the whole city . Come during the week since parking is limited.
author: Natalie M.

description: Beautiful view, but very chilly at night. Make sure to bring a sweater. View is better during the day.
author: Fernilla S.

description: BEST view of San Francisco!!! You can see the whole city from up here!!! Favorite place to admire this beautiful city and take it all in.  We biked/hiked up here from downtown, taking Market then 17th all the way up to Twin Peaks Blvd.  It was so worth it to share with my hubby the great beauty of San Francisco!!
author: Rosie M.

description:
This was my fourth visit to SF and Twin Peaks had always been on my list.  However, I've come to find out that summer is the foggiest time in SF and this day was particularly summery.  I would not be deterred, however, and I pushed my companions onto the bus which wove its way up from around Mission Dolores up the hill.

I'm told that the view up here is magnificent, but the day I went was shrouded in fog.  It's still haunting in its own way.  You could quite easily be wandering with Heathcliff in a Bronte novel.  Someone who has the luxury of living here should come up when it's perfect.  The rest of us visiting types will just have to cross our fingers on the weekend we visit :-)
author: Stephen H.

description:
Be careful driving up. The roads are fun and seem like good drifting places but don't risk it.

Once you get to the top, you will appreciate the city and the beautiful lights a lot. At the same time, you will appreciate the warmth of your car a lot. It's super cold and windy up there to the maximum.

Make sure you go on a clear night. That should be a given.
author: Sofia R.

description: This is a MUST SEE. Twin peaks is easy to find and commute to. You can see the entire city on a clear day. It is nothing short of a breathtaking view!
author: WesleyandJessica R.

description: Heard a lot about this place and it's simply amazing!! sometimes going alone to this place is the best thing to reflect things and have your personal time !!
author: Krishna V.

description: I've never seen such a beautiful sunset. Me and the bf really enjoyed watching the sunset here. The view is one like no other. The whole city in site.
author: Cassie S.

description:
I hurt myself pretty badly while walking down a wooden staircase built into a hill.  Is this unfair to judge Twin Peaks for that?  Maybe.  But whachagonnado Twin Peaks?  Sue me?  Will the owner of Twin Peaks send me an angry private message?  Bring it!  Lol.  

The view was good, but it was at night.  Some of the houses looked cute as dickens.
author: Bill V.

description: If you want great views, you'll need to dress warmly and head to twin peaks where you can see the entire city of San Francisco. There's two peaks, but there's actually one where you can see the views from. The other peak doesn't really have paved roads to walk up and I don't think they have the telescopes either. There is free parking when you get to the top of the peak, but can be difficult during popular hours. Its really hit or miss in terms of the view. You won't be able to see much on foggy days. Even on sunny days (when we went) the fog started to roll in as the evening progressed.  Doesn't hurt to try your luck by visiting here anyways!  Remember to bring a warm jacket and a hat and earmuffs! Its windy and cold!
author: Janet E.

description:
This should be a must for anyone visiting San Francisco. I recently came up here with my boyfriend for the first time with some of his friends. What the heck! How I had never been up here I am not sure. Make sure to bring a warm jacket, it's SO windy, a camera and a beer. Er...I mean a water bottle....

As we leaned up against the walls, we couldn't help but gasp because of the breathtaking views. I would love to come up here and have a picnic sometime on a warmer day. You can see literally everything in the Bay Area from up here. It's a truly amazing spot.
author: Issy D.

description: You can actually see all San Fransisco from up here. Very nice there is a lot of parking.Great place to take pictures
author: Migdalia V.

description: Very relaxing and beautiful. Just went there recently with my hubby and son. It was so foggy and windy but loved it... Can't wait to go back in summer to see beautiful view...
author: Kristy K.

description: This is the perfect hike if you're looking for quick, easy, and scenic. Once you're at the top, you can see the most amazing 360 degree view of the city from both peaks. I highly recommend that everyone try this at least once!
author: Jamie T.

description:
Twin peaks is amazing. I can't stress enough why this needs to be on your bucket list. I'm suppose to be doing my homework right now but am now sidetracked by the memory of this mesmerizing view. 

I came here one morning after dropping off my boyfriend and getting some Philz Coffee. I needed a place to chill and expand my peripheral vision as they haven't been exploring enough. The view was foggy but I had time to kill which with that eventually the fog lifted and then came the beautiful city and all of the bay area, I came here by myself, which gave me a peace of mind. Surprisingly they at WIFI, whaaat. You know what that means, homework time . After chilllin for a couple hours, "duty called" and I had to leave for work.

This place is great whether your alone, with a companion or a group of friends and family. It's definitely a view to see and a great drive up. They have telescopes so if you want to take a peak at some fine citizens of SF you can do that. I'm sure they have restrooms.
author: L T.

description:
San Francisco's best and FREE observatory that will allow you to see all the way from the Golden Gate Bridge to the Bay Bridge. You gotta time it right though--if you catch it on a clear day/night, then it will be nothing short of spectacular. If you catch it when it's foggy (which it is about 80% of the time), then all you will see is fog. Literally, you will see nothing but fog. 

So check your weather and come here. Despite how cliche it is, it's still worth the trip
author: Diana Y.

description:
Spectacular view!!! Whether it's your first time in San Francisco, CA or you're a SF Native stop by this peak. Take photos. Bring friends. Have lunch. 
Just an overall great place to be at. 

Make sure to get away from the main tourist "Kodak photo" place and head out to the peaks, there are two! Hence twin peaks. Get up there and you can see 360 degree view of this beautiful city!! 

Also great times are sunrises!! Or really foggy days, you can literally be above the clouds! Have fun!!
author: Ruth Awit S.

description: Beautiful, beautiful views of the entire city. The only downside is that you will be sharing this amazing view with many other people, as this place is one of the most popular tourist destinations in San Francisco. However, you are still able to appreciate the beauty of the city. The views at night are even more breathtaking! Be sure to bring some sort of cover up - it gets windy up here!
author: Ally M.

description: Since childhood, I have had the pleasure of viewing the city from this great location. It never gets old and I love bringing visiting friends and family here. You feel as though you are on top of the universe when looking out around you. The city lights are gorgeous at night and a great end to a date. (That's for the guys out there). During the day, the views of the city towards the bay bridge to the east and golden gate to west are unparalleled. On a clear day, you can see clearly into San Rafael to the north and deep into the peninsula. The road is a bit windy as you travel up the mountain. Be careful of opposing drivers flying down the mountain. I suggest going up through sunset district and coming down into the haight and ashbury area. Both neighborhoods are great for sight-seeing. Always bring a coat. It's never a warm day at twin peaks.
author: Ramla J.

description: this is such a gorgeous spot to not only get a perfect view of the city, but to also watch the sunset! I would highly recommend that you coordinate your evening to this location :)
author: Brooke W.
