description: Unlike going into the eiffle tower, or the space needle, you can come to Twin Peaks and see the whole view of San Francisco for free! It's a great date place and definitely a photo spot. The view is amazing. You can see the golden gate bridge, city hall, alcatraz, the embaracdero, and much more.
author: Mimi V.

description: Almost always crowded with people, but if it's a clear day, you see everything in the city! Great place to get an awesome panaromic picture.
author: Fiana L.

description:
On a clear SF day this place offers a view that seems surreal. You can see the whole city, the bay, the other side of the bay, I think I saw Apple Headquarters, and the White House, and the Taj Mahal....okay perhaps not all that, but you can see for miles on end in every direction. 

This is a great place to take a run up to as well. Good incline but not too hard. And its free.
author: Luis D.

description: Cool spot, but often super windy and shrouded in fog. That said, on a sunny clear day it's a pretty amazing view of San Francisco. It's especially cool seeing straight down Market St.
author: Madhu P.

description:
Gorgeous views. Very windy. The stairs leading up the peak are not great so wear good walking shoes and be ready to rough it a little. 

Need to get there by car as there doesn't seem to be good transit options there.
author: Charles S.

description:
Twin Peaks... I'd heard of it a couple of years ago when I first moved to the Bay Area but didn't make it up there until recently.  Lemme say... it was amazing.  The breathtaking peaceful views should make it a destination for any couple that is lazing around looking for something to do on a clear night.  I can't wait until my next set of friends or family visit and I get to take them up there.  They'll be blown away I'm sure.  

I went at night but maybe it's nice during the day too?

See ya there!
author: Susan D.

description: Super busy but incredible view! Easy to get to and parking wasn't a problem.
author: Mariah C.

description: The view from up there is amazing, beautiful, breathtaking, and just spectacular.  I've always been of fan of this place but I've always visited during night so I have no idea what chaos there is during the day time in regards to tourists and annoying "hyphy" kids.  But I can say is the best time to visit is probably between the hours of 1-6 a.m..  The night shot is fanatic with little to no disturbance from onlookers and the sunrise is great to catch here too.
author: Lea M.

description: This place has an amazing panoramic view of the city. The only issue was that when we got there, it was SUPER windy and chilly! All of the tourists there looked oh so cold. There were two one person toilets there but only one working one- which always had a line. I don't have much else to say but I would definitely come back here again to look at the view- even though it's a short visit- you kind of just look at it and take pictures for 10 minutes and then leave. No one stayed there and just chilled- maybe because it was super windy and cold. I would recommend at least checking it out once! It's also located near some nice looking neighborhoods if you're interested in driving around and looking at those.
author: Shin M.

description:
Twin Peaks is a must for locals and visitors to San Francisco. I lived in the Bay Area waaaay too long and didn't know about this impressive vista point!

Each and every time I visit I'm awed and astounded by the perspective laid out for your eyes. The clear view all the way down Market St. to the Ferry Building is one of my favorites.

If you've never been, don't wait for a tourist to come into town to make the trek up. Do yourself a favor and soak in the view. You'll thank yourself!
author: Greg S.

description: Amazing views and easy drive up. Lots of parking. A must see place sunrise, morning, afternoon, night, sunset. Bring a jacket cause it's freezing. Don't leave valuables in the car!!! A lot of break ins but smart robbers.
author: TravelingHungry ..

description:
A complete view of the city, a must see spot for tourists and locals as it is easy to get to, and free of charge. Parking was no problem on a weekday.

 I've heard it could be completely foggy, but it was extremely clear when I went. It does get windy up there so have a jacket.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Okay....since my move to California, on average, I have been to San Francisco at least once a year.... and WTH....I have never ever been to Twin Peaks....like OMG!?!?

I came here after dinner with my Bay area family and SURPRISE...it was also a first for two of my other family members....YAY!

Okay....this is San Francisco, be forewarned, I came here at night, it is cool, if not downright cold for most. Bring something warm to wear.

Also another warning, this is a tourist spot and parking can be challenging at any time of day.

Another interesting, but FUNNY story while I was there....someone got locked in the automated bathroom. Addendum....to use the bathroom, you have to pay with your credit card....LOL! Go there to see this bathroom, although I have heard of them in New York Central Park, it is the first I have seen on the West Coast.

OKAY OKAY...but on to the reason you come to Twin Peaks, you come here for the AMAZING view - HANDS DOWN!

Bring your camera and tripod for long exposure night photography....I did (see my photos)....I want to come back during the day!

Five Yelp Stars....everybody who visits the Bay area should see this view!!
author: Albert E.

description: This is definitely one of my favorite destinations in San Francisco, CA. Until my next adventure... Miss breathing in the cool foggy mist...I bid adieu.
author: Chris G.

description:
Gee what can I say thats probably already been said. Great views, day and night.
Lots of tour buses go through there.

Watch fireworks here on July 4 or New Years and this place is crazy packed. Cars parked all over the sides of the road. The winding road you gotta be careful if its foggy and the only reason you go there when its foggy is too...............
author: T C.

description: This is by the the most breath taking city view I've seen so far. This beats any la city view I've seen. It's quite cold up here however it is definitely worth the shivers.
author: Brian C.

description: Gorgeous views on a beautiful sunny day in SF...twin peaks gets crowded but everyone can agree on the spectacular view of the city! I can only imagine how pretty it would look at dusk with all the twinkling lights below. It's a bit of a drive to get to the top and you do need to be patient about parking, but we managed to find it pretty easily. I'm sure different weather makes it feel different too, but without fog, the view is stunning on a clear summer day. There is still wind...there must always be wind, but on a summer afternoon like last weekend (temps in high 60s-70s), the wind wasn't that bad. I was all prepared for a raging wind storm based on all these reviews, but didn't need my North Face jacket at all. There's another hill you can climb up for another view, but personally, I think the view right outside the parking lot is already fantastic enough. Bring some good company and time to relax here a bit!
author: Jasmine C.

description:
Lived here 1975-82, Twin Peaks was a must see a few times a month.
Visited a few weeks ago, was UN-impressed with the swarms of selfie-taking- tourists and plumes of TRASH and GARBAGE blowing everywhere.
What a sad disappointing reunion with a formerly pristine site!
author: Richard C.

description:
fantastic view of SF from here. 
you can either take a hike across from twin peaks highway, drive up from twin peaks highway, or walk straight up. there are two peaks. most people stay on peak #1 (highest), but there is a 2nd peak a few steps away.

very easy hike with rewarding views. be careful to watch for tour buses and cars as many speed along the curvy road up.
author: Mimi C.

description:
Who Killed Laura Palmer? Sorry, wrong Twin Peaks!

I often take the Bay Area for granted. Out-of-Town friends will ask me how often I come into San Francisco and are surprised when I indicate that it's not very often. First, there's lots of things to see all over Northern California, but it's more likely that between work, Gayle, and the Kid, I'm just too busy to go many place very often. 

Twin Peaks is a place that I go to remind me of what I'm missing by not paying greater attention to my good fortune. And since it's at the geographical center of San Francisco, I can see where I'm going next to almost any point within this City by the Bay. It's a beautiful perch for what might arguably be the most stunning views of San Francisco (day or night). However, the fog, wind and cold (depending what side you're on) require layers. 

When I'm done, might find me down in the West Portal neighbourhod. That would be me at the Manor Coffee Shop enjoying a slice of cherry pie with my Agent Cooper-like friends.
author: Eric B.

description: My favorite local spot. Bring a jacket it gets chilly up there!!
author: Kylie M.

description:
So foggy tonight! Always lots of people, but I always love the view here.

My little piece of heaven! I love love the view ;)
They recently added a bathroom which is AWESOME! It gets cold so bring a blanket & someone to cuddle up with! Amazing view of the cities and some nights, if you're lucky, you'll catch some fireworks. It tends to get crowded there on weekends so you might want to go earlier to get a spot.
author: Mim D.

description:
Nice Views. I wish it can be better but no. Driving up here is fun. 
See the city and its traffic and lights. Its nice.
Don't come when its foggy. Easy.
author: Sunny L.

description:
Decided to be touristy for the day since it had been years since I had been up there.
All tourists visiting SF need to add Twin Peaks to their itinerary!

The day was perfect - weather was beautiful, warm, not breezy, air was refreshing, the sun was shining and I could actually see the GGB and BB!  I was able to point out Market Street, the ballpark, etc.

There was a small crowd of people, a few joggers as well, and some climbing up the peaks itself.  It's fairly easy to get to, plenty of parking also.
author: Donna F.

description:
One of the best views of the city and one of the most breath taking views I've ever seen! 

After shopping a whole day on Haight St a local told us to make sure we check out "Twin Peaks" for it's spectacular view. We inputted into our gps on our phone and car and headed there later that night. The drive there was all twist and turns going up the mountain....it reminded me of the drive up to Kokee on Kauai. It was a lot more fun going down the mountain than it was going up...but the drive up wasn't very long. 

When we got to the top, parking was hard to find because it seemed like everyone knew about the place and wanted a glimpse of it just as much as we did. The view which overlooked San Francisco and the rest of the bay it was just beyond belief BREATH TAKING! Luckily when we went up it was so beautiful out with no vog and it was at night with crystal clear skies which was perfect for picture taking with all the city's light lid up. 

Although, even with the spectacular view it does get windy and cold up so we could only stay there for about 30 minutes max without freezing our bunz off! So be sure to bring your camera for all the views and do bring a jacket and even a blanket if you must!
author: Raych D.

description: Twin Peaks - If you have not been - This is a must see for the REAL overview of the city and county of San Francisco. On a clear day it is a jaw dropping panorama. On a foggy day, it is an incredible overlook. The view speaks for itself, and it is top flight!  Be sure to use the oh so amusing toilets. You will think you just entered the Tardis and Dr. Who will be there with you!
author: Charley C.

description:
If you're in the Haight street area, you NEED to come here. Even on the gloomiest of days you can still get a pretty view of the city, the wharf, even the golden gate bridge. Parking sometimes sucks but there's plenty of room to get a good view of the city once you find a spot to park. 

If you're not in the area though, traffic and distance could make it a 20-40 minute drive out. So plan accordingly so you aren't traveling back and forth around the San Fran.
author: Niko D.

description:
It is one of the must go places for tourist. Every time when we have friends visiting, this place always impress them. 
Parking hasn't been a problem for the few times I have been there.
author: Anonymous R.

description: Came here with my boyfriend on a clear summer night. So beautiful I almost cried. Bring a jacket.
author: Lee A.

description:
The view is spectacular but minus 2 stars for:
-the number of tourists who frequent here and ruin your perfect photos
-the annoying tour buses who block the roads leading up to here
-the terrible parking/driving habits of the above mentioned tourists

If you want better views with fewer tourists and easier parking then go to Mt Davidson or Corona Heights Park.
author: E E.

description:
Almost froze my face off hiking up here! But was it worth it? I definitely need to come back after sunset! 
The hike itself (starting from Market and Castro street) winded through unique neighbors and took us up funky stairs and that was the cool part for me. 
Bring a windbreaker!!
author: Kalong W.

description:
I like it here. The people are nice (workers and patrons). I like the location (right on Castro & Market) with lots of windows. Plus, it makes me feel a little classy. :)

I don't go often, but when I have, I have really enjoyed it.
author: Jason B.

description:
BEAUTIFUL VIEW of the city lights at night. It gets quite windy up there, so bring a jacket! There's no other view like it. I can't believe I've lived in the Bay Area all my life and I just recently went up to Twin Peaks.

For those of you on a date, it is a romantic place! Cozy up next to each other and take in the spectacular view.
author: Leana L.

description: I love going up here on a clear day. Awesome views. Once we drove up here,  we saw nothing but clouds.
author: Darija D.

description: Beautiful vista point! You gotta check it out when your in San Fran. Complete panoramic view of the city. Lots of free parking but very busy with tourist. I would love to check it out during a sunset or when its almost dark.
author: A H.

description:
Very Nice place 
You can see sunset view and Golden gate and Bay bridge view also must bring camera
author: Mike K.

description: Such a panoramic view of SF & East Bay. Everything below looks sooo freakin small. Came here shoot a few shots for my friend for some nice portraits. Always heard about this place, & I'm glad I got to finally see it for myself. :)
author: Amy C.

description:
This is THE PLACE to go when visiting San Francisco. 

We walked up here in the dark, which was a terrifying and frustrating experience, so if you must, maybe walk in the daytime and wear appropriate hiking footwear. 

The view is amazing. So many sparkles and sights to take in! 

There were raccoons and stoners all over the place when we went. Both entertaining additions to this otherwise serene spot. 

FREE!

There's really no reason not to go when in town!
author: Kaitlin D.

description:
I can't believe of all the times I was in the bay area, I did not once stop by Twin Peaks to check out how beautiful it is!! SHAME ON ME!

You get the whole 360 degree view of SAN FRANCISCO, where most people leave their heart at...it's drop dead gorgeous yo!!! Breathtaking view! Bay people are definitely some lucky folks, esp with Ike in town too!??!

Parking is free and pretty much at one point, people just made up their own parking lot, HA!

It was quite a drive going up but nothing dramatic. Just watch out for pedestrians since they do walk all the way up from the bottom. 

This IS the place you want to be up there at night time....but it's nice at day time too!

I WILL COME BACK FOR YOU TWIN PEAKS! LOVEEE.
author: Phung D.

description:
Beautiful 360 panorama view of SF (heart)
But, bundle up 'cause it's "hella cold" oh, and say hi to Karl the fog!
author: Anne H.

description:
Absolutely one of the top places to be at when at San Francisco (either visiting or living). The view is great either in the daytime or at night, and it's remarkable how much you can see and how beautiful the City looks from this vantage point.

Free parking! Bring a light jacket for afternoon and many more layers if going at night.
author: Jason T.

description: I have enjoyed visiting Twin Peaks and checking out the beautiful views of San Francisco. I really recommend this to locals and visitors.
author: Denise C.

description:
One of the best spots in SF to enjoy the view of the entire city and catch a breath of fresh (sometimes cold) air! Day or night, it's absolutely gorgeous.

I've been up here as a kid whenever our family made a trip to the bay, and now as an adult to take a moment to relax and appreciate life's simplest things.

I'd recommend going on a day when the sky is clear. There are times when it can get so foggy you can barely see whats in front of you. Oh and always, always, bring a jacket just in case it gets cold! The wind can make a lot of difference even though it's sunny.
author: Loriel L.

description: Worth stopping by to check it out but just be advised that it's extremely windy and foggy when you're at this altitude.
author: Steven W.

description: Love going here with friends to hangout and spend great memories :) It always a good place to sit and look down at the city and is still fun when foggy, you feel like youre sitting on a cloud lol
author: Seutatia F.

description: Luckily we were able to go here on a clear night.  Beautiful panoramic views of the city - you can see all the bridges at once.  I'm a sucker for city lights like a moth drawn to a flame.  Every time I visit a city, I always try to climb up a high point somewhere and take in the views.  Although quiet and serene, i feel that there is always a certain kind of energy that is given off in city lights.  And at Twin Peaks the view definitely supports that ideology.  Long story short...just come visit!  The view is breathtaking and fabulous!  :)
author: Theresa N.

description:
easy to get to by public transportation if you are okay with walking uphill for a little while

good spot to bring a date

came during the day and it was magnificent, great views and it was sunny with great views of san francisco, you can see the Bay Bridge and the Golden Gate bridge

extremely windy when i came up here in late April, i thought i was gonna be blown away, so watch out skinny people, grab on to something, its really that windy

would like to come back here at night, but if you do, i recommend driving because it is quite a quiet neighborhood
author: Bakchun K.

description: What can I say that everyone else hasn't already? Yes, this has to be one of the best views of San Francisco. You can clearly see how Market St bisects the city. It's fun to point out areas you and your friends know. You can also see across the the East Bay. I actually TRIED jogging here with a friend who had way more stamina and made it up the hill non-stop. I, on the other hand, had to walk and catch my breath. It is a steep incline but so worth the view. Make sure you wear a jacket or pull over because if you're sweaty as your loved ones say "ya might catch a cold." It can get a bit windy. This is a landmark of the city by the bay...
author: Marty J.

description: Parking on weekends is a pain because there are lots of tourist.  View is great.  Very windy and short hike option only.
author: Tashie P.

description:
I play tour guide to 2-4 peeps a month, and whenever I can, I take them here for the view whether morning or night. Just such a great place. Most sight seers only see downtown or the Wharf or Golden Gate and get such a limited view of San Fran. Taking them to Twin Peaks really makes them at a loss for words while they take in the sights. 

A few notes on visiting:
- Can be hella crowded on weekends or during the day. You can always park around the corner.
- There's a bathroom there.
- Once I saw a huge raccoon exploring the trash bins. It was bothering anyone, but I was amazed to see it so confidently go into the trash without any fear of the tourists around.
- The weather is constantly changing. Bring a jacket or a windbreaker. Maybe skip the view if it's a crazy foggy day, but even those days can feel like you are standing in a cloud.
- Late at night, there's sometimes locals who are 420 friendly or dinking. Just move on.
- If you are driving, don't park in the tourist bus spots. I saw cars getting ticketed.
author: Paul F.

description: Always wanted to see Twin Peaks so I got my lazy self up started the car and headed straight there. I had to pick the coldest day smh..i almost turned around after seeing what seem like a impossible hill to drive (17th st) oh yeah dosent help that my car is a manuel and everybody is trying to get to work or dropping the kids to school. After burning my clutch I managed to get pass that nightmare. It was an uphill climb and slowly you can feel that your getting near the twist and turn the road makes I get the the top. Wow what a view you can see pretty much everything from the Golden Gate Bridge to the Bay bridge even the east bay. It's Instagram heaven, panoramic view Allday. Bring your friends and girlfriend and post the views it's an automatic like. Come through it's literally breath taking.
author: Timothy E.

description: So excited to finally make it to the Twin Peaks. I've heard about them ever since moving here, but never made it up. There are several city streets that lead up to the Twin Peaks if you are interested in making it an extra long hike. Or you can drive up to the top, park and do the stairs to the top of the peaks. The steps to the tops of the Peaks are quite treacherous, but very doable. The vantage point is simply stunning. On a clear day you can see everything: Alcatraz, the Golden Gate Bridge, downtown, Market Street, and all of the windy streets.
author: Kari G.

description:
SF is such a beautiful city. There are many landmarks were you can can an awesome video fo the city but Twin Peaks I would have to say is one of my favorite.

To some people this place might be pretty ghetto since a bunch of people drive up chill and drink up there.

But don't mind them haha they're there the same reason you are to relax and enjoy the view. Whether night or day this spot is dope easy to find, look up and go towards the big electrical towers on the mountain. 

Bring warm clothing in time of the day since its at the top of the mountain it gets hella cold. All times I've been here we've just stayed up there chopped it up and took a lot of photos of the city. 

There are some days where there are just a bunch of people there but it's not like you'll get a ticket for parking in an area that's not a parking spot. (Then again I don't advise that, I don't want to be the person responsible for you getting a ticket lol).

Night or day this place is the spot to catch the beauty of SF from above.
author: Steph S.

description:
Twin Peaks, oh Twin Peaks.

I first came here about 2 years ago in the night time and the scenery is absolutely amazing here.

The view, the lights, and the people that come up to see Twin Peaks. Bring a jacket when you go up there because it definitely gets cold from the elevation. Haven't come up here during the day, but I'll check it out soon.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
Quite possibly the best view of the entire city of SF.

I wish I would have had more time to explore the actual peaks and climb up them, but alas I went with a tour group that only gave us about 10 minutes to stop and take pictures. BUT the next time, I now know about this place and will make the effort to visit here and spend more time exploring what twin peaks has to offer.
author: Rasien I.

description:
One day I was in the city driving around just seeing the different neighborhoods and trying to get a feel for the place.  I drove all over the damn city.  I went to SEE in Cow Hollow or some place with a ridiculous name.  I drove around the Presidio, Golden Gate Park, along the ocean, the Richmond district, the Castro and more.  Eventually, I encountered a sign that said "Twin Peaks" with an arrow.  I didn't know what Twin Peaks was so I followed the arrow and ended up on a mountain.

Twin Peaks are two peaks of about the same height in the southern part of San Francisco.  You can take a steep drive up to the top where there is a parking lot and a great view.  You can also walk up the hill like I saw some people doing but I think I would die if I tried that.  

The top is very touristy but the view is amazing.  All of San Francisco is sprawled out in front of you.  You can see the ocean, the bay, the bridge, the downtown, the hills.  It's truly a great view of the city.  You'll find many people who think the same so it's hardly a refuge from the city.  The place is pretty busy and parking is limited.  I'm sure that certain times and certain days are better to visit.

Many cities have a large skyscraper or tower to view the city (Sears Tower, Empire State Building, CN Tower, etc.)  In San Francisco it's fitting that one of the highest and best views is a hill.
author: Ryan L.

description:
A cool place to visit when in SF.  Whenever we're showing friends or family San Francisco, we always make sure to take them here to Twin Peaks.

It can get really cold and windy up there, but on a clear day or clear night the views are so worth it.

Make sure to bring your camera!  It's one of the best free attractions that can be visited in San Francisco!
author: PatrickJ T.

description:
This is definitely one of those places that I imagine lots of kids "parked" at in the 50s...


...and still do apparently judging by how many dark cars were up there at 2 am on a Friday night.

Twin Peaks was the very first thing I was taken to as soon as I landed in San Francisco in the afternoon. The Fog was at bay and the view was epic. Every visible landmark was pointed out to me from up here and I was in awe. They say first impressions last a lifetime. Well, I'm quite impressed Fran.

Almost every night I was in SF, Bianca L. and I would drive up to Twin Peaks to try and see the city. I'd say 3 out of 4 times the view was enveloped with the Fog but it was still fun to try. One of those nights a raccoon actually charged us which sent us squealing back into the safety of her car.

Bring a sweatshirt. Or a Tauntaun. It's absolutely freezing up there.
author: Leslie D.

description:
As the highest point in SF, the views are spectacular! One can literally see everywhere from Ocean Beach to the Golden Gate Bridge, to downtown SF, to the Bay Bridge, to SOMA, the Mission and Southern districts. It can be foggy at times and it limits the view.

The sunset is equally amazing and at night one can see the city literally light up. The church at USF is illuminated and you can see all the way down Market Street to the Ferry Building.

At late nights after midnight there are people who smoke weed but it's not bothersome at all. 

Definitely a must go to spot for tourists and photographers.
author: Thomas B.

description: A must go to place if you're visiting SF. The view from here is so beautiful but cold so bring a sweater. Also not fun when it's foggy:/ but it's nice to hike here
author: Yumi K.

description:
The only people I could ever understand to not like this place are the residents who live in the cramped areas you have to drive through to get here. I'm sure there are plenty of tourists flying through their back yards in circles figuring out how to get to the top!

Otherwise, what's not to like? Spectacular views, all without a cover charge! There could be better walking paths and such, but that's not really a fault of this place. Go during the day to see everything there is to see in the city and surrounding, on occasion, there is no fog and you can even see across the bay and the bridges. Go at night to see a star field of lights that seemingly fell from the sky.
author: Kurt C.

description:
Captivating views.

Twin Peaks is ratchet. If I'm not up there being a hoodrat, there are a plethora of other mf's doing hoodrat things with their friends. 

It's entertaining. Everyone just wants to look at the city lights - whether it's with a blunt in your hand, your hand on your boo's ass, drinking in the car or hanging out the car playing the SF anthem. 

Shit gets real up here tho, so don't get cray.
author: Lydia L.

description:
I've had Twin Peaks on my bucket list for several years and I finally had a great day to just do it.   I started out on the # 37 bus but decided to hike about 1/2 way up, so I exited at an early stop.   After a hike up several roadways and then thru 2 or 3  steep ascending staircases between the housing units, I arrived at trail pointers for the final ascent to both peaks. Hint, this trail pointer is right behind the last housing complex next to the peaks - call it a mid-way point which ends on a the winding figure 8 road and yes you have to hop over a concrete barrier placed there to keep the cars on the road.    

The stairs are stone and gravel and the ascent is not for those out of shape or with medical conditions.  There is an observation area at the base of the peaks which has limited parking.   While I was there at least 1 tourist bus arrived but since I arrived early on a Tuesday, I avoided most of the crowds which is rare.  Once you reach the base, there are winding / ascending stairs to the top of each peak via  two sides of the each peak.  

Once you reach the top, sit and be awed by the views.  Luckily, for me, it was a crystal clear day and the wind was not too bad.  I can understand how that can change rapidly.  I advise bringing a coat, dressing appropriately and wear sunscreen.  At night, I'm sure it is COLD.  I spent an hour on each peak, from about midday until well after 14:00.  I was mostly alone, enjoying the solitude with only a few other visitors.  It was peaceful to just be taking photos and appreciating the awesome views, rugged terrain, and wind whipping across the tops.   I really did not want to come down but my hunger from the hike won out. 

Upon descent, the stairs are still rocky so watch your footing.  Appropriate foot ware is advisable for hiking.  At night, the footing can be treacherous and I suspect hand held lighting is required as I saw no other major illumination.  

Yes, there is one restroom, located at the base of 1 peak, so as others have said, you should go beforehand if possible.  

I also decided to hike all the way back down to Market and was treated with some really nice views while walking thru these gorgeous neighborhoods. Near the end of my hike down was this awesome spiral ramp twisting down the next level - not expected.  

While I'm not sure how far the # 37 bus goes or where exactly it stops. I recommend finding out and visiting Twin Peaks if possible - especially on a clear day.  Remember to dress appropriately and mind your footing and you will be rewarded with views not available elsewhere.  I plan to return for a dusk or night view sometime as I image seeing the city light up as the sun sets is a wonderful transition to capture.  Cheers.
author: G M.

description: The view from up here of the city is gorgeous. It is a hit or miss depending on the weather. If there's fog, you won't see anything at all and it is not worth the drive up. Last weekend I took my fiancé and his brother at night. It was sprinkling just a little bit and then came the rain shortly after we left Twin Peaks. We got lucky because the visibility from atop was perfect and we were able to take in amazing panoramic views of the city lights. Though faraway, you can even see the Bay Lights (fine arts light show) on the Bay Bridge from Twin Peaks. It was so awesome!
author: Michelle T.

description:
Gor-geous. We'd come on one of the clearest days and were struck with awe at all that we could see. This Bay Area of ours is beautiful and to be able to share it with others is true delight. 

Careful on the drive up.
author: Loli L.

description:
Taylor Swift likes fairytales. She also likes magic, romance, and swooning. I think my experience here is one which Taylor Swift would envy. In other words, Taylor Swift would have soooo killed to be me (:

They say a picture is worth a thousand words. Well, I think an experience is worth a million. Because I know my review would not be able to capture the moment I'd like to share, I suggest you see it for yourself. Glittering city lights hovering in darkness with the patches of fog fitting together like pieces of a puzzle. Everybody hates fog when it comes to sightseeing, but this is picture can not be complete without: the picture of San Francisco.

I was shivering cold with warmth in my arms, a bit hungry.

The wide ramp below was perfect for drifting, as I had Initial D playing in my mind. I'm going to add that to my bucket list: drift at Twin Peaks.

My new amigo and I will be stealing a boat someday. If you like boats, you'll enjoy swooning from afar as you scan the city lights for ships (all ready for the taking!).

This is my runner-up spot behind Treasure Island. Plus, you don't have the toxic chemicals floating around in the air.

P.S: When I become homeless, I'll be chilling out here. Make sure to bring me lots of quarters! I'll be holding a sign saying, "Family has been killed by ninjas, need money for Kung-Fu lessons."

P.P.S: The road to get up here is like driving on Marsh Rd.
author: Elaine N.

description:
The girlfriend's father flew in from San Diego, so we were off & running on a frenetic weekend NorCal sightseeing spree.

With a number of sights all around the City already seen, it was time to punctuate the sentence of our day with an exclamation point. We drove up to Twin Peaks. Up at the vista overlooking the City, there's a decent amount of parking & we easily found a space.

On a sunny & crystal clear evening, it was blustery & cold. It mattered not. The view of the City from atop Twin Peaks is magnificent & not to be missed. Undoubtedly, the single best view in all of San Francisco.

We flirted with hypothermia long enough to be amazed by how much we could see from our lofty vantage point & then returned to the warm confines of the car. Daylight was retreating & our 1 day tour of San Francisco was just about complete.

It's always good to finish strong & going up to Twin Peaks is a strong finish to any day in San Francisco.
author: John M.

description: I may be biased, but we stayed in Twin Peaks while we were visiting so this was right out our front door. I think the rating isn't as high because you will really have to put some effort into getting to the top which can certainly deter anyone. It's also quite foggy, sometimes throughout the entire day depending on the wind. It is worth it though because you'll feel accomplished when you make it to the top and see possibly the best view of the entire city. The first time we went up my girlfriend cursed me out because it was pea soup at the top, but the next morning it was clear and all was forgiven.
author: Joshua C.

description:
Beautiful view. Probably even better at night or a sunny day. The weather is definitely colder up there so be sure to wear layers.

May be difficult to navigate to but as long as you're heading towards the Radio Tower you're heading in the right direction.

A must-see for anyone visiting the City!
author: Kathy W.

description:
July 4th fireworks, 360 degree view of fireworks all around, sunset, gorgeous.
Although, on Independence Day, Parking was prohibited going uphill. So my boyfriend and I had to hike up the hill for let's say 20 minutes? So dont expect to be able to park closest to the hill top! BUT, any other day, parking is usually available! 


Breathtaking . I love SF .
Your visitor from Seattle
author: Lindy N.

description: Best view of the city! Really breathtaking. On saturday 6/29/2013 before noon there was not a cloud in sight.  It was easy to find and parking for us was no trouble at all. A must when visiting SF! Note: Yelp says that is open only monday-friday. Ignore it.
author: Christianne F.

description:
Want to know what I did when I was underage and couldn't drink?

My friends and I would hop into some little Japanese import car at about midnight and speed our way up to SF for coffee, Chinese food and a smoke at Twin Peaks!

Talk about the best time to check this spot out! No tourists, creepy fog and that VIEW. Proof that the best things in life are free, this continues to be one of my stops when I am roaming around looking for a time filler or an "ooooh, ahhh!" to impress my out of town guests. If you are a photography enthusiast this will be your SF money shot!

I recently came with my friends from LA on a bright sunny day. The view was gorgeous as usual and it brought back sweet memories. One of my LA friends was my partner in crime who would come with me back in the day. Like this place and my friend, things only get better with time.
author: Lily M.

description: Went here last weekend with some girlfriends. It was very fun! The view is amazing!! Specially at night. We went in the afternoon, so we got to see some stars.
author: Brooklyn A.

description:
One of the best looking cities in the world at night
One of the best places to enjoy the view of this city
I would recommend this place to all my friends
It is very romantic on a cold summer night
Most people just say for a few minutes
So parking has never been too big if an issue when I have driven up there
author: Max P.

description:
Not sure why you would rate this less than a 5.  Its a great place to catch a spectacular view.

Its also a great destination for a run.  With its elevation of close to 900ft its a good workout!
author: Raman S.

description: Beautiful view of the city! The drive isn't difficult, and worth visiting atleast once you take in the scenery!
author: Deb J.

description: Soooo amazingly pretty! Can be very romantic. Been there twice now. The first time was too foggy but the second time was perfect. The view is breathtaking at night time compared to sunrise because all the lights. Parking is and can be a problem. Great place to get a bird's eye view of SF.
author: Meena N.

description:
Such a beautiful view of the city. If you're lucky, you get to see the whole bay area! Sadly for me, I've came here many times when it was cold and foggy. I think out of all the times i've been here, i only had one sunny day.. Good thing my brother brought his dslr camera so I took a lot of pictures! Got myself an awesome facebook picture! 

I also came to Twin Peaks at night, it was quite romantic coming here with the bf.
author: Nguyet T.

description:
The most breathtaking view of the San Francisco skyline. We came here at night and had a great view of the city lights, but I imagine that it would be even more beautiful during sunset! 

Must-see for anyone visiting SF for the first (or hundredth) time, but don't forget to bring a jacket because it can get windy!
author: M C.

description: Breathtaking at anytime of day or night.
author: Court S.

description:
The view is just as amazing in the daytime as it is in the nightime. Light fog is perfect, but try to come here on a warmer day, because it is frigid during cold nights. I've been here in all seasons and time of day, because I love the drive up here. The view is beautiful, but not that mind blowing to me. I think a better view of SF is from the other side of Golden Gate bridge on the old military base up the mountain by Sausalito. Or from the top of Coit tower is also a better view for me. 

However, if you visit SF and never come here, you are seriously missing out on a gem of place and a fun drive. You can use this place to the full if you're a more outdoorsy person. Great for hiking, jogging, biking. So much trails to do, separate from all the cars. I'd love to just park my car and explore the trails here, I'm sure it is so serene and mind clearing. 

So bring a coat, bring your own binoculars, haha. Just stand there and take in the fact you are in SF, one of the most famous cities in the world. Then go back to your car and blast the heater to super high. Lol.
author: Andrew I.

description: One of the best views of SF definitely must do especially if visiting the city. Put this on your bucket list.
author: Adam W.

description:
One of the best views of the city.  A must visit location when a friend visits SF.  Recommend visiting this place once during the day and once after sunset.  During the day, there is usually a mobile hot dog vendor in case you are hungry.  Not the best tasting hot dog, but it's kinda fun to kick back with a dog and soda to enjoy the view.

One major benefit of Twin Peaks compared to other peaks with views of the city is that you could enjoy the view with NO climbing, just drive up there.  One negative side could be the number of tourists you would encounter there.

I personally enjoy viewing the city from two alternative locations:
Tank Hill (http://www.yelp.com/biz/YaOHbbseQ-5J-VLBh6iPQw)
Corona Heights Park (http://www.yelp.com/biz/tGCFC0PTjLbU5m7Euw2NJg)
author: トモ T.

description:
Such a breathtaking view, and it's free!  

I lived in the Bay Area for years and never knew about this place.  What a complete shame!

We came right before sunset and hiked to the top of the peaks.  The view of the city, the bridges, everything, is out of control spectacular.  There are also hawks that just chill in the wind right above your head.  So cool to watch!

It got a bit chilly, so we went back to the car to wait until the lights of the city came on.  Instead of walking back up the hills, we came around to a parking area that's designated for tour buses only earlier on in the day, and there we sat enjoying the view.  Very romantic.  :)
author: Lisa S.

description:
We've never had an out-of-town visitor stay with us without making a stop at Twin Peaks. It's spectacular both during the day and at night, and a great way to start a trip ("behold the many hills you will soon be walking..."). It is guaranteed to be windy, so do come prepared. A flashlight at night isn't a bad idea, as you're walking up winding wooden steps. 

For its popularity, we've never felt crowded or even seen many people while we visit and parking is easy at the base, between the 2 peaks. If you don't make it any higher than the drive up, even that view is pretty great.

My favorite time is when the fog rolls in -- it's so neat to watch it take over the city.
author: Megan S.

description:
Such a romantic excursion...even though with my hair flying all around I feel like I look like a cubist painting.  

Better then to stay in the car and steam up the windows ;0

I love the sweeping views, especially at night.  Downtown SF looks like those glittering lightboxes I loved as a child.  

St. Ignatius' twin spires and dome have a gilded aura that makes me feel like I'm a knight sent to defend a fortress.

For all the time I've spent looking out at the amazing cityscape, I've forgotten to spend much time looking at the peaks themselves.  I understand that they are home to the endangered Mission blue butterfly, and that the peaks are responsible for helping keep back that summer fog that, albeit beautiful, does hinder my tan and attempts at al fresco dining.

Next time I go up I will take some time out from smooching and try to spy a little butterfly!
author: Joanna M.

description:
there is no way that I can not bring John to Twin Peaks, next to the Golden Gate Bridge, after all it he is a tourist, after showing me the London Tower (and no I havent seen the Princes and Anne Boleyn's ghosts) ... I have to bring him here.

Friend: Malou, what are you doing at TwinPeaks??? (after reading my tweet) and who  are you with?

Me: Well, I am doing what others are doing...hmmm...and I am with John...*wink*

Friend: hmmmm...

We came on a clear night, so both the Golden Gate and Bay Bridges are visible, did I mention there was a full moon too?

with tourist or not, you must come here and see for yourself.
author: Malou C.

description:
A romantic drive day or night to get a birds eye view of the city. You can stand here and point out all the landmarks to people visiting in San Francisco. Bring a jacket, it gets windy up here. 
Another free thing to do in the city.
author: Mocha G.

description: Magnificent views. Be prepared if you want to picnic up here. It is VERY windy and cool. Spend the 50 cents to use the telescope.
author: Joe M.

description: A great place to see the entire city of SF! It was crowded when we got here because there were two tours going on at the same time. Besides the great view, this place has a restroom! I didn't use the restroom but it was nice to see the convenience of one when you need to go! :)
author: Nhi R.

description: Third time the charm! The first two times were super foggy so we couldn't see anything. The clear sky tonight was perfect, especially with the last full moon of 2012. Free view of the entire city is breathtaking.
author: Christine C.

description:
Twin peaks! Wow! I don't know what to say but great view! Really breath taking! Oh and EXTREMELY WINDY! Be prepared. I think all the pictures I took, I have my hair in my face! We would have stayed longer but it was sooo cold! 

If you are visiting...I'd say this is a must go to spot. You can see the bay bridge, golden gate bridge...probably every other bridge. At night, everything is lit up ! The moon adds some shine as well!

-Give it a try!

P.s: It is freaking cold! Don't say I didn't warn you!
P.s.s.: These are the times when I wish I had a DSLR
author: Jocelyn V.

description:
I'm an idiot.  I've lived in the Bay Area for over 20 years and have NEVER been here!

I got to go here last weekend when the weather was fantastic (80 degrees baby!) and you could see past the Golden Gate Bridge.  What an awesome place to bring tourists or anyone who enjoys a great view.  We took a million pictures, watched a painter do some landscapes of the Bay, etc.  This is going on my must-do list for any visitors!
author: Leanne P.

description:
First came up here at night after a formal dance event in the city. I had never been up here before despite growing up in the Bay Area my whole life, so my date insisted on coming up here. It was super windy and freezing and as such, we only enjoyed the gorgeous view for a couple minutes before getting back in the car and blasting the heat on the way down the hill.

Second time, I brought a friend here as a place that he HAS to show his parents, and we came during the afternoon. It was an absolutely beautiful and clear day, and we could see the Berkeley Campanile from here. Still quite windy, but we were able to spend much more time up here enjoying the view.

The view is a great wide-angle view of San Francisco and the East Bay and the major bridges. There are paid telescopes for viewing. 

Definitely a must-visit for any tourist! Check out the view here, then the opposite view from Lawrence Hall of Science at UC Berkeley.
author: Esther Y.

description:
BEST LOOK OUT SPOT IN SF!

This place is beautiful. On a clear night/day you can see all of SF and beyond from the top of  Twin Peaks. 

Great for date nights, hanging out with friends or even by yourself to meditate.
author: Aimee E.

description: known as the highest point of San Francisco, visiting this place is definitely worth the incredible view. there's parking all along the hike, leading all the way up to the top if you dont want to attempt the hike but just want to get to the view. there's different areas of the location to sight see or just hang out. some areas of this location has telescopes and restrooms. the tallest point of this location has wooden steeps leading to the top. this place is very family/children friendly
author: Kathy T.

description:
Amazing. 
Went to San Francisco for the first time, my boyfriend insisted on taking me up here one cold a** night with the whole city lit up and got down on one knee and proposed :)

Clearly I have a bias, but it is definitely a special place. Great views, and really peaceful. I hate being cold and sometimes I act like a sissy when I have to do something like hike, but this is worth it! Right up there with some of my favorite lookouts in Ireland and France.
Enjoy!
author: Amber F.

description: The gps kept giving us the run around. But we eventually found it. I love this spot. Its so beautiful and romantical LOL. I thought the drive up was kinda creepy. The signs are not well lit and not very informative (direction wise). We enjoyed being able to experience such a beautiful sight. The parking lot is a fair size. The view at night is spectacular since the lights shine and emphasize the beauty of SF :). There are telescopes scattered throughout the place. The only thing that kills the beauty of this place is that a bunch of hoodlums sit on the edge and smoke pot , not only do they do that they act annoyingly obnoxious. Bleh minus that I would definitely return.
author: Andrea L.

description: I went back today, and wow, it was so beautiful! First off, check the fog forecast before you go. My friend and I waited and waited for weeks until we finally found a clear night. We took the MUNI again, but this time made it a point to take the 37, which took us much closer to the peak. I highly recommend taking the 37 up if you don't have a car -- otherwise, getting up to the top is pretty complicated. I'm still not actually sure how you find your way down; both times, my friend and I just ended up asking people in the parking lot for rides #lazy.
author: Kelly R.

description: Nice view. Really cold and rainy up top. Difficult to get to without a car. I know this place is famous and all, but I honestly could name 5 other places in the city that offer far better vistas and are more fun to climb up to.
author: Josephine L.

description: Best spot to view the entire San Francisco.  Best time to come is at night where you see the city skyline lit in the dark.
author: Bob S.

description:
There is a sublime emotion associated with every visit to Twin Peaks:

ELATION.

The first time I went, it was the grand finale to my first day in San Francisco - I was sold. I now visit Twin Peaks anytime I have visitors, after a date night, feel like dessert in the car, or am just having one of those days....... Paired with music, the experience always has the same effect: that of an exhilarating yet quiet calm that fills me like an internal caress.

Just four pieces of advice: unload before you go, bring a sweater/jacket, and make sure you bring good music (eg Yann Tiersen, Nouvelle Vague, Gotan Project, Telepopmusik, Kings of Convenience, etc). If you get lost on your way up and have Google Maps on your phone, look up directions to "Christmas Tree Point Rd."

[ 250 ]
author: Asha S.

description:
Not much can be said that hasn't been by anyone else already. Great view... came up there feeling like such a loser because I was the only one by myself. Can't hate on me... some people need their alone time you know?
 
I couldn't complain with my green tea latte that was keeping me warm while it looked like everyone else was feeling the chills. Sucks for you!

Anyways, I plan on coming again soon... with company this time.
author: Nga C.

description: Drive, bike, or hike to Twin Peaks Summit.  It is the second highest point in the city and provides spectacular views of the Bay Area.
author: Michael D.

description: Ending this trip the same as last time. In with the new memories. Out with the old.
author: Eric J.

description: Great view of any part of the city. Not much to do up here, but a great place to drive up to and enjoy the view for a few moments. Visit probably lasted 15 or 20 min max. Also its always very windy here, so bring a coat, especially at night!
author: Matin F.

description: Just drove into SF from LA, and SO glad to be back home. Just had to come here and take in ALL that my City has to offer. Love this place! It never gets old looking at the panoramic view of SF from the Golden Gate Bridge to Downtown. Ain't nothing like this town.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
(Teeth Chattering) I'm...so...cold...

After a fun filled afternoon in San Francisco, my wonderful date decided to show me the bright lights of the city by bringing me up to Twin Peaks.  How romantic is that?

Only problem is that the fog had rolled in and there was literally zero visibiltiy.  The drive up was terrifying.  And once on top, the wind was blowing and I was freezing!  Thats when it started raining!  Funny thing is, we drove from triple digit temps in Sacramento to avoid the heat, and now we were getting frost bite.  Oh, how I love California!

Unfortunately, our trip to the top lasted less than 10 minutes, less time that it took to drive up the hill.  LOL

Hopefully next time the weather will provide a better outlook spot.
author: Allison H.

description: Twin Peaks is the best way to view the entirety of San Francisco! On my visit, I came here once in the afternoon (after the fog had cleared you could see everything!) and once at sunset. Both times were breathtaking and unforgettable! As others have said, it does get chilly so be sure to bring a jacket.
author: Abby S.

description:
Wow. This place is very breath taking. Such an awesome view of the city. It was my first time in the city and I'm glad I got to come to this spot and finally see it for myself. If you haven't been here you're missing out! 

There is a strong breeze so bring a jacket. But we came on a perfect day the sun was out and the breeze felt really nice.
author: April B.

description:
Absolutely gorgeous.  It's like looking at a sparkling jewel box at night.  You can see the red Golden Gate Bridge to the left, and the bright white new Bay Bridge (often described as looking like a "bride's veil") on the right.  And you can capture both bridges in one photo.  If you have out-of-town visitors, this spot must be on the list of places to visit in the Bay Area.  

Plenty of parking spots are available right in front of the viewpoint where the telescopes are.  Even during the holidays, one can easily find parking as people come and go quickly.

Have yet to try:  looking at SF fireworks from this peak!

Bring a jacket, it will be chilly.
author: Y L.

description:
Not like Twin Peaks NEEDS another review - but I figured mine might be special for cyclist. First of all, if you've visited Twin Peaks you should know this isn't a small challenge just for anyone to do. San Francisco is known for it's dramatic hills and Twin Peaks doesn't subside to that - in fact quite the opposite.

I've been riding for a year slowly training for some competition rides and the best way to get into shape is hills, hills and more hills. 

At the beginning I had some technical difficulties w/ my shoe's clipping into my pedals which makes it extremely difficult to pedal with only one foot. So - if it's your first time w/ clip in shoes... be careful. I slipped out a few times almost causing me to cut into traffic (people speed up/down that hill). There were a few times I considered turning around cause of that...but didn't. 

After 20 mins or so of the most painful/steady hill of your life you are greeted with the most amazing reward and view in the city.

[Everything's beautiful up there - even the Tenderloin]  ;)

Going down hill was a breeze, almost too easy... Thou, if you don't have good brakes don't even THINK about it... you'll die - seriously. 

Dress light for the uphill but prepare to freeze your ass off on the way down via insane winds.

I hope you got something out of this...
author: David C.

description:
I was looking for cool places to adventure to in the city on Yelp this summer, and Twin peaks was one of the spots I found with tons of great reviews, so I decided it was a must. 

Yelp, you never let me down :)

With a fellow adventurer and a bottle of two buck chuck in tow, we took muni as close as we could get to Twin Peaks. As the bus driver and other passengers caught on to what we were up to, they all piped up with helpful advice of the best ways to get there, all sounding quite reminiscent of doing the same thing we were doing years before. One of the passengers was concerned about me wearing flip flops but I assured him that as an upstate new yorker I could handle it. When we got to the right stop the bus driver told us where to go. We only had to make it to the top of the somewhat sketchy wooden stairs before we were struck by the beauty of San Francisco on a clear (wooo no fog!) summer night. Although it was pretty cold, since it was around 10PM, there was a ledge that we used to brace ourselves against the wind. Glorious.

I love SF.
author: Eliza D.

description:
Tourist must go to spot.

Highest 360 degree view in the city.

Check the weather report; a clear day is crucial.
author: Steven F.

description: I'll always have a fond memory of this place because my boyfriend took me here on our first date :). We came at night and you should DEFINITELY bring a jacket because it was super cold and windy. To get here, it's a very steep and winding road but the end result is an amazing view. You do have the option of walking or driving, and if you choose to drive there is a decent amount of parking available. On some days it may be foggy, so you should check the weather forecast before coming up! The panoramic view of SF is really worth it though. Super pretty!
author: Vivian L.

description:
Many a metropolis-viewing...
Many a mindblowing conversation...
Many a makeout sesh...

...have gone down at this sweet city-viewing spot.

The amazing panorama of San Francisco from Twin Peaks at night reminds me of just how lucky I am to live here.

EXCEPT when it's too damn foggy to see anything, which is the case... often. But that's the city for ya, right?

I HIGHLY discourage you from getting stuck up here with someone you dislike even slightly. This can turn the aforementioned pleasures quickly to abhorrences even on the clearest night. 

At least that's my experience :).
author: Kate V.

description: This is the best view of the whole city. I think it's much prettier at night time as you can see the city in lights! Keep in mind that the drive up is dark and it may be busy on top at night with kids drinking and hanging out!
author: Jenifer T.

description:
I found this location on Yelp and decided to go here on 12.31.2013 to watch the fireworks with my significant other. Unfortunately, you're so far away from the show that all you can see are merely sparkles and blasts of the fireworks and hardly any 'BOOMS' that I'm used to.

Don't get me wrong, this place is BEAUTIFUL, but if you're looking to catch some great fireworks, this isn't the place. I must say, It's quite a spectacular view at night with all the lights and surrounding architectural structures!

A must see for a special night, just not for New Year's Eve.
author: Kamran A.

description: Came up here to chill with some friends on a Wednesday and it was very nice. It was only cold so bring a sweater with you. Also it was kinda busy I guess? there was a lot of people and it was kinda hard to find a place to park. buts it's ok, still enjoyed my time up here.
author: Seohyuniee O.

description: Thank goodness I only live a 3 minute drive from here! This place left me absolutely breathless (well, that's maybe because I was also out of breath from biking up the steep steep hill!). While I thought this place was nice during the day, I think I actually prefer coming here at night to enjoy the city lights. It gets REALLY cold and it's always windy here so bring a nice jacket (or warm partner and cuddle).
author: Sam L.

description:
In my opinion, the most gorgeous spot in San Francisco. I mean, you really cant ask for a better view of san fran. 
I come here usually for one of two reasons. 

1. I am really stressed out and need to hike alone and be reminded of the awesome city i live in. 
2. I have guests over and want to show them all the touristy things around SF. Twin Peeks is always on my top 5 for them. 

Its cold up here, take a sweater!
author: Elaine M.

description:
Tourist Hot Spot but its a must go if you are ever in The City even if you are local this place is pretty cool. You can view most of the districts in The City and on a clear day see the Golden Gate Bridge in all it's glory. 

Would I be back?
Yes, I would be back
I have gone up to SF, countless times and this place never gets old.
author: James S.

description: AN AMAZING VIEW OF SAN FRANCISCO. The roads can be dangerous but definitely worth the drive when you get up there.  Try to go when there's no fog (which is hard to determine) but if you go during the right time where its fog free, you get to see the beautiful city of San Francisco and all its glory.
author: Danny N.

description:
OK, great view. On the other hand, watch for criminal activity. During the approximately 15 minutes my family and I took to walk to the summit and back from the "off road" parking, thieves had broken out the (highly tinted) rear window of my station wagon and had stolen various camera gear (in a bag, mind you) from behind the back seat. This is all in broad daylight with people milling about. I suppose the broken glass in the parking lot should've been sufficient warning. Upon walking around the park to see if anyone happened to be "with" my stolen goods, we encountered several groups of jokers smoking pot (obviously and with impunity) in their parked cars. Great, perfect for the kids, and maybe I can get run over too. San Francisco, please get this park cleaned up.

Update: According to the police when we filed our report, "this happens all the time."
author: Adam S.

description:
One of the best views of San Francisco and the Bay Area anywhere in the Bay Area but...

... you have to make sure that you go on a non-foggy day. On a clear or windy day, the views from Twin Peaks are breathtaking! You can see almost the entire city of San Francisco, Golden Gate Bridge, Bay Bridge, San Rafael-Richmond Bridge, East Bay, Alcatraz, Sausalito, Treasure Island, Angel Island and almost the entire Bay. 

Warning: always bring a jacket! Doesn't matter that it's in the 90s or 100s in the rest of the Bay Area. You'll need a jacket up here. Come here twice: once in the morning and then right before sunset and stay after that to watch the city lights twinkle.
author: Don D.

description:
We were looking forward to a beautiful night skyline of San Francisco. 

Instead, when we got up to the lookout spot, it was extremely foggy (that seems to be the theme of my trip here to NorCal). Other than a few blurry light far far away, we couldn't see anything at all. On top of that, the wind was blowing crazy and I could hardly stand up straight, not to mention I was freezing cold!

We stayed there for less than 10 minutes and were very disappointed. We had such high hope for this place seeing all the good review here but the weather just didn't cooperate. Hopefully, we will have better luck next time!
author: Sum H.

description: I missed this on my first trip to SF, but was fortunate enough to come here on my second trip.  This is a must do.  You get a multitude of views which are all amazing.
author: Bob B.

description:
Probably my favorite view of The City by far. I haven't gone up in the day time, but at night.. well, it takes my breath away. It gets cold though, so layer up! Or even better, bring blankets. I've come here with the boy a few times - unfortunately on New Years Eve, they closed it off, but we ended up watching the fireworks at one of the lower streets that led up to Twin Peaks. They still looked amazing (:

There are always a ton of people up here, but they kind of do their own things, and don't bother you. I hear there are some rude tourists in the day time, but at night, everybody's too absorbed in the beauty of the city lights to bug you.

Best part? It's free. No parking fees or anything. Not a fan of the little binocular things; the view you can see without them is nice enough that you don't need those. Twin Peaks is one of those sights you HAVE to go to at least once in your life.
author: Amy L.

description:
This was the place to be when I was a youngster. I was one of the only guys with a license AND a car when I was in high school and we would take girls up here during the Summer (that's August, September and October in SF) and we would get down. It was like a scene out of American Graffiti!!

I went back recently and it was windy, cold, wet and raining pretty good, but that didn't stop me from taking pictures of the beautiful SF skyline and it sure didn't stop people from gettin down. Plenty of cars had foggy windows and that just brought it all back for me. Great spot and clearly always will be.
author: Hector G.

description:
One word: Breathtaking!

Beautiful view of San Francisco. You will have to see it to be able to embrace and experience it all. It is just stunning and very relaxing. It is overall my favorite scenic view and should be yours too.

Thank you Seanards for showing it to me! Love you!
author: Linda N.

description:
Twin Peaks never gets old. It's a cute place to take your significant other, it's a sight seeing type of place, and also a place with a gorgeous view. You won't stay here that long because there isn't really anything to do, but take pictures.

It's quite a windy road, but it's worth the view. 
And if you plan on going during the night time, which makes the view even more spectacular, it might be quite packed. It looks better at night time because obviously you see the lights, the golden gate bridge light up, and everything. It's too gorgeous sometimes. 

If you're in SF, might as well and see this view, even if it's 5 minutes b/c it's worth it.
author: Ivadine M.

description:
Gorgeous spot.  It's too bad there's trash and graffiti, but that's the doing of the a-hole visitors, not a problem with the location.  There isn't enough money to keep up with all the trashy visitors.  It's worth the walk up the hills, although the steps are made for giants so wear good shoes, the path is rocky and steep.  Bring a picnic, walk to a hilltop, and have a nice time afternoon overlooking the city or the Pacific, or both.

So glad I could share the view with Jen K.  What a perfect day!  Let's do it again soon!
author: Rebecca H.

description: The drive up here is so nice. So much green. The air quality felt so fresh. The view: AMAZING! Took a lot of pictures and just took the scenery in. If that make any sense. Pretty cool when you are on top.
author: Zochi F.

description: Super windy at 5pm on a Saturday, but overall, good experience! Nice place to visit if you aren't looking to spend money. Overview of SF, with the fog occasionally coming in and out. Make sure to layer up before going.
author: Patrick N.

description:
The first time i came here was with my boyfriend on his birthday. I thought it was romantic because we came here late at night and it was his first time too and he was born and raised in SF. The view was jaw dropping. I didn't like the fact there were some people playing music a little too loud in their car when people were trynna enjoy the view and on top of that, it smelled like weed. Try not to come here obviously when it's foggy because I know a lot of people coming from where I live in the Central Valley like to take spontaneous trips here and when they get here, they can't see anything cause of the fog. Be aware! 

I Hella Love SF.
author: Janice V.

description:
Another long time favorite of mine- it could look eerie, like in the thriller/suspense movie, "Copy Cat." But on a clear sunny day, the views are just gorgeous. It's the views and the landmarks that make this city so memorable- I do miss my birth city from time to time. Anyway, it's one of the places I look forward to seeing again whenever we're in town. A must!

Tourists come here, by car or tour buses. Locals come here, by car (popular, romantic at night) or even on foot- for the exercise- recreational (what a workout, with the hills and again, the views- it's a 2-for-1 experience). I suppose the difference, is as a local, you expect the fog and it's not new or unusual to you. It just becomes a part of life here. So, locals may dress more accordingly. I used to live here, I know.

The picture opportunities- lots of them. The hills, the streets, the homes, the landmarks you recognize- it's there. I'm sure if you had that Panoramic feature on your camera, it would not disappoint. Sometimes strangers will offer to take a picture of you and yours, which is really nice. We do this all the time- we reciprocate the favor. Our camera: Press the button down half way and then click! Voila- a picture to remember.

Yeah, it's cold and windy even if it's sunny (at least, the sky is blue). Be prepared- always dress in layers when you come to the city and wear comfortable walking shoes too- Rule # 1. Don't say I didn't warn you. I've mentioned this basic rule numerous times in my other reviews.

It's funny how you know one way getting here as a teenager and then of course, we went another way, and I didn't recognize the path! My husband relied on the GPS system. It was also his first time driving here out of all there trips together, BTW.
author: Margret C.

description:
it's a good place for hikers and bikers, but i wouldn't do it once is enough, riding bike up the mountain(it's hard) a lot of muscle needed in your legs.  but down hill it's fun to get the wind in your face...
 just be careful going use your brakes as much as possible
author: Alex W.

description:
After a weekend trip filled with nonstop tourist action and endless gluttony, the breathtaking view at Twin Peaks was the most perfect way to end the trip. We were lucky that the night skies were clear! 

(Be careful of the two fat raccoons running about. They look like little lost puppies running around at night...)
author: Megan H.

description: always bring an extra jacket regardless of what time of the day you get in here....pretty windy and cold...
author: sherrie m.

description: The pictures here say it all.  Simply incredible views.  Amazing how far you can see from up here.  I loved it best at night time.   A must drive to place when in SF!
author: Alexandra C.

description: Gorgeous views and history are my favorites. It's a quick drive up and is great for outdoor activities.
author: Darren F.

description: If you're in the area and it's a clear day this is a nice quick stop to get a really great view of the city. It's a short drive to the top and view is so rewarding. The best part is you don't have to do any hiking, the view is right in front of where you park!
author: Brandon Y.

description:
Nothing better than hyping up the best view of San Francisco to friends/family then taking them here and it's foggy as hell. I'm talking about zero visibility every single time... day or night.

I've had some great times here and my friends will never ever let me forget the dumb sh*t that I've done here. From pissing on the wall and making my own fog to throwing up in that nasty ass restroom, nothing but good times. 

This was one of the last places I visited before I almost lost my life around April 2010. I guess I had to try and catch that last glimpse of one of the most beautiful views in Nor Cal before I kicked the bucket.

Can't wait for my next visit and I promise to take pictures of... fog.

"JoOo Iiiiyee need to put a quarter in it?!"
author: Be A.

description:
If your in the city on a NON FOGGY Night be sure to take a drive up and see a panoramic view of the city. Market street with its lights, looks absolutely amazing.
Great place to bring a newbie to the city. However beware of foggy days, as Twin Peaks is above the fog, so somedays you can see absolutely nothing.

Be sure to take a trip here if you haven't seen the view before!
author: Noelle L.

description: I used to come here in the day time to study for midterms and finals. I rarely left my car because of the high winds and after dark I don't recommend going alone if you plan on exiting your vehicle. Some of the peeps this peak manages to attract after dark are a bit shady. Great view of the city though....obviously.
author: Kristy F.

description:
Grow some thunder thighs and hike/ bike up this bad boy (on a beautiful sunny day) and you'll be rewarded with a wonderful view of San Francisco.  

Plenty of 20 minute parkings if you decide to bring the car. 

It's windy and cold up here so bring your layers and bring the tourists!
author: Walerz B.

description:
The journey to Twin Peaks is in itself an adventure if you have to take public transportation to the peaks.  I got on a bus and winded my way up the peaks.  From the bus stop, I climbed up the side of the mountain to see..... wait for it... wait for it.... CLOUDS!!!  It is very important to note that you have to go to the Twin Peaks on a clear and sunny day.  I personally don't think it was a total lose though.  It was great having the wind blow all around you all alone on the top of a mountain.  It felt like I was on top of the world.  Another note, take a coat or sweater as it can get quite cold in the sky.

And as always, Have Fun!!!
author: Christian H.

description:
Easily one of my favorite places to go in SF. 

In the day time, or night time, you will still love the view. I personally love seeing the city at night.  You can see all the bridges in SF on a clear night.

Literally cannot get enough of this place. It has such an amazing view.
author: Tiffany S.

description:
I often take bike rides up to Twin Peaks. This a short, beautiful, ride. Your hard working getting to the top is rewarded with a panoramic view of the city and bay (assuming it's not too foggy, of course).

The ascent is somewhat challenging, but eventually, at the top you'll find that it is smooth sailing. I usually ride up Twin Peaks Blvd., approaching from the South and descend on the North end, so I do the hairpin turn going down. Plus, this  is probably the best way to do it because the road is paved much better on the north side.

Tangent Alert: While riding up O'Shaughnessy Blvd. I saw a coyote. I believe there is a sign posted about coyotes being present, but did expect to see one. We just looked at each other. I think we were both scared :). Shout out to Shaugh, the coyote (I named him)!
author: Brian S.

description:
- do not, i repeat, do not bother going on a foggy day
- try going during "off" hours during weekday afternoons/ early weekend mornings otherwise you'll be competing with tour buses and locals alike for much-coveted parking
- not dog-friendly/grassy
- if you're in town longer than a day -- try and visit Bernal Heights instead which offers a 360-view w/out the hype and tourist fuss-muss.

lastly: it is *alwaysalwaysalwaysALWAYS*, freezing. 
welcome to SF & layer the #@!&%-up!
author: Anjali V.

description:
#2 stop on my San Fran trip :) 

The peaks were super easy to find and conveniently located nearby Castro Street so WINNING :D

The view itself was breathtaking. You could see the whole span of San Francisco! Sadly the only thing i could recognize was the Golden Gate Bridge...

I love that this spot isn't terribly touristy and there was plenty of parking available all around. Twin Peak itself  is basically a road that circles around a tiny plot of land. The road itself consists of many parking spots and the very edge of this circle is a walkway that allows people to view the city from all sides. Woot! :) 

Quick Tip: bring a jacket! It was definitely windy up there. 

I kind of wish I got to come up here at night but I still appreciated the view either way.
author: Julie Y.

description:
All other Bay Area views are slapped in the face by Twin Peaks.

Completely worth all travel arrangements, air, bus, bart, car, WHATEVER to get here and see the overlook. 

Breathtaking and god-like view of San Francisco, East Bay's skyline, Mount Tam, and all FOUR bridges (on a non hazy day or night). 

I drove from Oakland in the wee hours of the night to see this for the first time in my life. COMPLETELY worth it.

Go. Go now.
author: Jessica R.

description: Cold as hell (does that even makes sense?) but an awesome view!
author: Antonio J.

description:
It is absolutely gorgeous up here. You can see almost the entire city! I've only been here in the daytime, so I'm pretty sure the night time view is as spectacular or even better.

My car doesn't really like the drive up here though. Or my friends. I don't know how to drive up hills (there are no crazy hills in the middle of Fairfield and with an automatic vehicle of all things). One time, I was driving and stopped at a very steep hill at a stop sign. I think I scared the guy behind me because my tires screeched and my car rolled back quite a bit before I was able to drive ahead. My friends are all calling me badass now that I screeched my tires. ??? hahaha But they're pretty scared to go up any hill when I drive in the city. That won't stop me from coming back to Twin Peaks though! I'll definitely surprise my friends by going up here for sure! One day hehe

There was plenty of parking the last time I went. I believe it's only 20 minutes, but you spend the entire 20 minutes taking pictures. 

It is really windy up here too, so bring a jacket and layer up!

I think the next time I come, I'll just hike up there. It would be more of an experience and the hike would be very rewarding for my thighs.
author: Terri L.

description: Amazing views. Gets quite windy up there so make sure to bring a jacket. Also try to come at an off peak time or weekday as it can get crowded and parking may be harder to find. Must see San Francisco site
author: Samir H.

description: Place from where you can see the beauty of San Francisco. Mission, Market, Richmond, Sunset and what not.
author: Pratik J.

description:
A friend recently introduced me to this spot. Wow. Far less touristy and crowded than spots like the Golden Gate and such a fantastic view. 

Also, you might notice the hairpin turn that's in, like, every car commercial halfway down the mountain. Cool!
author: Alie A.

description: Beautiful gem of San fransico, the view is gorgeous and the perfect finisher for any date night in the city. Went on a Friday night so it was pretty packed with tourists and weed smokers alike. Drive up was a little sketch, especially with the head on traffic in the dark, so please drive carefully if you plan on coming. If your in frisco make this spot a priority because it is worth all the hype.
author: Macin T.

description:
This is undoubtedly the most scenic view of San Francisco in the Bay Area with the view spanning from the Golden Gate all the way over to Bernal Heights.  The view gets even broader if you hike one of the peaks.  

I bike here every other day.  Though it looks like a very steep hill, if you take the Twin Peaks blvd. starting at Portola instead of Clayton, its much more gradual incline.  

I once saw the Blue Angels fly over San Francisco during Fleet Week from the top of Twin Peaks and their motions accentuated the sculptural aspects of our peninsula's majestic beauty.  A better place to see it than the more populated areas of town during that festival.
author: Christopher A.

description:
