Go up Twin Peaks on a hot, clear day (rare in SF) to see spectacular views of the entire city! You will be amazed by SF's beauty - tourists will immediately fall in love with San Francisco, and locals will be reminded why San Francisco is the best city. 

You haven't seen SF, if you haven't visited Twin Peaks. Even if you have a couple of hours in SF, COME HERE! Though, bring a jacket because it's most likely windy up there!
author: Michelle L.

description:
This can be a breathtaking experience or one of the biggest bummers. If you are lucky, you will get a day without cloud and fog obstruction. If it's a typical day, then you'll most likely see what I see (see photos). The "Point of View Telescopes" are $.50 (quarters only). 

No smoking! There's also a catering a truck here in the afternoon if you happen to be hungry. There's free parking but it's pretty limited and you're fighting with other locals, tourists, and tour buses. It sucks that MUNI doesn't come all the way up here. I trekked after getting off the 37 Corbett.
author: Dominic T.

description:
Gorgeous views of San Francisco!!

A must-see during your visit, if the weather cooperates. If there's no fog, you have 360degree views of everything from the Pacific Ocean, to the Golden Gate Bridge, to the Financial District to the Bay Bridge, to the foothills of the south, with water and beautiful mountains everywhere!

Super windy up there, so hold onto your stuff!

There's no good hiking trail to get to the top, so we drove, but once you get there and park, you still have to climb up to the top (takes about 5 minutes).

We spent a good two hours here just admiring the sights!! Well worth your time!
author: Suejung S.

description: It's no wonder this is such a well known spot. The view of the city down below is quite beautiful. Although it's super cold from there, the view at sunset is pretty awesome. Drove up at about 7:30 on a Wednesday and was able to get parking at the top. Not sure how one manages to park down below and hike up here but if you missed a leg day or aren't freaked out by heights I suppose it's doable. But for the lazy, I absolute recommend coming during the week.
author: Stephie D.

description:
Highest point of the city with fabulous views day and night. come with friends or with a lover. Just a great place to see downtown, the Wharf and Golden Gate Bridge really makes them feel with a loss of words from the beauty. 

Recommend going on a clear sunny day.
author: K D.

description:
Great view during the day and even better at night.

As a SF Native, far removed from her city by the bay, when I get opportunity to go to the peaks, I get excited like I've never seen a high vantage point in my life.  But this is my spot, ever since high school when I could learn how to drive up the damned hill itself.  

This view beats all others in the city.  Both locals and tourists come here-  Tourists gawk at the scenery, and locals bring their tourists friends to do the same. 

Bathroom is junk-- Oh, I've had memories trying to learn how to close the machine.  What do you mean, it's cleaning?!?  Let me piss already!  Better luck finding a bush and squatting.

At night time, it can get a bit ghetto in typical SF fashion.  Lots of kids come up here to do god knows what in their car and others blast their drake, or hyphy music with that heavy bass.  Others light one up, since SF is a very pot-friendly city.  Either way, all patrons of the peaks came for one main reason, and that was to enjoy the view.  Just make sure you get down safe, and DON'T DRINK.  We've had unfortunate events at this peak with fatalities.  I'd like to keep this place somewhat safe.   Cops roll by to make sure we don't act a fool.  I've had a few times where I've never seen a cop, and others I've seen brigades of em makin sure no bad biz is being dealt.   

NOTE:  VIEW IS BEST AT SUNSET WHEN FOG IS ABOUT TO ROLL THROUGH THE MARINA.  TRUST ME.  and PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE pick up your useless cigarette butts!
author: Cat A.

description: Most beautiful view besides Vista Point at the Golden Gate Bridge.  Bathrooms are a fun experience to be had......
author: Cindy S.

description: Not a single photo could do this place justice. You must see it to believe it. At the top of Twin Peaks you will find one of the best views of San Francisco. Perch yourself on the wall, and soak in the city views.
author: Amy M.

description:
Check my picture (#146) for an awesome pano of the city from Twin Peaks.

If it wasn't for the tour buses full of auspicious asian/european tourists, and the gale force winds, this place would be the BEST spot to view the city. Beautiful 360 view of the city from one of its peaks, you can just about pick out every neighborhood in it's glory.

Bring sure to bring a jacket and your camera!

If you like to bike, jog, or hike take on of the roads/trails up to the peak and blast your way down! Nothing like a rewarding view of the city to help with your fitness moral!
author: Eric A.

description:
Just got back from SF... went to visit friends living there now, and to celebrate the best holiday ever (St. Patty's Day)! 

I was there a week, and did A LOT... out of everything Twin Peaks was the most amazing! If you go at night, it is just an spectacular view of the city. You can see the Golden Gate Bridge, The Dome, and all the other landmarks. Not to mention... FREE!
author: Jessica E.

description: This is one of my favorite vista points in the Bay Area - very accessible by car for quick visits with out-of-town guests.  Gorgeous place to watch sunrise or sunset - and plenty of photo opportunities.  The one thing I would change would be the litter - there's always so much litter, glass and in the summer - the smell of urine (eww!) - which detracts from an otherwise enjoyable experience.
author: Jenn C.

description: I've made the mistake of coming here at night and it is cold & windy!  Pick a beautiful day to soak up the magic that is Twin Peaks!  My bf & I, along with what seemed like half the city, were up there the weekend of the airshow.  It was such a treat to bask in the warm weather and see the jets zoom by!  Tourist trap?  Probably.  But I think it is safe to say that the locals love Twin Peaks also.
author: Lai T.

description: I loved it!  It has amazing views of the entire city!  Very cool!  I will definitely have to remember to take my out of town guest for a drive here.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I had the privilege of living at the foot of Twin Peaks (on Burnett Avenue) and let me tell you, it was such an amazing treat to wake up to every morning.  So much so that was easy to take for granted.  

For one, it's the coldest part of the city and the best place to experience San Francisco summers.  It could be 90s elsewhere, but I'd still be wearing layers of clothes due to the breeze up there. Even if it's too hot to wear more than a tank top and slippers elsewhere, trust me, you'll need a jacket in Twin Peaks.

For two, it's a hit or miss with the fog.  Sometimes it would have amazing "I can't believe I live here and/or SF is the best city ever" kind of views.  But most of the time it tends to be cloudy, you could make the trek all the way to the top and barely see a thing.  

For three, the windy road can be really tricky.  It's scary to drive in, especially at night. I hated that there were very few street lights and was always scared I could make a wrong turn off the cliff. but also loved the romantic and dimly lit view of urban life.  

But still, aside form all that, I'd still say that Twin Peaks is such a breath taking place that will lift up any sour mood and make you feel inspired and in love with the world again. Enjoy every bit of it.
author: Lea F.

description: I love going here when it's not as busy or crowded but it definitely has one of the best views in SF. There are other views in the Bay with better views, but this is must see if you're from out of town.
author: Stephen D.

description: Really beautiful view of of sf. I would recommend coming during the sunset or night to see all the lights. Also parking can be a pain but you can park on the corners of the hill.
author: Mike T.

description:
If it's a cold chilly night in the streets of SF... then it's BELOW ZERO at the top of Twin Peaks! Bring a blanket or a good jacket and snuggle up to your one and only ;)

I've taken many people here as it's a great place to take out-of-towners to impress them with the grandeur of all the city lights at night!  It's beautiful during the day and night.. but I prefer the night because it's romantic and breathtaking.

Don't think anything too naughty either! This is not make out point in SF! It's usually fairly crowded, with people walking around taking pictures and enjoying the view, plus at least one police car on the lookout.

Otherwise, bring your camera and enjoy a special moment with someone :)
author: Samantha L.

description:
Awesome view of San Francisco!

A little bit of hiking, fresh air, and a great view at the top. 

Make sure you brink a jacket because it does get windy.
author: Stef L.

description:
Nearly froze my ass off the last time I was here. VERY WINDY at the top. 

But, the wind and cold is worth it. Nearly 360 degree view. Multiple viewing spots so that you don't have to compete with all the other onlookers. As other reviewers have mentioned already, DO NOT COME HERE ON A FOGGY DAY-- you won't be able to see sh!t. But, being that this is San Fran, roll the dice and wait till tomorrow. Because the view is breathtaking.
author: Will C.

description:
On a recent trip to San Francisco, I took my girlfriend here. It was her first time here, and I've only been here a handful of times (though it has been 3-4 years since I last drove up here. As I gaze at the cityscape, the golden gate bridge, and the water of the bay, I get this nostalgic feeling that I don't feel elsewhere; I've never considered the city San Francisco my "home" but it represents the smaller cities that I grew up around.  

We got there perhaps 15 minutes before sunset and watched as the sun disappeared over the tree line to what I assume are the trees from Golden Gate Park. The drive doesn't take too long, and it wasn't packed at all when I got there. Since it does get windy/chilly up there, I advise thick sweaters, jackets, and/or blankets. Some people do like to sit in the car and admire the view from there instead.
author: Stanley S.

description: The crowd at night was a bit much but i didnt care, i could clear my thoughts and look off into the distance and think about my deepest memories. The only thing i can recommend is that you have to atleast visit this place if you are in the local area.
author: Alec V.

description:
Enjoyable experience watching the sunrise - I'm so glad there was no fog but it was windy and COLD. We were early to the sunrise - apparently, the sunrise time given on weather channel, etc is the time that the sun is fully up and not at the first light?

Easy to drive to although it was a windy road (two entrances to the top) and ample parking at 6am on a Monday morning. It's definitely a place I'd take out of town friends, or anyone who hasn't been there before. But pretty please, people, throw your trash IN to the trash can.
author: Kristy T.

description:
I have ZERO tolerance for the cold, ergo I never did too well coming up here....but the view is absolutely, breathtakingly gorgeous. I'm sure I'd make another visit as long as I've got 8 layers of crap on. Almost like going to mammoth minus the snowboarding. 

P.S. Don't come here alone. Bring a date cause you're going to need someone to cuddle up with or you've done sealed your icy-popsicle-like doom.
author: Rho L.

description: Nice place to take family for sight seeing.   The only reason i didn't give it five stars is because all the weed smoking and drinking at night (ghetto people).
author: Joe B.

description: Lovely spot to take in the views of the entire Bay Area on a clear day or night :)
author: Tracy C.

description: This place was really a neat stop for a new tourist like me. It was quite crowded, especially in the middle of the day and in the middle of the week. We got out of the car and were surprised at how cold it was up there. Listen to the other reviewers and bring a jacket! You can get some great views from up here, and it's a great picture spot. The drive up here is pretty cool too.
author: Cherine A.

description:
The views from up here are gorgeous!  I took the city bus and was able to get up here with only minimal walking/climbing.  For an even better view, climb the higher hill directly behind the lookout area.

This is an amazing and romantic spot, and I imagine it is even prettier at night with the lights of the city twinkling in the background.

Bring a jacket because it is freezing up at heights that high.
author: Miss L.

description:
We didn't see Laura Palmer's corpse. Yeah, I'm old by referencing an over 20-year-old TV show. Oh, and now I'm explaining my joke references like when Dennis Miller would explain his references like when he said "... had the attention span of Bo Radley." Gee, I just sub-referenced like Miller, too. I need to get back on track. Writing this is like trying to say on track while driving the windy road to Twin Peaks.

It's not really a park, but just a scenic vista point with busloads of tourists. What's even more shocking is that some of the tourists never got off the bus. Maybe the bus driver was on a tight schedule?

The alarm remote wouldn't lock and unlock my car so I had to use key entry. Maybe that's why the bus passengers don't unload - the bus doors won't open. The transmission towers on the Peaks were probably interfering with my car remote. That's actually a bit scary since our bodies absorbed those signals for the 40 minutes we were up there. Thankfully, we aren't pregnant or want to have kids.
author: Brian U.

description:
This is the best view of SF. You can see all of it.  It's not the easiest place to get to without a car so it might be difficult to go to if you're just visiting SF like I was. I ended up taking a cab which isn't the best idea because no cab driver wants to go there; the fare to get there wouldn't be worth it. I split the cab fare with some buddies anyway so it wasn't too bad. Luckily, we had an awesome cab driver that took us there despite of this. He also gave us a little bit of a tour and history of SF. It probably jacked up the fare, but his conversations were interesting enough to make it seem worth it.  Also, the cab driver mentioned that it's usually cloudy in SF so that day we were lucky because the skies were all clear and sunny. 

Twin Peaks is an awesome view, but that's all there is to it. Not much else to do, but to climb the two peaks and soak in the view. It's pretty windy up there so it can get chilly. Make sure to bring a light jacket or sweater. 

I went during the day, but I can imagine it looks just as amazing at night with everything lit up. 

Getting back to the hotel was a challenge. Like I said earlier, cabs rarely come up that far so we ended up hiking down and tried to find a cab when we reached "civilization". We eventually did. It made a great adventure!
author: Ron B.

description:
Great place to take visitors to the SF Bay Area. High enough to be in the clouds, certainly chilly from the windy conditions, and awesome panoramic views of the city. We went during the day on an overcast day (when is it not overcast in the city?) and even our visitor commented how beautiful it must look at night.

Even bought a spray painted piece of artwork from the artist stationed at the lookout spot. He threw in a free frame too! woot!
author: Tommy B.

description: It is a very popular spot among tourists and locals. You see the lights at night(the Castro is most evident) and during the day you can see most of the city. Be careful during foggy days, the visibility is very poor driving up and the turns can cause accidents to the least attentive drivers.
author: Kelvin M.

description: This place is perfect to see the night lights of San Francisco. You will see both bridges (Golden Gate, and Bay) and everything else. Very good for tourists and a perfect dating spot. They even has public restroom. So considerate. I won't come back but I will definitely recommend someone who has ever seen the view to come.
author: Lei-Lei F.

description:
Alas, it was a little foggy when I went up here, but I still got a nice view. The fog surrounding us made us feel like we were in another world!! whee!!! We stopped by Blue Bottle and Ike's (yup, we're prepared), grabbed coffee and delicious mouth-watering sandwiches and ate them here, perched on one of the stone ledges, breathing in the cool, crisp air and looking around us and below us in delight. Then we proceeded to take silly pictures and run around and admired being up so high looking down at this amazing city. 

I turned to my friend and asked "Is this the only free parking so readily available in SF??" There was a lot of parking. And we were there on a Saturday morning. ;D 

It wasn't too crowded, it wasn't windy or too cold, and it was one of the most refreshing, liberating adventures ever!!
author: Eileen K.

description: Breathtaking view with public transportation (37 MUNI) closeby. Can't lose. Very romantic spot for the lovers out there, just bring a coat! Gets pretty breezy :)
author: Jeff M.

description:
Lived in the Bay Area for ten years and I am still a tourist. My boyfriend and I were driving back from Half Moon Bay and we're driving on 35 and he sees the Sutro Tower. He's like, "we're driving towards that". We drive up there, we take in the breathtaking view of downtown SF and of the Blue Angels flying over, then we look to our right and see tons of people on the hill. 

How do we get there? We wonder.

Thus our discovery of Twin Peaks. Again, my boyfriend and I are floored. We always knew this place existed, we just never took the opportunity to take advantage of it. Now I have an excuse, I'm not Bay Area breed, but my boyfriend who has lived in the North Bay has never been. 

The views are just amazing! (Did I say that already?) And it does help to enjoy such views with someone to hold on to and to gush to. Next time, when my feet don't hurt, we'll climb up the hill and take in SF even more.
author: Jamie L.

description: Beautiful! A great weekend hike (although be careful going up- the trails aren't great). This is why I love this city!
author: Sam F.

description:
Peak view.

Market Street cutting through the city. Alcatraz sitting in the bay. Skyscrapers shooting upwards. Bay Bridge sparkling. Bernal Heights Park beckoning.

On a clear day you see it all and more. One of the most incredible views the city has to offer.

You can see the East Bay too. But you won't ever want to leave.
author: Jason B.

description: Amazing views of the San Francisco Bay Area. Really cold and windy up here too so make sure you have a jacket! Free parking but sometimes it can get tough finding an empty spot.
author: Pearl V.

description: This place bring me back home... Enjoyed the moment definetly will be back again on next visit.. Come here on the night...cheerssa
author: Yulius F.

description:
I tell you what... I've never been sooooo cold in my life!!! Except in the snow as its melting through your clothes in Chicago on a windy day... 

BUT.. if you have the courage to freeze your little booty off and use the flashlight app on your phone to find this extremely sketchy old wooden stairs that are hidden in the abyss of dirt, rocks, and semi-long dry grass (i think its grass it was dark ;-/).. then you'll love it!!!! The view is amazing and at times the chilly breeze adds to the ambiance. 

I would recommend a group or at minimum a cuddle buddy because you need some body heat. Although the other people up there with you (more lunatics like yourself that love to FREEZE on a summer night) are very friendly and they may accept you into a private huddle LOL
author: Niah N.

description:
Just a fantastic day to visit the best view in town. I took my girl here (she had never been) and she was flabbergasted (I do not get to use that word enough) at how amazing the city looked from this wonderful perch. 

The views more than made up for a mediocre lunch and set the tone for the rest of the afternoon. It's like finding your thrills on Blueberry Hill...but better!
author: Nick B.

description: Noe Valley hike to Twin Peaks, 35 mins / 1.3 mi one way: http://bit.ly/1uztyoV
author: Inigo M.

description:
It takes a long time to get there by bus but the view is worth it. The whole city is standing in front of you and it is just a magical moment.

Le bus pour accéder à Twin Peaks prend pas mal de temps pour arriver à destination mais le jeu en vaut la chandelle. La vue sur SF est tout simplement imprenable.
author: Mark B.

description:
What is there to say that hasn't been said? 

It's free to come up and free to park. 

It's a breathtaking view. 

You can watch the weather change in the different neighborhoods. Fog will roll over the Golden Gate Bridge and through the Presidio while the water by the Bay Bridge gleams blindingly in the sun. 

Yes, there are tons of tourists up there, and some can be downright rude. But there are tourists everywhere, and you just have to bear with it. At least here, there's an incredibly magnificent view.
author: Christine A.

description:
I recommend going here at least twice in your life, day and night. 

Twin peaks sits atop a hill that basically cuts SF in half. The view of north SF in the day lets you see how vast and dense such a small city can be. The view at night, well, it's not something that one can grasp from a review; sights like these must be seen for yourselves. 

No matter what time of year you go up there, at night, it is always cold. Wear your pea coats and grab your blankets, it's snuggle time!

In the winter when it is not raining or summer before the fog rolls in are the prime times to come up here for a clear view. 

Restroom tip: It never works =(

Another tip: Pantie dropper.
author: Barry H.

description: Good place to clear your head or impress your out of town familia (or the lame in town relatives who don't ever leave their house). Go get em tiger, blow them away with your amazing city.
author: Wendy N.

description: A must visit spot for all the visitors and tourists. Please make sure you are visiting this place on a clear day else you will be a little disappointed. It is as beautiful during the day as during the night on any given clear sky day :) . You can see the entire city and even the Golden gate bridge from up here. It's always a bit chilly or windy here so carrying a jacket or some is a good idea if you wish to sit and admire the scenery for a while. You can drive right to the very spot but it has very limited parking so be prepared to walk a little if you don't find a parking on the peak. There is a loo on the peak right next to the parking and parking is free.
author: Ritika S.

description:
WOW my whole life in San Francisco, I have never been here until a couple of months I discovered this place. Well I have always heard about it, but I just thought it's one of those tourist spots so who cares. But my wow my first time here I came like 2-3am in the morning and it was packed! 

It was really windy and cold! But the view is to die for. It is so pretty and you can see Market Street and everything. I loved it. Now that I have discovered this place I come here all the time with my bf and friends. It is beautiful!! Do NOT come on a foggy night though because you wont be able to see anything!

And please use the bathroom before you get up here because the bathroom they have is filthy and disgusting! It says out of service but if you push the door it opens but it seems as if it hasnt been cleaned in a long time, there was literally shit on the seat, i couldn't pee in there. It was so grosssss. 

Okay anyways enjoy the view! One time I came here and it was a hot day so the night wasn't cold at all, it was one of the best nights ever! and it's also a pretty romantic spot for the lovely couples that come up here :)
author: Alice Z.

description:
Yes, I live here on San Francisco's two boobs. Soon to be vacating at the end of this month, but it's been a pretty interesting year so far living from the best panoramic view of the Bay Area.

The key thing to remember is that you need to climb the peaks, not just park your car and sit at the binoculars along the railing. The peak furthest from the tower, where the road first breaks onto the top, is the best peak. 

Why do you ask? On a clear day, you can see all three bridges, Napa, Sausalito, Alameda, down to South Bay and across the ocean. At night, GG Bridge, Bay Bridge and the Alameda Bridge look fantastic. But if you decide to climb the first peak near the tower, then you get nothing but trees instead of a clear, microscopic GG Bridge.

As for the neighborhood...nice, safe and quiet. Plenty of parking and houses with actual backyards. Downside is the fog in the summer and the inconsistent Line 36 making my ass walk up and down the backside of Twin Peaks. Not fun. But I will miss  my backyard having the best view. 

And for those who noticed on my Yelp discovery to share....no, that is not in reference to my ass.
author: Alita M.

description:
Sometimes when I have a bad day, or I'm starting to get negative, I try to cheer myself up by thinking of the good things in my life. 

When I see the amazing view of the city from the top of Twin Peaks, I remind myself: I live in San Francisco.

Not everyone in the world can say that. People who don't live here always tell me how lucky I am to live here. I'm not gonna lie, I am very lucky. 

Looking at the lights, the busy buses and cars buzzing around, the tall buildings, the houses tightly packed together, it makes me feel so proud to say I'm a San Franciscan.
author: Sophia G.

description:
I came here last night after dinner around 10:30pm and was *blown away* by the views of the city...though the wind was strong enough to probably blow someone off the top of peak!

We were driving back home but didn't want to leave the city yet and mentioned that one of my co-workers came up here for her fiance's bday.  The bf and I thought, hey let's give it a shot and see how it is.  After driving up we found parking, though there were about 15 cars up there.  

I highly recommend coming to this place to get some ridiculous crazy awesome views of the city and bay.  With that recommendation I *highly* recommend you come bundled up since it's windy as hell (in our pics we have that "okay take the effing picture I'm freezing and it's too windy" smiles going...classic).

Bring a friend, come by yourself, bring a date, bring someone you don't like and watch them get blown off the top of the peaks (syke!...kinda), but just come and take a look at our beautiful city, you won't be sorry = )
author: Kat P.

description:
Granted, you can get fabulous views of the city from many vantage points but none so epic and serene as Twin Peaks. Yes, there will be crowds and tourists during peak hours but definitely not as much as say...the Golden Gate Park or Coit Tower. Plus...you can always hike around as there are more secluded spots with the same view.

The drive up to the peak won't take you more than 10 minutes but be braced for the strong headwinds once you reach the top. It does get windy and cold, so bring a jacket just in case. You must visit it twice...once during the day and once at night because they give you two very different views of the city. I personally enjoy the night view as the crowds are not as big.

I don't know how many times I've gone up here but this is the perfect place to bring a tourist (who could be your date as well) to give him/her that San Francisco charm. Nothing beats San Francisco...the most beautiful big city, in my opinion, in the USA.
author: David W.

description: Bwah ha ha ha!!! Meant to click on Twin Peaks bar. Not the landmark. Ha!!! Although it is also a must see.
author: Heather H.

description:
Excellent views when the air is crisp and clean. See all the way to Marin, Oakland, South Bay, where ever you please. Make sure to make you way up to the actual peaks, to get away from the tour buses and the constant clicking of shutters. Great ways to hike up the mountain, as well.

I am a bit disappointed to see the Fisherman's Wharf style hawking of goods like random souvenirs, spray paint art, crappy food trailer. The attraction of this destination are the views, and the tranquility of being detached from the busting metropolis below. I guess where there are tourists, they will follow.
author: Ray C.

description:
More great views of SF! Twin Peaks is almost like the polar opposite of the Marin Headlands. The whole of San Francisco is spread out before you, with the Bay popping through in the distance.

Lucky for us, we had a native who showed us where everything was (and got us there in the first place). The wind is quite strong up on Twin Peaks, so make sure you come prepared (scarf & jacket), otherwise you may end up having to cut your sight-seeing experience short.  Even when the sun is shining, the wind cuts through to the bone.

In short, Twin Peaks offers breathtaking views, just bundle up!
author: Eve C.

description:
A Great Escape from SF school/work life!

I've come here 5+ times and loved each and every visit! It's definitely one of my favorite Spots in the city! You can reflect about life and its extremely nice to step away from the city.

DO: Come here during the day and night.
Bring your camera, jacket, and blanket (at night)!
Bring your friends and/or significant other. 

One of my favorite times here was actually climbing up Twin Peaks! I ruined my brown boots, but it was so much fun and definitely worth the mini hike!
author: Erin M.

description:
Twin Peaks gets me sentimental because I've had a lot of memories here. With enchanting views that overlook SF in its entirety, Its definitely one of those views that make you grateful that you live in the Bay Area. It never gets old. This is definitely a tourist spot during the day, but at night you'll get some tourists + locals alike. I frequent this spot during the daytime more so during warm weather, but will come here at night in almost any weather sans fog to see the lights below. Do not come here when its foggy, it would be pointless. 

If you want to go up there early in the A.M'S to capture the sunrise over SF, you will never be up there alone. There are always people who come at a certain time till morning-& if you're from the Bay Area, you should do this at least once.

Twin Peaks definitely beats Golden Gate views. Go here if you want to capture the essence of the city.
author: Stephanie D.

description: This is by far the best night view I've seen in a really long time. You can pretty much see 360 of SF because the hill that this area is on is pretty high compared to other areas of the city. I will have to catch a glimpse of the sunset someday when I venture out to norcal.
author: Anne K.

description: On a clear it is definitely the best view within San Francisco.  Be sure to bring a sweater/jacket, as the top is definitely at the top, and is usually windy/pretty chilly.  Otherwise, enjoy some of the best views the Bay Area has to offer.
author: Mel G.

description:
The best view of all San Francisco. I give 5 stars for the view in the daytime, and give 10 stars for the view at night. Very cold yet nice windy breeze to enjoy. I recommend coming here probably every time you'd visit the bay area.

All in all, it's...FREE! 
$0.50 cents for these telescopes but you don't even need the telescope to enjoy this epic view.

Win.
author: Aaron O.

description:
My oh my, what a hike! Twin Peaks put itself on my radar as I was looking up some local flavor spots while in SFO. Reviews about the view of the city spurred me into action to put this on my list of places to visit on my self-made city hike.

Up, up and away... Twin Peaks certainly does offer a 360 degree view. From way up there you can see just about everything-the view facing downtown was especially impressive. There were also groups of families up here with their kids. I overheard one of them exclaim: "Wow! We're above the clouds! I've never been this high up before. This is so cool!" 

If you're up for a great hike, hit the streets and walk towards Twin Peaks. There's no better way to see some of the side streets and housing styles in the area. Otherwise, most people seemed to be driving to a couple of meet points. One side is but a quick trek up the side of the peak, the other, maybe a 10 minute walk uphill.
author: Wendy P.

description: One of the best place to view the entire city of San Francisco without having to get to Coit tower or the top of the office building. One a clear day and sunny day, it does get crowded and parking is challenging. I usually wait 5-10 minutes and there is a always a car that leave a spot. It does get cold and windy here even on sunny day so bring a sweater or something warm. I always wanted to hike around this peak but we always seem to rush to another tourist spot :-( Hope to come back again in the evening to enjoy the sunset. Highly recommend for local and tourists.
author: Sam M.

description:
This is an awesome place to come on a super foggy night when you and your friends are bored and not into all the other random night life events going on in the city. It's almost like you're driving into a creepy foggy forest where all the dumb kids in scary movies go to while you're screaming your head off saying "noooooooo". It's pretty entertaining trying to navigate these roads in dense fog. Definitely SF weather here. 

On a rare occasion when the weather is amazing and it's not crazy windy up here, this place is awesome. Great view of the city! Tourists and locals always come up here. Most of the time I think it's pretty windy though so make sure you bring a jacket.
author: Kim P.

description:
Amazing view of SF.

My first time here was in 2009 when my friends and I went after Prom. Went back again twice this year with my girl, it's always a breathtaking place to visit.

Just make sure to bring a thick jacket and wear layers when you're here at night since it gets freeeeeezing. It's hard to enjoy such a great view when you're body keeps getting harassed by such cold weather. Also, don't bother going during cloudy days, you'll barely be able to see anything at all.
author: Oliver D.

description:
If there were gates at the edge of heaven, you could see it here.

Above the mountains, beneath the marine filled clouds and somewhere softly in the middle, is a carved-out stepping stone for many to stand upon, and behold. 

Above the electric lit playground and shave-crafted cement, stands more than a city. 

Between the lights are black river alleys; darker than night itself. Men and women, sons & daughters of history, dance below the mid-moon that shine upon their heels.

Cow-hollow knights and hipster princes trek the play and field.
Soulfulness emanates from a western edition of gentrified souls.

Warmth rises from the planet, wraps about us like a blanket. I could stare in her earthen eyes all the day long.

Vanilla swirls curl in her hair...
The looking glass of humanity at a distance
Beyond the pioneering of a settlers imagination
A reach without touch.. A view with rare distinction; maps and mazes to find your way home.
author: Christopher L.

description:
ABSOLUTELY SPECTACULAR.. especially on a clear night!! The stars seem so close and so bright and youre in absolute awe just staring at them. And the city lights? WOW, just beautiful.

The panoramic views you get of SF- day or night also allow awesome photo ops. 

If youve not been here yet, I suggest you go. Such a nice place to "get away" from the hustle and bustle of the city.

But then again, it's just my opinion..
author: Christine M.

description:
ive been to many sight seeing far up on many mountains..

but this would be the best view, morning and night.
its soo beautiful up here and it can make you forget about all your problems for that moment. 

this is a must see for everyone
author: Holly V.

description: Beautiful scenic view overlooking the entire San Francisco city. Check the weather before going up as it may be cold/rainy/windy and that would ruin the experience. Definitely bring a camera to take some beautiful photos!
author: Matthew P.

description: The view of San Francisco from Twin Peaks is absolutely amazing on a clear sunny day! Note that it has to be sunny and clear. I went up here once on a rainy day and it was a complete waste of my time. If you're a tourist and don't know what to do in the city, COME HERE. Even if you don't drive, you can easily get here on a public bus. Make sure to bring an extra sweater because it can get kind of windy and cold on certain days.
author: Kwoky L.

description: I'm a Bay Area native and I had never heard about Twin Peaks until recently. After hearing about the amazing views that you can see of the East Bay and San Francisco, I knew I had to go check it out. So, this past weekend, I dragged my fiance and I across the Bay to San Francisco to walk around Twin Peaks. The area is very easy to get to by car. Fittingly, the Twin Peaks area is located in the Twin Peaks neighborhood. As you get closer, there are signs to keep you going in the right direction. There is ample parking. Lots of tourists are around depending on what time of day and week and year you go. The view is amazing, especially on a clear day, like the day that we went. The area is dog friendly. The actual twin peaks are great to climb. Each peak has two sets of stairs and from the top of each peak, you are rewarded with the view. Great place to go if you have out of town visitors or if you are a local who wants to check out the view. Will have to go back again at night to see what the view is like then!
author: Irene L.

description:
The best view of the city bar none. This is exactly why I think S.F. has L.A. beat when it comes to being a beautiful city. On a clear beautiful day, you can literally get lost and just look in awe to what the bay has to offer as far as sights goes.

This is one "tourist trap" I love going to. "Local flavor" to the fullest. One view (Signal Hill) in Long Beach, somewhat offers the same, but overall, Twin Peaks just about trumps it all together.

This is one place I would frequent if I lived in the City. I would just take in the view and the serenity of the city. The other cool thing, it's FREE. No charging for parking, to walk around, nothing. Even though there might be others here, I just felt like I can breath and just enjoy winding down from a long day's work (or being a super tourist in my situation). S.F.ers, I envy you guys for having such a wonderful spot such as this to call your own.
author: Wes S.

description: It's always so cold here! But it is San Francisco. Beautiful view, a must-go-to if you're around the area and have time.
author: Carmen T.

description:
mandatory tourist destination if you're visiting San Francisco. 

With a full Friday to spend sightseeing, my buddies and I made our way from SF to Muir Woods, back down to Sausalito, and wrapped our day of driving up with a trip to Twin Peaks. Wow - what a cool experience. Amazing view of the city and a must-see sorta place if you're visiting the Bay Area. Would even come back if I'm visiting San Francisco again!

Also, super surprised we were able to get a parking spot late on a Friday afternoon.
author: Joe M.

description: When @karlthefog isn't visiting SF, this spot gives you the most amazing views of the city!  If you want an amazing photo op, drive the windy road up to Twin Peaks where you can park and marvel at the beautiful city of San Francisco.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Fantastic place to feel like you're on top of the Bay Area without having to board aircraft.  Obviously it's better if you come on a sunny day but expect to share the view with a lot more people than usual because of it.  But that's ok because people are pretty good about not getting in your pictures and staying out of each other's way - this is not a place where you want to tumble.

A fun game my family and I did was to try and distinguish the different neighborhoods from each other.

I would recommend shifting your car into a lower gear, on your way up and down for a few reasons:  one, there's a chance you're part of a procession and it wouldn't be smart to speed demon your way through the two-lane road; two, mainly for on your way down, you don't want to burn your brakes; and three, driving slower allows you to take in the view before/after reaching the top.

Just a suggestion.
author: Connie M.

description:
In college, we'd take visitors up to Twin Peaks at night to take in the view. Thus all my memories of the place include being tightly packed into someone's Dodge Neon only to arrive at Twin Peaks and nearly freeze in the whipping winds before it was time to pile back in the car. This may explain why it had been some time since my last visit. 

Last week, though, I saw a completely fresh and fantastic side of Twin Peaks. As it was on my visiting German cousin's list of things to see, I drove him up on a particularly warm and sunny day. I discovered that Twin Peaks is SO much nicer during the day. Sort of makes you wonder why everyone goes there at night. . .
author: Miriam W.

description: On a perfectly clear day or night this place rocks. If it's foggy, which it frequently is, don't bother.
author: Michael S.

description: This is out of the way to get to but worth the effort.  I've seen pictures from the peaks before but no picture can compare with being there live and having all of San Francisco below you.  What a fantastic feeling, this is really a million dollar view that anyone can get.
author: Al E.

description:
Awwwwwwwwwww man, I thought I wrote a review of this already. I guess not. Anyway, thanks Myko for your review cuz I went to look. Anyway, hubby used to like driving up here to sit and do nothing. It was coooooooold as hell on most days, even during the summer so we always sat there with our jackets on freezing our asses off.

But the view.............

.......... ahhhhh the view............

That is what it's all about!!
author: Anita L.

description:
If you're lucky and arrive on a bright and sunny, clear day (like my boyfriend and I did), then the sights are spectacular!

Just be forewarned that despite the sunshine, you're still in SF and it's damn chilly when you're up that high.  

So remember to bring a coat, a camera, and your loved one(s).  This is definitely an SF spot that shouldn't be missed!
author: Alma R.

description:
Came here at the suggestion of Judy M aka JUma...thank you j.

I was able to 1up my sister...on "HER" stomping grounds...crazy, huh?

This has got to be the best panoramic view, hands down, of any city I've ever seen ! ! Really, I mean, you could see it all ! ! From the Golden Gate Bridge and Park on the left, all the way to parts unknown on the right...and then all the B.S. sandwiched in the middle !

It was midday Sunday, clear beautiful weather. My sister even stated that you could see all the way to San Jose...ok...thanks Ms. Warwick.

Anyways, a sight too beautiful to pass up. If yer in the area, drop by, even if it's not sunny. I BET, even in unfavorable weather conditions, Twin Peaks will still, somehow, manage to make San Pancho look nice...hahahahahahahahaha...as I drive my azz back to L.A. down the 5 South...thank gawd.
author: chico f.

description:
Best view of San Francisco on a sunny day or a clear night. 

If the weather is foggy, don't waste your time driving up to Twins Peak. You will not be able to see anything! 

I would probably say its one of the most popular area for tourists and couples. Especially couples at night. I never been there to hook up but i heard stories from my friends that they have seen two legs up in the air in  the backseat of a car. 

you get the picture. :)
author: Carol Y.

description:
This is a definite must-visit for anyone and everyone who ever steps foot onto San Francisco. The view is breathtaking. Just make sure it's not foggy, and it would probably help if you wore extra layers because it can get really cold up there. I go here for the view, but others myave have other reasons: biking, making out, "getting away"...

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description: LOVE this place... U will have full view of San Francisco.  I could spend hours here just looking at the beauty of San franscisco. Just make sure You take ur jacket with. It can get windy and foggy!!!
author: Amy S.

description:
Having moved to the Bay area from Toronto, I've had a few visitors so touring around SF has become a normal thing.  I always bring or recommend that they check out Twin Peaks for fantastic views of the city.  
While it's not difficult to get to, you definitely need a car.  The way up winds up around the peak and there isn't too much parking so I can only assume during tourist season it gets packed. However, the couple of times I went (once in September and then in November) parking was never an issue in the early afternoon.  
Best of all, it's free so it's a win-win - free & awesome views of the city.
author: Tanya N.

description: Visited this place during Thanksgiving weekend.  The weather was very nice so there was clear visibility in every direction for miles.  The parking can be rough though on weekends so expect to possibly make a small hike to the top.  However, people do come and go at a decent interval so getting parking right at the top isn't too far fetched.  One thing I noticed that there are multiple signs that say no big trucks or buses allowed near the top but that doesn't seem stop the five buses I saw on my short visit at the top park themselves for the tourists and block the road practically.  All in all, its a great thing to do in town whether you are a tourist or a native.  Seeing the view from the top and taking in the scenery of the entire bay area as far as the eye can see is pretty inspirational and serene.
author: David A.

description:
Love the place got engaged there :)
sometimes the fog can be too much and with the height of the peak you need to have an extra layer of clothing or have a spring jacket or sweater or something as it can get windy and cold up there. but on a clear day without any fog or clouds you would just love the place.
author: J P.

description: Love this place always a stop when visitors are in town, but make sure its not cloudy or foggy and it gets windy.
author: Don I.

description: Beautiful views to be had. Best when not foggy to see sunrise or sunset, or both as you can see both the east and west clearly.
author: Nicholas W.

description: Beautiful views of the city - even cooler at night when the city is all lit up. Bring a jacket/extra layers as it's pretty windy up there.
author: Christine C.

description:
If it's a foggy day... forget it. You're not gonna see shit.

However, if it's a clear day? An absolute must. The views are breathtaking and your out of town visitors will eat this shit up. Or, just snaps hundreds of pics, same difference. And on a clear night this really does make for a romantical date.

And to echo Janney B's review, if you're looking for some exercise there are some KILLER hills up here. Buns of Steel ain't got nothing on these streets.

This is also my hood, which means the famous Twin Peaks view is what I get to see everyday out of my bedroom and living room windows. Booya, bitches.
author: Leilani H.

description:
I've been coming here for years. 
Still and forever will be the BEST view of SF and all around the Bay.
Make sure you're dressed warm, have blankets at hand, and a cup of hot chocolate because it gets super cold up there.
author: Criselle O.

description:
Do not miss this site if you visit San Francisco.

You see the whole city from above and it rocksssss.

Do not forget your camera.  There are many great photo opportunities.
author: Alexis B.

description:
An amazing view, one to be seen at least once before you exit this earth.

I was surprised. We found ourselves here one weekend, at about sunset. And the view along with the cool coastal breeze just seemed to make it memorable. Enjoying what you see, having a cup of Joe in hand, I was floored. I adore the city and all of it's eclecticism. This was the topper for me. To see it all come together right before my eyes. 

Twin Peaks is a pair of hills which rests upon the highest point in the city. Overlooking all of what the city has to offer. It's owned by SF's recreation and park's development who strive to preserve and maintain the city's remaining endangered wildlife and habitat. 

Tourist trap #901, check!
author: Irma E.

description:
Great place to take in the most amazing views of the entire city.  It's even better if you have a honey to go with and enjoy the romantic views.

It's the perfect place to take out of towners to get a true sense of the city and point out the various neighborhoods and spots.  It's windy, as it's the highest point in the city, so hold on tight while you're up there.  But it's worth it!  The beautiful sights really are breathtaking.
author: Jen K.

description:
Best 360 view of SF! the drive was lovely too as you enjoy the residential area on winding slopes and curvy streets. we found parking right away and if you don't find it, then just wait b/c people don't stay long. we hung around for about 30 minutes. we also climbed the small hill near the view point where we got a 360 view of SF @ daytime. I would love to return at night. the climb to the hill was a little steep but nothing 3 girls in sandals can't handle.
BRING JACKETS, SWEATERS, HATS, GLOVES. it is windy and the coldest I felt in SF.
author: Tiana F.

description:
Woohoo! The view is as good as it gets! Hiked up here the other day from Golden Gate Park...it was quite the trek, and a bit suburban for a classic hike (haha, it's SF!) but totally worth the panoramic view of the city at the top. On a clear day you can also see Oakland, Berkeley, Marin County, and South San Francisco. 
I can't believe I waited so long to check it out!
author: Leigh W.

description:
I"M THE KING OF THE WORLD!!!

What's that? I'm NOT Leonardo DiCaprio? 

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WV2fVK6OJfzn2BkRGpbP7A?select=EleDGVUJ5xDmB7H5wYJEvA
author: Kenny L.

description: My must-go place whenever i serve as tour guide when people visit.
author: Ashley C.

description: Twin peaks offers a great panoramic view of San Francisco. It never fails to make me realize what a great city I live in whenever I come up here. Watching the sun rise here is magnificent! You'll feel like you're on top of the world watching San Francisco wake up as the sun brightens up the city. The night view up here is unbeatable on a clear night. Do dress warm as it does get windy and chilly up here. From up here you can see the Bay Bridge and Golden Gate Bridge. You can see how big this small city really is.
author: Jenny G.

description: It is such a sight to be up there and be able to see all of the city. Bring a jacket because it can get COLD up there. Also drive safely because there are some tight turns up and down the peak and it can get really FOGGY. Be safe!
author: Wilson T.

description: Like all the other reviews said, great view of the city.  Glad I was able to visit on a crisp, clear day.  Romantic!  Especially since it can get a little chilly...nice to snuggle up to a loved one!
author: Jennifer A.

description:
4/5 light up my life

i like to imagine that all the lights are people, and you feel connected to a city in a glance.
author: Alvin D.

description:
This is a beautiful outlook...if it's not cloudy or raining. I've been here at 5am during an all night scavenger hunt around the Bay Area and the city lights are gorgeous. I've also been here around 4pm on a cloudy day and the city looks drab.

You'll see plenty of tour buses during the day drive by with tourists who want to take an obligatory photo. My preference would be to pull up a car, hang out a bit, and see what happens to the sky. Conditions change quickly in SF, and the clouds we experienced on a Saturday quickly burned off...and then rolled back in again. If we didn't stay 30+ minutes, I doubt we would've got decent photos. 

Definitely a fun place to bike and walk around. There's also a small hot dog vendor who makes a killing.
author: Reid Y.

description:
I stumbled upon this little gem one night in the city. Atop Twin Peaks you will get the most amazing panoramic views of San Francisco, you can see everything, from downtown San Francisco, The Bay Bridge, The Golden Gate Bridge, and even parts of the East Bay. This place is most amazing at night, and if you're looking for a place to come hang out with friends, see great views of the bay, or take your special someone for something romantic this is a cool little place to come.

There is parking available at the top (free parking) and telescopes available to those who care to use them. It is quite windy and cold up top but very much worth the view. Make sure to bring jackets and sweaters to keep warm.
author: Tony R.

description:
Come here for a fantastic view of SF. But don't come here on a cloudy/foggy day .. you won't see much and you'll have a horrible time trying to drive up the hill. And bring a jacket cuz it's going to be cooooold!

Last time I came here right after sunset, and the fog was already rolling in and starting to obscure our views. Wish we had gotten here a bit earlier.

Next time, I'm going to come with some friends and hike up one of the peaks. :)
author: Eric C.

description: We checked this out on a whim on our vacation and we are so glad that we did. Drive up for an awesome view of the city. When we were there it was super foggy, but the city would appear every once and awhile. Bring a jacket - super windy and cold.
author: Amanda M.

description:
Beautiful! Friends and I came over here to kill some time before we went to have dinner..

Make sure you bring a very warm jacket or you'll freeze to death! Fantastic view of the sunset.I love it!
author: Wendy T.

description: A must for anyone new to SF, especially at night. Drive down the Castro to Mission for best effect.
author: George T.

description:
The best view!!! Twin peaks has a fantastic view of San Francisco and the rest of the Bay Area! It can get pretty crowded (long line of cars) but totally worth it. Make sure you bring a jacket and maybe some gloves, it gets windy and COLD up there, especially at night! You can always park your car and look from there, but you have to get out and walk up to the wall to really see the whole thing. It's AMAZING. Try to come during the night and during the day as well. Bring your camera!

The view is really breathtaking, you must go here if you can! Especially if you live in the bay area and have never been here!
author: Raizel G.

description:
I recommend coming here at sunset or at night because the view is gorgeous! You're really high up and can see all of San Francisco and the bay. The night I was visiting, it was extremely clear (not foggy at all!) and there was a firework show near the Golden Gate Bridge, so that added a little something to my experience as well.

Breath-taking.
author: Katherine T.

description: This is hard to get to without a car or tour bus. It was a super troop to get up to the peak, there is a definite view of the city but i've experienced better!
author: Angela L.

description:
Many friends suggested we visit Twin Peaks on our trip, but stressed that we should not go if it were foggy out--they say that driving up to Twin Peaks can be dangerous in the fog. Luckily for us, it was not foggy, only gray when we went. It is really a beautiful place... I only wish we had sunshine so we could capture the city better. 

Would absolutely come back again, especially if it's sunny.
author: Janny W.

description:
Really beautiful view of the WHOLE Bay Area.  Go on a clear day, not a foggy day.  Great place to bring some beers and watch the sunset with your sweetheart.  Actually I had sex in this parking lot at night quite a few times when I still lived at home.  Oh...the good ol' days.

The toilet there takes quarters...so bring quarters or you're screwed, lol.  One time I went and the part where you put quarters into was all jammed up and it wouldn't open.  We had to leave because my friend had to go pee.  Lame.  They need a public toilet there with multiple toilets.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
I love you twin peaks.
You have provided me with so many memories.. both good and bad.
The view is truly amazing.. I've taken so many non-SF folks up here and their eyeballs looked like they popped outta their heads! I enjoy the reactions and the "wows".
Just don't go up on a foggy night.. cause obviously you can't see anything and it's kinda pointless.
Everything and anything goes on up there.. so beware ;)
author: Tiff C.

description:
This is an incredible view of the city - breathaking! 

A great first stop on a tour of the city.  Visitors are always awed.  We have taken friends day or night and they are always amazed.

You can count on it being very windy and cold, so dress in layers.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
Visited today when the city was beautiful and clear (just after the high winds came through the Bay Area).

Awesome views of the city, SF Bay and on the other side, the Pacific Ocean!

We will come here one day to catch the sunset!
author: James W.

description: A great way to capture great shots of the city at night. Make sure you bring a jacket.
author: Jeremy E.

description: Better luck tomorrow...one of my few visits to SF and it's super overcast, which meant almost zero visibility! Ugh. There were a few breaks, but in general, super windy, cold and bleak up on the peaks. I had to use my imagination (ugh), but I saw through my mind's eye just how incredible the view would've been if it weren't for all the low climate. Will definitely have to come back here next time. Err...
author: Peter D.

description:
This is for KIDS! Bring the toddlers up on a super windy day (most days are, anyway).  Point them INTO the wind, and let them gulp in air. It just slams up those little pug noses. Hilarious! Fun! 

This is what my dad did with us. We thought it was almost as fun as Playland at the Beach.
author: Nini M.

description: We came here in the late mid afternoon and it was very clear! There were alot of tourists, parking is small but we got one right away.  The drive up is somewhat windy but its not unbearable.  Once you get to the top and out of the car, you have a amazing view of the city!  It was a clear day but u could see th fog rolling in very slowly from the right.  It is also very windy and cold (and I'm from Hawaii) so bring a jacket!  Great photo op! A must do if you want to do sightseeing in the city!
author: Crystal A.

description: The best place to go to at anytime with very spectacular views. This is another one of the best tourist attraction points!
author: Bennett W.

description:
As someone who lives in the area, I'm a little biased towards the oh-so-awesome Twin Peaks. 

You can't do the view justice - simply know that you can climb up the hills (or stay down on a smaller vista) and look at everything that San Francisco and the Bay have to offer. It's simply amazing and something that every SF resident should check out. 

Why four stars? The trash. Shards of glass are littered on the top of the peaks, around the trails and just about everywhere else. For a town so eco-friendly, it's a pretty disappointing sight. Maybe additional trash cans would help solve this problem, or even a city official or two? 

Go check out, and make sure to wear some shoes!
author: Tom A.

description: Another great San Francisco landmark and vantage point of the city. The drive to Twin Peaks is very easy and I have never dealt with traffic or parking issues. I have come up here during the morning, noon, and nighttimes and it's been flawless. The views from Twin Peaks is incredible but do not come here on a foggy night. You will see nothing but fog and it can get very cold and windy up there. Great snapshots and cool telescopes to literally see people walking up and down Market street shopping for fruits or getting drunk. Might I add, there is a bathroom conveniently located here as well!
author: Danster L.

description:
After raining all day (literally!!!), my bf and I drove up here to see the fantastic view of the city.  He couldn't believe that I'd never been to this spot, especially being a bay area native. I know, sad.

Anyways, there weren't many people here, since the weather was horrible all day, however...we totally lucked out because it was such a nice clear night.  The view was beautiful.  We were actually able to see the Golden Gate with no problem at all.

My bf had been up here a couple of times, and he said it was by far one of the clearest nights ever. I was really glad to share that moment and view with my bf.

This spot is a very romantic place to take your loved one... =D
author: Connie C.

description:
Lived in San Francisco for 18 years and visited Twin Peaks 5 years later! Wow.
Bf and I came here on labor day and was lucky enough to catch the sun set.  The view up here was spectacular.  A 360 degree view of the city.  Wear comfortable shoes and bring a jacket with you.  The walk/climb up could be difficult and rocky.  It gets really chilly once you're up and a jacket would definitely keep you warm and comfortable to stay for for a few more minutes!  Wished we would have came later the night to see the city lit up with all the lights.  Saw pictures on yelp and they look so pretty!  So do plan wisely folks and you would not regret taking a trip up here.
author: Lily M.

description:
Stunning views and ample parking at twin peaks.  A great view of the city and the bay during the day or at night.  I will have to say that the view from East Bay's Grizzly Peak is more stunning in terms of the bay as a whole, but lacks the city view like Twin Peaks has. 

Play a game at night and see if you can find a person wandering the streets from up there.
author: Steven T.

description: great place to hike and a great view! recommended for anyone visiting SF!
author: Karen K.

description: Awesome views.  20 minute parking at the circular lot.  .50 cent for telescope viewing.
author: Jboogie L.

description: One of the best view spots in the city! Was a tad bit tricky to find but it's absolutely lovely! Just make sure to bring a hoodie, it can get pretty cold & windy!
author: Alexandra U.

description: The road up to here is scary so minus a star. But the view is spectacular! This place is romantic @ night but sometimes there are rowdy kids smoking up there too.
author: Brenda L.

description: You need a car to get there, no way, and be ready to the chilly weather up there... but this is THE BEST PLACE in San Francisco... I'm serious.. you could spend hours there watching the City and the Bay Area from those hills... especially if you go during Sunset and Night... GORGEOUS!
author: Andrea M.

description:
Good view! But very cold up here! this is san fran, so most the time it will be covered in fog anyway. when will san fran EVER have a warm clear day's sky right?! 
there's parking up there but just a few spots
author: Veranna N.

description:
Ahh a beautiful spot in SF to overlook the whole city. Ive been here twice, once at night and once during the day. I definitely recommend coming during the day, the view is a lot nicer (though a lot less romantic) but at least you get to see every building in its full essence instead of tiny
dots of lights. I recommend bringing a jacket, no matter how sunny SF looks that day, its always windy and chilly up at where the twin peaks are. Careful not to get blown away if you're sitting on the edge to overlook the city.
author: Evelyn S.

description:
FREE views of SF...

Easy to find with signs getting there.
I suggest going there during the day and when it's not foggy.

Went at night, and it's hard to point things out and it's really dark and scary.
author: Realtor Karl B.

description: Been up here a few times, on cloudy nights and clear nights. Make sure to go on clear nights, it's truly beautiful, one of my favorite spots to take pictures and just chill back.  Although it's always been super cold and windy, but it's worth it!
author: Timothy N.

description: I loved the first time I came here. Definitely a good spot to go with your BF/GF or wife/ husband. BUT also really great for ANYONE! It's so beautiful, especially at night. I would recommend it to everyone
author: Elenie V.

description: Fantastic views, go on a clear day to see all of north/east san francisco and east bay (including neighboring oakland!)
author: Will D.

description: Great views of the city, awesome panoramic view for picture taking, but bring a sweater or blanket, it gets chilly!
author: Debi B.

description: It's FREE, fairly easy to find, pretty good view of the Transamerica Pyramid. It was windy on the day I went. There was some fog so part of the view was obscured. If you are alittle bit brave, you can climb down and stand under the viewing area that has those telescopes. It's shaded and a great windbreak.
author: Winston W.

description:
I never imagined that you can review sites.  This is "as good as it gets".  There are two peaks, and the most popular one is the north one because you can see downtown and the golden gate bridge.

The people up there are super friendly also.  When I was there, many offered to take pictures for you, so I tried to do the same.
author: Joan K.

description:
The drive up here is a bit nerve wrecking but I have to say that this is the best place to make out with someone and/or bring your significant other/person you're dating/person you're knocking boots with.  The view here is absolutely stunning --it really does make you appreciate living in the Bay Area.  

It's insanely freezing up here so bring a snuggie to cuddle up in --that or create some body heat ;)
author: Brenda T.

description:
As much as I love the East Bay Regional Parks and Mt. Diablo, I've got to get out of the 'burbs sometimes and go on an urban hike for a change. After a great lunch in Noe Valley, we followed the walking directions up to Twin Peaks, via the stairs on Douglass and then up Romain and Corbett. It didn't take too long but the majority is uphill, so got a good workout on the way up. Loved seeing all the houses and gardens along the way.
Once to the peaks, we hiked up and down each one.  The climb up from Noe Valley to the lots near Twin Peaks was actually more strenous than the peaks themselves.  But once up there-the most awesome views of the city I've seen yet. Love the view straight down Market where you can see the flag in the Castro all the way down to the Ferry Building. 
Found another place I can take out of town visitors for spectacular city views-although they will probably prefer driving over hiking. Not too many tourists on the day I went (except if you count me, since I'm from the East Bay)
Go in March if you can-some very pretty wildflowers are in bloom.
Pretty awesome day and "hike" (if you can call it that)
author: Jennifer N.

description: Best view of the city especially at sunset. It's really windy (regardless of the hot weather) so bring a jacket. Amazing place for photos (for sunrise and sunset) and a great place for romantic date overlooking the entire landscape of San Francisco. I climbed to the top of the small mountain to take some great shots of the sunset.
author: Gina T.

description:
Quotes from visitors I have taken up to the top of Twin Peaks (even on a foggy day):

"Wow!"

"No way!"

"No fuckin' way!"

"Holy shit!"

"Holy fuckin' shit!"

"This is incredible!"

"This is fuckin' incredible!"

"Damn, Sam!"
author: Jeff P.

description:
GORGEOUS, ROMANTIC!

A nice precursor if you, eh hem, you wanna get some later that night!

but i do have some requests::
-people, please do not bring your kids here! they will run around and chase eachother on the cliff annoying couples who are trying to enjoy the scenery, and all you will be doing the entire time is yelling at them to get back on the sidewalk. 
-people with the subs in the car - this is NOT the place to bumpin Lil Wayne, Eminem, or R. Kelly. you are not flaunting anything, you are being a nuissance!
author: The Fuzzies S.

description:
I think it's the best view of San Francisco. It's really breathtaking and you just can't imagine it until you have experienced it. Also a fun drive up the hill. Good luck finding parking on busy days!

You can see all the way from the Golden Gate Bridge to Bernal Heights and everything in between.
author: Chris I.

description: Beautiful view. Parking not too bad on a Friday night. Smell some reefer, see some LED lights In a dude's car. Love that there's self cleaning toilets right by the view.
author: Deanna L.

description:
Such a beautiful sight to see. 

Whenever friends comes to visit the routine is always to shop downtown, happy hours, deserts at Ghirardelli square, then finished off with a view of the city at Twin Peaks. The last piece is always the best because it's such an amazing view, particularly at night with a clear sky.
author: Meuy S.

description: Great spot to just chill, check out the views, clear your mind, and enjoy a sunny day in the City. And best of all, it's free.
author: Jeziell B.

description:
A BIG 5-Star post for the view at the top of Twin Peaks. The BEST view of the Bay Area--hands down! You can see everything from the top of the peaks... all of Marin, Golden Gate Park, downtown and the ocean. It is so nice and peaceful. It is a great spot to run if you want to get in a quick 5K or if you want to do some hills... especially in the morning before the crowds congregate. You definitely won't be bored with your surroundings. 

The only downside up here, is that people really trash the area. Being that I live in the hood, it's super annoying to see this day after day happening. Visitors come up the peaks to enjoy the view and a beverage of choice, which is all well and good; however, no one seems to clean up after themselves. It is so sad to see all the broken glass on the paths. Has anyone heard of recycling and/or a trash can?!?
author: Nichole P.

description:
I prefer the north boob.

Mostly, I wish I were a dolphin. But times like these, I wish I were one of those deep sea fish with those bulging eyes that could magically exist above water so my extraordinary peripheral vision could take in the sweeping vistas so wasted on my human faculties. 

Windy days require layers and warm head gear for top trekking. People shouldn't be able to call themselves San Franciscans without a visit both day and night.
author: Ligaya T.

description:
It's hard to hate on twin peaks. This seems to be a great place to take your friends and relatives when they're in town. 

Be warned: if you see any fog wherever you live, don't even bother going as you will NOT be able to see a damn thing at the top. 

On a clear day, the view is amazing. 

If you're a local, you'll probably be ok going there once, taking a picture and never going back.
author: Carlos A.

description:
Great views of the city.  Nice walk up.

Minus a star because there is no sidewalk walking up and the cars drive too fast.
author: Jean K.

description: It is what it is. Love the windows, people watching at its best. Friendly patrons great bartenders. I popped in around 8ish so I go upstairs to the Ladies room after finding out it was upstairs. No biggie but very narrow staircase and a gentleman was sitting at a stool right near the staircase um ok so I get there the bathroom was a DISASTER !!!  Toilet paper everywhere including the toilet. BUT it smelled FABULOUS !!! Why??? Luckily HOT COOKIE is next door. Needless to say I held it. I'll wait till I get home I did go get some cookies and saw some cute girls outside. -2 stars for that hot mess good thing Hot Cookie came thru the vents!
author: A P.

description: Great views of the city! Went at night. Sooo romantical;) Take a blanket something warm to drink, grab a spot along the wall and enjoy!
author: Adri H.

description:
Ugh... I cant even begin to explain the beauty of the city when youre up here. I used to go to Twin Peaks at least three times a week, and each time its beauty engulfed me. Go at night with a jacket and a group of people(can get a little dangerous and scary), and I promise your breath will have left you for a vacation. The first time I saw it at night I -- well I teared up from the sight of the city lit so beautifully... Call me a wimp, I dont care!!! ;) Its also fun making a game of finding landmarks in city. 

One of my favorite spots in the city!!! Tourists: this is a must see!
author: Joey H.

description: The best view you can get of sf. Holy crap the view. Came here and was disappointed it was foggy, but a few seconds later, BAM fog gone, clear view. Ive been to other views where I had to drive hills and hills to get there but this was by far the best drive. Quick and right to the spot. I went on a friday morning and there was pretty much no one there. One of the best spots in sf, for sure.
author: Steve N.

description:
I love it. All the tourists are up there with their telescopic cameras....damm I think I got in the way of a few pictures..haha oh well..
ATTENTION ALL TOURISTS: Please take a warm jacket and stop complaining that it is cold---you are in San Francisco not Honolulu...thank you!

Oh yeah..and make sure you go with people you like because you just my get the urge to send them rolling down the hill to see how fast they can go..hahaha...

Husbands: Please be nice to your wife because you may just end up slipping
author: Jessica M.

description: Probably the best view of the city. Downside is you have to come on a clear day, otherwise it's not worth the trek (which you need a GPS for - windy roads). Parking is ok. They have one or two artists selling paintings or other crafts. Although the view is awesome, it's often too cold or hazy/foggy to enjoy.
author: Isabella L.

description: Wanna take pictures? Go here. Wanna go for a drive? Go here. It's usually not super packed and you get a great view of the city. Take my family visitors here all the time.
author: Paul V.

description:
Kudos to my Costco-discounted, non-upgradable GPS for getting me up to Twin Peaks.  I was first in search of Sutro Tower for some photography (why?  Sounds like Sutra?  I dunno).  Anywayz, after the disappointingly bad Kama from the tower, I cast my view upward and saw cars going around in circles high up on the hill.  Poke the touch screen and the computer lady from Star Trek guides me up there.  

Totally clear day, great, clear view down Market Street from (seemingly) the only  Safeway in town, all the way to the Ferry Plaza Building.  Clean, fresh air, too, if I manage to hold my breath when the smoking tourists exhale.  Get yourself up there any way you can, hike up the small hills and get your tiny bit of exercise for the day.  I certainly did, with 30lbs of camera equipment in tow.
author: Wayne Q.

description:
Why it took me three years to get to Twin Peaks I will never know...  Absolutely stunning 360 view of the city and surrounding areas.  I'd suggest walking up both peaks for the best view - plus, it seemed the peaks had a much smaller crowd than the parking area.  Simply put: a must see.  

We caught the tail end of the wildflowers, too, and I am thankful for that.  My dog, who I think is a closet vegan, ate a few, then gave 'em a good Bax squirt so his fellow canines would know he was there. 

Great spot for a date, picnic, good walk, or a book read.  It wasn't too windy today, so I really lucked out.  Judging from some of the other reviews, it can be hit or miss here.  

I will echo what a few others have said - take care of this spot.  If you take a bunch of trash up there, take it back down with you.  Don't be a douche-bag and leave it all over the place, it's not going to go anywhere and no one else is going to pick it up.  I carried a bag full of Baxter's fresh deuce all the way back down, so I think you can carry down your garbage as well.
author: Sean O.

description:
The view from Twin Peaks is gorgeous.  Pretty sure I've now been 3 or four times in the past 9ish months.  Sadly, I had lived here almost four years before even checking it out! 

There are 360 degrees views of the entire city. Golden Gate Bridge, Bay Bridge, Palace of the Fine Arts, Coit Tower, etc etc etc.  I'm not sure a bus goes there, so a car is ideal for making this trip.  

There are no bathrooms up there, it's really friggin' windy and cold, but is now a favorite place to take the out of town guests.
author: Jenny W.

description:
Everyone always likes to brag about how they've had raunchy ass sex here. 

Ok. and?

Oh yea and this place looks nice on a clear night in SF. Stunning I might say.
author: Andrew W.

description:
I might be freezing my ass off while checking out the scenery here... but it's all worth it.

Why? CAUSE I LOVE IT HERE.

The city lights. Van Ness Strip(?) brightly visible. The Bay Bridge. The Golden Gate Bridge. The Bay... It's the whole shabang of San Francisco right in front of my own eyes.

The drive up to the top of the mountain is my favorite too :)

I have yet to come here during a sunset, but I will. One day. How amazing and beautiful would that be?
author: Annie S.

description: One of the places I always bring visitors, hopefully twice so they can see it in daytime and at night.
author: John G.

description:
I used to live across the way in Diamond Heights and I loved the views I had there...but on those very rare, cloudless nights my friends and I would come up here to gaze at the City.

Still gorgeous!
author: Carina M.

description:
A friend introduced me to this view about 6 years ago. Couldn't believe she knew it before I did. Now it's the place where I take all of my dates haha...jk.. Funny how thing shifts sides.

Great view but don't wonder around too much over the wall of rocks...you'd run into a few suprises. such as: used ehem, broken and empty bottles, etc.

seriously this place is amazing. I even designed a poster and a book about this place...check the photos. :D.
author: Gerard L.

description: Not convenient by public transportation, nor close to anything else, but if you go on a clear day the view is unbeatable.
author: Madeline S.

description:
You know those scenes in movies where people can look out over their whole city? Twin Peaks is my first experience of actually being able to do that, and it gives me a wonderful sense of perspective, as well as being a breath-taking spot day or night.

Not to be missed!
author: Darrien A.

description:
Most people come up to Twin Peaks for the fabulous 270 degree views of San Francisco, and on a clear day, those are certainly awesome. (On a clear night, they are even more awesome.) The actual peaks are usually nothing much to look at.

That changes on sunny days in spring. It's covered in wildflowers: the yellows of oxalis and mustard; the pure orange of California poppy and the tangerine of what looks like calendula; the purple spikes of lupines; and from time to time, there's a sweet honey scent from the wild alyssum. Bees, butterflies if you're lucky, and white-crowned sparrows are out enjoying the flowers.
