Go soon if you want to see this. From March 2-16, 2010, before noon, they're spraying toxic herbicides over it all.
author: RK B.

description:
Long-story short: Twin Peaks may or may not be the home of the Pirate Overlord of San Fransisco.

Short-story long: So we're driving through the Castro, on our way to Twin Peaks. The sun is out, the windows are down, we're full of truffles and ice cream, Michael Franti's 'Say Hey(I Love You)' is on the radio, hawt gay guys are blowing me kisses at traffic stops (no joke) and needless to say...it's a blissful Sunday afternoon.

Being the wannabe-pseudo-crunchy-neo-hippie that I am, I stuck my head out of the passenger window so I could feel the salty San Fran breeze lick my face (in contrast to the usual hot-as-balls summer subway funk that kicks my ass in NYC). After a few minutes of this, I decided to open my eyes to look towards the heavens above, and that's when I saw it: the distinctive double masts of a large ship...IN THE SKY.

It was a pirate ship HIDDEN IN THE CLOUDS!*

At first, I thought I was hallucinating, so I closed my eyes, brought my head back in the Volvo (C is old-school gansta) and decide to look out through the front windshield. Guess what - IT'S STILL THERE.

Now I'm getting concerned, because we seemed to driving closer to this cloud-bound nautical beast (seriously - with masts that big, this ship had to be HUGE), so, trying to keep my cool, I said to my companions, "Um, so like...does that look like a pirate ship to anyone else, or am I trippin'?" 

C took a glance and said "Hey, look, that's pretty cool", before making a turn that inevitably brought us closer to the summit. K just nodded and nonchalantly replied "Yes, Oriana - we're taking you to our Pirate Overlord."

At this point, I started *FREAKING* out, because...well...I've seen the Wizard of Oz too many times as a kid, and if our journey to the Pirate Overlord's ship in the sky was gonna be anything like that, there was no way I coulda survived an encounter with the flock of flying monkeys.

So now we're slowly meandering up a secluded winding mountain road, listening to acid jazz in silence. And I'm trying really hard to maintain my composure and not ruin the collective chill vibe in the Volvo, but OMFG - WE'RE GOING TO MEET THE PIRATE OVERLORD!!!

Finally, we reach the top, park, exit the car aaaannnnnnnndddddddddddd...there's no pirate overlord in the sky...womp womp. What I *thought* were the masts of his ship were actually plain ole radio antennas on the highest point of San Fran - the thick fog kept their bases hidden from sight when we were driving through the Castro. 

*sadface*

So instead, I enjoyed the breathtaking view of the entire city; with the Golden Gate Bridge to my left, Downtown San Fran straight ahead, and Oakland in the distance (...and may it always stay that far away :::shudders:::). And once the initial vertigo subsided, at that altitude we could actually look *through* the clouds/fog and even map out C's house in the Lower Haight.

Since no one else was wearing a look of disappointment, I couldn't tell if any of the other Twin Peaks visitors were also there to meet the Pirate Overlord.  However, most were taking pictures and a few were even picnicking against the cliff wall below, since it was the only area blocked from the fierce misty breezes.

I still would like to meet the Pirate Overlord who lives in the skies of San Francisco, though...I'm just sayin'. Or maybe I just have an overactive imagination. (But admit it...you believe in him, too.)

*Full disclosure: I was a bit done because of the Truffle Man in Delores Park.
author: Lady O.

description:
Very cool to see the city from above. You can really appreciate the beauty and magnitude of San Francisco from here. I would definitely recommend visiting Twin Peaks. 

Unrelated bonus: This is located off of the scenic byway, which has the greatest roadway signs ever. A very 50s, minimalist seagull with red writing.
author: Brandy S.

description:
If you only spend one day in San Francisco you simply must come see the view from Twin Peaks. The only slight problem is that it's a bit of a pain to get to on the buses - they do come up here, but pretty infrequently.


 Just get a cab and take the $10 hit. It'll be worth it.


 Basically from Twin Peaks you can see the Pacific, the Golden Gate bridge, the Marin headland, Sausalito, Alcatraz (and the various other islands), the Bay bridge, all of San Francisco and in fact the entire Bay Area. The view is best at sunset/sunrise, but if you have the time it's good to experience it in all lighting conditions.


 The viewing area is where I spent most of my visits, which is great for viewing San Francisco and the bay, but you can get a view of silicon valley (to the south) if you climb the short distance to one of the peaks.
author: Alistair H.

description: Amazing view of SF, especially at night when the city lights contrast against the darkness of the bay.
author: Tom L.

description:
simply irresistible, beautiful, picturesque view of San Francisco! 

today was a SUNNY, CLEAR & SUPER-WARM in SF.  
WOW!!!
b/c of the gorgeous weather...i was so happy & content. 

this location is a great place to take panoramic pictures of the entire Bay Area.  you can literally see and locate everything! (whoa...you can see Market Street so vividly!!!) 

also, i'm a true romantic, so this place would be marvelous to be with your significant other at either day or night.
author: Deborah C.

description: Love this place!  If you have guests visiting SF you have to bring them here!!  I've taken several visiting family members and friends to various "touristy" places around the city and this is the one place that without fail ends up being the favorite.  Great views but bring your jacket.  It's usually really windy up there!
author: Neil A.

description:
This is such a nice get-away for San Francisco locals, bay area residents, tourists, and basically everyone.

I only came up here twice and usually in broad day light(afternoon around 4ish). The view swept me away and I was stunned by the beauty of San Francisco. The drive up here is not as bad as Grizzly Peak in the east bay and there is parking and ramps leading up to the location.

No matter what the occasion or my emotional state, I will know that this is a place to express whatever feelings i may have inside. 

However, Twin Peaks does get really WINDY, COLD, and FOGGY so it may ruin your romantic or sensational experience here. To me, I see it as a nice add-on to this beautiful getaway. Just remember to always get a jacket or some more clothing to keep you from being sick =)

Some may see this as a bad thing but there are certainly a lot of tourists during the afternoon. It didn't bother me at all. 

Next time, I will come up here when it is night time. Since the afternoon is already beautiful, I must check it out at night.

5/5 for the beauty, view, experience, adventure, excitement... the list goes on and on.
author: Jacky C.

description: This is a very awesome spot to take pictures. The view is very breath taking. When I came here it was very very windy and cold. The fog was coming in and it was really cool watching the fog veiled over the skyline. I think this would be an awesome spot to take a date, especially at night, although I never gone here at night. The next time I come back to San Fran, I would love coming here at night to take pictures and I think it would be amazing to see the city from above at night!
author: Sandy C.

description:
Hands down always the favorite  part of any guided tour I provide to out-of-town guests.  On a clear day, you can see for miles & miles.  On a cold, foggy day you might get a decent glimpse of the taco truck parked in the lot waiting to serve tourists.  

Even though this is one of the most popular tourist stops for every tour bus and tour guide wannabe, I've never had a hard time parking and taking in the view.  

Agree with others that the downside to this attraction is the litter and the abundance of smoking tourists who just can't seem to keep themselves from lighting up - the air would be a lot fresher if they could control themselves :(
author: Lxs S.

description: Not sure if this warrants  a yelp page but a nice view but I prefer the top of the mark at the intercontiental downtown.
author: David D.

description:
I am a former resident of Twin Peaks and not that I am biased or anything, but this was my favorite neighborhood in San Francisco.

It's residential, right in the middle of the city, with a good bit of nature around it.  Some short hikes are accessible around the peaks and the road around the peaks is great for jogging on before 9 AM.  The views are incredible and you get to watch free fireworks shows from the comfort of your own home.  You also get to watch the Blue Angels when they're in town.  And San Francisco has one of the most stunning skylines in the world.

Now for the bad stuff - it gets freaking cold up there and WINDY.  When that fog rolls in from the ocean blanketing the Sunset/Richmond and pushes itself over the peaks and tries to spill into the Castro and Mission, the apex is the peaks and the three highest residential streets in San Francisco.  Blustery would be a mild way to describe it.  

Definitely a must see for any visitors, if it's not foggy.
author: J H.

description:
Nice night view!
Keep in mind that you need an extra jacket!
It is really cold up there!
author: Minhan S.

description:
Best views when there is no fog and no wind at night. 

Guys: take your girl here, it's a romantic spot
Girls: us guys usually like to drive up Twin Peaks very fast so hold on tight ;]

Note: Be sure to bring a blanket or shelter of some sort cos its gonna be COLD!
author: Benson T.

description:
this is the most beautiful places i have been to.
 
it was foggy today but it still had a nice view of SFO.
it's so breathtaking i want to live there. lol

i cant wait to go up there when it's sunny or at night...especially at night it's probably so much better.

and it has those 20 minute bathroom, but i refuse to go. it was nasty.
author: Anna P.

description:
Only 15min drive from downtown SF for a fantastic and breathtaking view of the city! 

Bring a thick jacket as the temperature will drop to single digits with strong gusty winds.
author: Catherine W.

description: The views were awesome, the weather was perfect (in San Fran, at the end of November), and there was plenty of parking nearby.
author: Oleg A.

description: One of the most spectacular  views in the U.S.  This is the 1st place I bring SF newbies whenever I come here. If you're here on a clear day (its was), the views are amazing.
author: Robert B.

description: The view is breathtaking when karl the fog isn't around. Make sure you bring a warm jacket or someone to snuggle with. I'd say it's a nice make out spot, but there are a lot of people walking around. Great views of the city during the day and night.
author: Beverly D.

description:
This another one of those places that make you GASP at the beauty of San Francisco. 
I have so many memories here.  Many times I have been at the look out point.... simply staring in awe at the wonders of SF. I look far and wide... wondering... questioning... enjoying everything around me.  
Whether I am brought here by heartache, love, or friendship I always find peace in the views. 
Be prepared for chilly winds, drunk teenagers and scarce parking (on weekends).
author: Wes P.

description: One of the most spectacular views you can find in the city! BUT be warned that it's insanely freezing cold and windy at night!
author: Jeanette Y.

description:
As everyone says, it's a FABULOUS view. It's not just fabulous, it's serene, cool (temp), and just beautiful. It's touristy. You'll find it on every SF Tourist website probably, but it's classic so definitely check it out even though you're not into tourist sites.

One of my favorite things in the entire world is a beautiful view. I can just sit, overlook a city, body of water, look at the stars, or anything like that so this spot was p-e-r-f-e-c-t. :)
author: CJ J.

description: I've come here so many times throughout my whole life. I always enjoy the scenery and I've shared a lot of my first experiences here. Great place to take your first date, matter of fact I was here on my first date with my girlfriend a while ago. The memories never seem to fade away since thats something people always hold close. Anyways I love this place and I'll be sure to share this spot with my kids one day. Hope everyone enjoys what this place has to offer its a great place to check out with your friends, family, and significant others. Only bad thing about it is lookout for those racoons at night time and the fog sucks sometimes. Hope to see you there!!!!
author: Marvin C.

description:
The best view in San Francisco... on a clear day. 

Whenever I have guests in town, and they have finally gotten over their time at Fisherman's Wharf... etc. I take them up here after a nice dinner on a clear night to see the skyline of our city. 

Nothing better.
author: Jordan Y.

description:
Awesome.  The best view of any city that you can get.  New York City is the only one that can compare.  It is breathtaking.  Experienced a little vertigo and it is windy and cold, but beyond that, nothing could compare to this.  Very busy, hard to find parking.
Highly recommend.  Been to SF many times, first time here and wished I would have went on the prior visits.  Don't miss!
author: B W.

description:
A must visit if you are in SF.  

Amazing pictures opportunities if its not cloudy.

crowded and windy at times.
author: Roger A.

description:
A good scenic get away within the city.

This spot is a must while in SF to enjoy all the wonders of the city.  At times you are just there at awe 

Not a bad drive to get there. Parking can be a problem when it gets crowded on a nice sunny day.
author: kent c.

description: Great place to go if you want the view of The City... whether it's day or night time, this place is pretty much almost always occupied. It can get chilly and windy so bring a jacket.
author: Kaycie Y.

description:
I almost got killed tonight by a matching pillow-top mattress and box-spring set.

On my realistic quest to look like a Victoria's Secret Model by Summer Swimsuit Season, I hiked two miles this morning and then decided to leave my office (near the Ferry Building) at 6 pm and walk home to the Sunset via Twin Peaks.  A 6.5 mile hike, guaranteed to shed a little of my winter cushion.

After I passed the Castro, I stood near the top of Twin Peaks and was fortunate enough to catch a beautiful sunset.  Between gasping for air and admiring the view, my physical and spiritual bodies felt pretty darn strong.

And then I saw it.  A truck speeding down Market Street (or was it Portola?  I forget where they transition) with a mattress set in the back.  Suddenly, as if I were in a movie, the fluffy white mattress and box-spring both flew out of the back of the truck and start skidding towards me.  It was terrifying.  As they approached, I was sure they were going to shove me over the railing and kill me.  My life honestly flashed before my eyes.  What a terrible way to go, you know?  ---Hey, you know Janney B. from Yelp?  B*tch got ranover by a Serta last night.  Let's 5-star her death!---

Fortunately for me, the killer mattresses landed in the road twenty feet away from me.  Unfortunately for rush hour traffic, they were blocking both of the lanes.  The truck at fault kept going and didn't stop.  Traffic was at a standstill, vehicles unable to pass the scene.  

I stood there, the only pedestrian around, still huffing and puffing from the first 4 miles of my urban hike.  Without thinking, I threw my messenger bag on the sidewalk, sprinted into traffic (it's dark, mind you), grabbed the box-spring mattress and pulled it out of the way.  THEN, while cars began whizzing by in the left hand lane, I bent with knees and flipped the heavy mattress three times until it went up on the sidewalk, finally resting against the railing.  This adrenaline-fueled feat of strength is especially impressive, considering that I typically require help opening jars of pickles and bottles of water.

I was the only moron walking in the direction of traffic in the dark on Twin Peaks.  Call me crazy (my exes do...) but I think I was in the right place at the right time.  I was meant to be there, because people needed my help.  What a terrific feeling that is. 

Note: Mr. Trucker, you're gonna have to try harder than that to get me into bed.
author: Janney B.

description: Best view of the city.  Hands down!!! I live really close to this and finally had a chance to make it up here.  The views are out of control.  Seriously, you can see the whole city in every direction.   It was a clear day and it blew my mind.  If you are a runner, blast the hills to get up here and you feel like Rocky when he knocks out the Russian Enforcer.  Yep, that good.
author: Vinh N.

description:
By far the best view of the city, and home to many memories over the years. 

I think I have, in addition to a handy little parking God who only takes about 1 day off a month, a Twin Peaks God as well. It seems that I have been one of the lucky people who has managed, many times, to catch this place when there are only one or two other cars around. There have even been a few times where I had the place all to myself. 

I have sat up here on a clear, warm (I know, what?) evening, sans jacket, sharing a six pack with a friend, after ditching a pretty damn cool party, only to have one of those conversations about life that sticks with you.  

I have been here on a first date that later ended with him slow dancing with me in my family room. I think this place inspired his romantic side.  

I have been here when I needed to make one of the more difficult choices in my life and needed clarity. I am quite convinced this place helped me make what I know was the right choice. 

I have been here frolicking on the hillside like Julie Andrews, singing at the top of my lungs with friends (I am sorry to those of you who had to witness that, I do not remotely sound like Julie Andrews).

I have laughed here, cried here, talked here, not talked here, thought about life, cleared my mind and have taken many a visiting friend to show them why I love where I live. They always understand.
author: Drue C.

description:
One of my favorite places to come and chill out and enjoy the view. I also like staring at Sutro antenna.

Come here on a really windy day. Go to the very top of one of the hills. I think its the hill to the left if your looking down Market st. Lean your back against the wind. You can literally lean in the wind. Feels nice.
Also a good smoke spot!
author: Brent W.

description:
I recently took my high-school sweetheart here. (I know, so 5 years ago). I had fun scaring the sh*t out of him while driving up the hill! :). 

The view was spectacular! As always...

::continue below for another remarkable "andrew driving time" story involving a conservative, southern california catholic mother visiting her gay san franciscan son::
author: Andrew C.

description:
100.
Growing up in SF ...
I think my family tourist pics at Twin Peaks fight GGBridge pics and win. The view is that amazing.
 
Three bridges lines cast into different cities, watching the skylines change. The wind mericilessly whips your hair about your face and scours your skin and it all makes you want to pee - bring change for the toliet.

Other than that, this is a sexy place to be. 

The red and white Sutro tower juts from the side, delivering signals and giving airline pilots and people in traffic westbound on the Bay Bridge some erected excitement. 
Excitement like a crowd of 40+ people showing up in blazers and San Francisco sweatshirts from a distant land thousands of miles away, smiling through chattering teeth, who spent $100 on some bus tour to get here because even locals sometimes just can't seem to figure how get up... Even the city itself is a fallen Christmas tree in the night.
 
The Portola Style in: twisting and turning, sharp curves, echoing those late nights spent in cars shrouded in fog and observing the please park a few spaces away rule.
 
Students losing summers and prom nights in 40s, weed and peace and in the infinite daydreams that loop around each mound.
The peaks have nursed my many broken hearts, soaked up my tears and reminded me that its too pretty a place to cry and the view will always take it away with a breath.
 
Its the perfect stage on a freezing winter night when a meeting turned into a phone call to we just cant get off the phone, you're that amazing we must hang out now and we don't want to eat, let's come up here. Followed by a 3AM hike in knockaround shoes up up and away, where we laughed at the police lights beaming the car to no avail; we were on the top of SF, sitting on that first inhale of heaving chest sharing a coat for an hour because we lost the trail in the falling fog and the even with the spark of the night, we couldn't come down. 
 
Twin peaks, you're the SF love of my life.
author: Cheryl D.

description: Amazing view . If it's foggy it makes it a bit difficult to really enjoy the view. Evening is the best view of all the lights, and it really makes this a great relaxing spot.
author: Eisa m.

description:
I'm torn between four and five stars.  I'll settle for four because this is the only place in San Francisco where I don't feel comfortable without a jacket.

The view from up here is amazing.  It's better than almost anything in the city.  It probably is better than anything in the city, but I don't want to open myself to lawsuits.  Well, that's not really the reason I won't just come out and say it, so I'll just come out and say it:  The view from up here is better than anything in the city.
author: John S.

description: I had forgotten how beautiful the City is from Twin Peaks.  If you catch it on a perfect day, it makes you even more proud to be a San Franciscan.  Beautiful vistas, stunning architectural patterns, the uniqness of the Bay Area can be seen from this vantage point.  If you've never been, or haven't been in awhile and you are in the City on a nice weather day, check it out.
author: Curley R.

description: This is a must visit in SF. Its provides an awesome view of the entire city of SF for FREE! Its easy to get to by car, and although there are always people there, its not terribly crowded or inconvenient. Its a great place to take pictures.
author: J Y.

description:
It's Twin Peaks! There's nothing to compare it to in the city.

Hang out
Make out
Smoke up?
(censored)

I'm only docking a star because it's often overcast and cold as the heart of a conservative. So bundle up and enjoy the view.

Actually sitting in the car up here at night reminds me of those movies from the 50's where the kids would take their steel boat of a car up to Hollywood Hills and lay on the hood. Good times.
author: Ryan V.

description:
Brought a friend here one time and she started crying because the view was so nice haha. Have not been there during the day but at night its amazing.  Great for taking photos of the city too. 
Nice spot to take a date.
author: John c.

description:
twin peaks. 

Memories.

*sigh*
author: Janice C.

description: In a city where postcard views are a dime a dozen and occur with a simple turn of the head, Twin Peaks is the king of the, um, hill. Up the hill, reached by car and free to those willing to make the drive, I deeply appreciated my friend taking my wife and me here. Panoramic views and a blustery wind makes you almost feel a explorer astride a summit that just happens to have its own public toilet and snack truck. So you've got that going for you....
author: Ivan S.

description:
Make sure you take a sweater up there... it could get chilly!

The first time I went up here... my single gay friend and I were admiring the night view of the City...noting that this must be where people go on makeout and booty bumpin sessions..... then we started singing... 


"All by myself... don't wanna be... all by myself.... anymore"
author: Grace M.

description:
This seems like such an automatic MUST SEE for anyone who's in SF for more than 10 minutes that it's almost an Alcatraz-sized cliche, so I'm surprised at how many people - even long-time residents and SF natives - are yelping about how long it took them to take their first expedition here.

Sure, it's a must for out-of-town guests, but it's also a great spot for those of us who live in the city above which the Peaks loom.

With an elevation of ~900+ feet (Noe Peak, the South Peak is 922 ft..  Eureka, the North Peak is 904 ft.), the Peaks are actually the second tallest hills in SF (Mount Davidson is the tallest), but probably #1 in terms of best 360 panoramic view.

And the hype is deserved - they're pretty incredible, both during a (clear) day, when you can see for miles in every direction, and at night (when it turns into a bit of a makeout/ smokeout point), when the lights of the city come on like a huge electric train set.

The downers about TP have been well-documented: too many fanny pack-toting tourists with their deisel-belching busses crowding the parking lot & posing for group photo ops.  

So definitely make sure you get out of the parking lot and climb the dirt trails to the tops of the actual peaks.

There's also an complete lack of amenities - a mediocre hot dog vendor is all that stands between you and starvation.  Srinivas R. made the comment of the year: "If they had a bar, it'd be perfect."  So its BYOB...problem solved.

When you do go, you should also beware of the weather.  "Los Pechos de la Choca" - or the Breasts of the Indian Maiden as the Spaniards called the Peaks (no sh*t) - can get especially...ahem...nipply.  And fog can essentially ruin the view (although being above a low-lying fog layer might be a cool experience unto itself) - so check the weather report.

But watching a storm roll in and ravage the city from this vantage, as Jason W. says, could possibly be one of the coolest things you can do.

And if you want to get 'extreme', try the Sevenpeak run - which covers  3,200 feet of elevation in its ups and downs:

http://bestof.sfweekly.com/bestof/award.php?oid=oid:67225&section=oid:24954&year=2005

From personal experience I can say it's a bitch, but your surroundings will keep you going.  ("Rocky Mountain High"...or something like that.)

Finally: Did you know...?
Twin Peaks is only one of three areas that provides a home to the endangered Mission Blue Butterfly.

Most of the plant life the Mission Blue Butterfly needs to survive has been destroyed by development, but Twin Peaks has been able to restore and sustain much of this natural plant life, providing a safe place for the butterfly to survive. 

I do my research, foo'...ya heard.
author: Ryan W.

description: Best view of the city from up here. Located near the big red radio tower, the tower serves as a compass for lost travelers. Its quite windy up here so bring a jacket or two or three if at night. The day view is different than the one at night so seeing the view at both times of the day are worth it. I personally like the night view better. Great to bring out-of-towners.
author: Robert Y.

description: Best place to see the city!
author: M R.

description: Anytime we have visitors and the weather allows, we head to the peaks, especially during mid-day for great pictures.
author: Francis H.

description: My buddy and I decided to walk from the concrete slides to the top of Twin Peaks. I don't know if you're supposed to do this. Our route took us up winding streets, hidden stairways and finally a path along the side of the hill itself. I don't know if these were really paths they might have just been the way water runs off the hill causing the rocks to be exposed there. It was crazy, we're crazy if you're crazy you should do this but if you're not, you're better off driving I should think. After clinging to the side of the hill and making our way to the parking lot we saw tour buses, a bathroom and a food cart. We then walked to the very top. What a view, what a day. You live in the city? Go do this.
author: Klik W.

description:
Who is not to like Twin Peaks...every out of towner that we bring up there, will go ooo'ing and aaaahh'ing about this spot! Ok, provided on a clear bright sunny day....we've gone up there when it was foggy and windy and that is not something to be desired, well at least not to out-of-towners who are aiming for the sweeping views of the Bay and the city!
We've spent a lovely birthday evening there as well with cake, candles and knife in tow, wonderful moment....sigh, I miss SF!
author: Yan M.

description:
This morning I was standing on top of one of the Peaks (north one I think) and watching a full-as-can-be gorgeous moon, changing from silver to yellow to orange, slowly sink into the western horizon, while the "dawn's early light" was coloring the eastern sky equally lovely shades of orange, red and blue. I launched my little kite and watched it rise into the sky in a light easterly breeze, to greet the rising sun. Sheer bliss.

But standing on top of the same peak when the world below you is shrouded in pea-soup fog and the wind shrieks defiantly and threatens to blow you off your feet - to me, that's blissful too. Just make sure you're wearing a windbreaker that can withstand the onslaught.

Down below, on sunny days, schools of tour buses circle the peaks, vomiting up hordes of camera-toting tourists and swallowing them up again fifteen minutes later. Less blissful, perhaps, but still fun to recognize the various languages they speak. I used to regard Twin  Peaks as a kind of hilltop Fisherman's Wharf because of the tourist factor. But if you pick the right time of day and walk all the way to the top, the place can grow on you. You can even enjoy a moment of reflection and solitude, like I did this morning.
author: Froggy V.

description:
Whenever I need to think about myself I come here.  Sometimes I just need to get away from it all and think about me.  I especially like how the sun hits my face at dusk.....

Oakland and the tenderloin have never looked so beautiful from this vantage point--sometimes I can see homeless people roaming around the valleys below and I like to pretend to squish them with my fingers.  Squish. Squish.  Squish.  Where else in the city can you do that?

Bring change for the vending toilets otherwise your full frontal will end up on some Japanese U-Tube site. 

Bring your camera!
author: Bill B.

description: I love this place..when my hubbie and I first started going out he used to bring me here. Perfect place to smoke a blunt.
author: Raquel P.

description: I feel bad for seeing this but the first time I went with a girlfriend to make out and I was so unimpressed, my expectations were a bit high may'be? But the 2nd and 3rd times to show friends visiting the city produced the same result. I'm glad so many others enjoy it though.
author: Jon P.

description:
Could I give Twin Peaks anything but 5 stars? I mean c'mon, thats like giving mother nature the middle finger.

My nutty self thought I could ride my bike up here from my place in the Duboce Triangle! Ha! My muscles were liquid and I was rolling backwards instead of forward...

Oh well, I parked my bike and trekked the rest of the way up. You gotta love the urban hike...

WHAT A VIEW! I am on a constant crusade to find the best view in SF, and this has got to be it. It makes Corona Heights look like an ant hill!

I sat on the ledge, relaxing and daydreaming, and idetifying every SF landmark I could find. The GG bridge! The Bay Bridge! Dolores park! The crackhead laudary mat!

My good time was ruined though, when about 6 tour buses pulled up and dropped off *hundreds* of toursits. I am not even kidding, hundreds! It was worse then Union Square on a Saturday. Boo!
author: S F.

description:
how could you NOT love the view?

great place to just chat and enjoy the view.  sometimes crowded, but park lower and hike a bit up
author: Jh M.

description:
Beauty lies in the beholder's eyes and the one fond beauty is Twin Peaks. 

Twin Peaks, the two hills that centers San Francisco with its breathtaking views.

In the evening if you look to your left is the infamous Golden Gate Bridge and to your right is the vertical street lights of Market street overlooking the bay.

I always feel a sense of nostalgia coming up here for many reasons. Now going down memory lane....

Well for one thing, this is the "it" place to bring your significant other. ;)  

Just going up twin peaks on a clear night made me realize how beautiful my city is.  Getting a glimpse of the view is to die for, but make sure it's not  a night when the fog rolled in...
author: Sophia S.

description: One of the most surreal views of the Bay Area. On a clear day, you can see some parts of the South Bay! Just see it for yourself! Remember it does get chilly at night!
author: Richard G.

description:
It was cold, windy and misty on Saturday night. We were up at the Twin Peaks at 6pm...the fog had just started to roll in through the moutain tops and onto the city below. The wind whipped our hair and our cheeks and noses were pink from the cold. We huddled for warmth and rubbed our hands together. 

The Golden Gate bridge was illuminated by a small patch of sun and we pointed out the familiar sights to each other. Golden Gate Park, Alcatraz, Bay Bridge, Sausalito. 

We precariously hiked up the steep steps to the peak, with the wind threatening to blow us away at any minute. Step by step, catching each other as we stumbled, we made it up to the top. We were in the midst of clouds and fog. Misty, windy, amazing.
author: Jeanne S.

description:
Yelpers who've rated Twin Peaks at 1 star are crazy. What's not to love about Twin Peaks? It's absolutely beautiful up here! Even though we went on a cloudy day, it was still a sight to see. I've never been at night or on a sunny day but when I went it was hella chilly. So be sure to bundle up or bring your special someone and cuddle.
The drive here is scary since your going up a narrow hill and thinking about the drive down doesn't make it easier. It's just as worse. It'd be best to take a small compact car. Unfortunately for us, we took a big truck. Good thing is there's no parking fee here, however, there are few parking spots so you might have to park along the curb or gravel.
author: Lisa T.

description:
If you grew up in SF, you been here:
1.  When you were in middle school and you snuck out of the house and you were looking for the haunted house that could never be found, and when you found it you did not dare enter it, and if you did you did not open your eyes.
2.  In high school, when someone decides chilling up at twin peaks was romantic....LOL...I guess i can be
3.  As an adult during an lunar eclipse or a warm night photo op.
Anyhow, if you are a tourist, you should come here.  And if you are a resident, you should too.  It's not EXTRAORDINARY, but it's a sight...and it's quite peaceful.....if you can filter out the electrical buzzes from the tower.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Quite possibly the best view of San Francisco.

My only advice is that when you do drive up, come up the south side via (look fancy language) Twin Peaks Blvd. As you're rounding the first left turn, around the bend, turn to the right (unless you're driving, pay attention to the road!) and overlook a bright view of SOMA and the Bay Bridge that would normally be obstructed from the peak.

Oh, and bring a jacket. It gets cold at night.

Just a great way to end the day when you're showing a friend around the city.
author: Jeffrey C.

description: Absolutely beautiful view of the greatest cities in the world. Definitely a must-see for anyone and everyone - tourists, locals, and everyone in between - at some point if you're ever in San Francisco on a clear day/night. Don't forget to bring a jacket because it'll probably be pretty chilly and windy.
author: April P.

description:
The views from Twin Peaks are phenomenal...

The atmosphere up here depends on the day/night you go.  Below are just a few different scenarios...

Weeknight (clear skies) - Parking is usually available, but there will be high school kids asking if you have any "bomb" (aka weed) for sale.

Weekend (clear skies) - Parking will be a pain.  And there will be tons of tourists, couples, and a variety of people from all walks of life enjoying the view.

Weeknight (foggy skies) - See "weeknight (clear skies)" review.

Weekend (foggy skies) - See "weekend (clear skies)" review...with the exception of available parking.

Enjoy the views, and find a dark spot to make out....until some scrapper pulls up blasting Mac Mall, and dudes roll out looking for some "bomb."
author: Daniel M.

description:
view is beautiful, could be pretty windy some days.

On sunday mornings, I'm not sure if its every sunday but they have this large group of mexicans? latins? I'm not sure exactly but it sounds spanish or something close to it? I hope I'm not labeled as racist for this. But yea they stand there and basically are screaming something, I'm guessing its a religious procedure of some sort but its loud and just not great for sunday morning sunrise viewing.

Other than that, at night its nice and um, yeah you get a great view of the city.
author: phillip w.

description:
I do believe that quite a few of the significant San Francisco Landmarks can be seen and appreciated from this location, the SF downtown, Golden Gate Bridge, Wharf all come together to provide this picturesque landscape that no postcard could ever do justice.  Whether it's a a clear sunny day or a brightly lite night scape, this spot is simple beautiful no matter what time it is.  I will say that the day time, it is a tourist trap, with tons of out of town visitors and the parking area is jammed with tour buses.  

At night, while it isn't exactly the best neighborhood if you are wandering alone, still that said, the view is amazing.  I will also mention I dislike how people can be inconsiderate and just smash their bottles all over the place especially as on other yelper pointed out that there is no lack of garbage cans...  Still for the homesick returning local or the first time visitor this is definitely a great stop to take in the view.
author: Chris T.

description:
I heart Twin Peaks, but not because it reminds me of Laura Palmer, but because the view from it is amazing. Not like amazing when you find an Oreo in your pocket, but amazing like you've found a bunch of Oreos in your pocket.

I've been reading the reviews. I've never made out with a girl up here, but maybe one day I will. Also I'll try to conceive children up here too. It's on my bucket list, I swear.
author: Eddie P.

description:
Oh the memories of me 15 making out here with my ex boyfriend!!! lol

After re reading my review of exes...I should've left this in the past!! EWWW....
author: Joanne E.

description: Beautiful at night! The drive up was kinda scary, not gonna lie! Once you get up there, you will be amazed! Make sure you layer up because it gets really really cold at night! Great for couples :)
author: Cindy L.

description:
We went up there on May 16th, 2009 at night.  First time going up there when it was dark.  I was really surprised by the amount of people there and the lack of parking.  Guess it was because of the incredibly warm weather.  I noticed that the crowd were mostly people on dates, people getting high in their cars, or people drinking....not that I mind any of them.  ...Then the cops showed up and some people left.  There's also some people up there that like to start fights...and I think that this really kills the nice scenery.  

I usually come up here on a nice sunny day with family or friends just to check out the scenery.  I would definitely go again when we're at a heat wave since it felt good to be up there.  The view is crazy at night.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
Is there a sexier spot than Twin Peaks?

author: V B.

description:
AMAZING! It was colder than a polar bear's toenail this night but I got an awesome view!  Me and my cousin went here after dinner and all these years I've lived near SF, I've never been her.

I loved the view.  I want to see the sunrise/set one day from here.
author: Lo C.

description:
Come here if:

1) you want to see youngins "pre-partying", "car- barring" or whatever you crazy kids call it nowadays.

2) you want to get it on while overlooking a beautiful view (or if you're a perv with binoculars)

3) you're on a date :)

I opt for option #3.  Come!  It's free, memorable, and breathtakingly beatiful!
author: S L.

description:
Absolute wonderful view of San Francisco and beyond. Not just a tourist spot. This is a spot you can visit repeatedly as a local and enjoy over and over. You've got visual access to the Pacific Ocean, the Bay, San Francisco, Oakland, Bay Bridge, Golden Gate, Alcatraz and more. Just an absolute amazing place to visit. 

Climb up to the top of the peaks and then enjoy the view and the air.
author: Kurt I.

description: Do yourself a favor and come up here on a crystal clear night.  It's the best view of the city ever.
author: Dave M.

description:
I love this place.  What's funny is I've been here so many times and it took AWHILE to finally see the view.  The first three times it was hella foggy, but the 4th time was a charm.  It was probably because my one and only was there to take in the view with me.  It was PACKED though...and unless you go during the oddest hours (no this does not mean right after the clubs and right after eating at mel's), it'll be packed with blaring music, drunk comrades and lots of makeout sessions.

You see all of SF, and I love seeing it at night (who doesn't?).  I hate those quarter (how many quarters do they need now?) machines, they're such a waste and you can see more things with the NAKED EYE people.  So you see a close up of a building, then what?  Better to see THAT right up front, too.

So I was sitting on the ledge with my sexy man during the summertime and I'm swinging my legs when one of my flip flops fling out to no man's land.  Oops.  I tell him I don't need the cheap yet cute flip flop and I'm fine without it, but he goes down the hill and gets it for me.  What a prince charming.  I guess fairy tales do come true, and this whole time I thought Cinderella was an idiot.  JK, she's my fave after Mary Poppins.
author: Lili K.

description:
Twin Peaks: The Haiku

Like two pointy boobs,
You make motorboating fun
Oh, view is good too.
author: Jared S.

description: Spectacular view without the tourists. Going up here is one of the many things I like to do to remind myself why I love the city so much.
author: Jennifer P.

description: Love the view from up here and try to stop up there when we drive into the city for a lazy day.  Recommend weekdays for on the weekends it can get extremely busy up top.  Need a snack or drink while up there.  Normally a small food truck is parked up there but don't expect discount prices and the guy normally with the truck is very lazy so pick out what you want and then you'll find him sitting up front with no regard to you or what you want.
author: John F.

description:
Wonderful view of the city here, with both bay and ocean views. We went on a weekend afternoon-- bad idea --but a weeknight would be perfect. Definitely avoid tourist-friendly times if you want to be able to A) move around, B) not get hit by a giant bus, C) hate tourists.

We scooted there, which was extra fun with the hills and twists and turns and such.

Minus one star for the unnecessary "observation deck."
author: Jeannie C.

description:
Another great view of San Francisco.

I was taken here by the beau on a whim one beautifully clear day.  We had a panoramic view of San Francisco and most of the East Bay.  From the other Yelp reviews, it looks like we'll have to go back at night!

Don't forget: ear muffs and a jacket (it can be cold and VERY windy) and your camera!
author: Heather S.

description: Wow, oh wow! The view is absolutely amazing. However, it's cold and windy so much that we had to jump into the car after about 5 minutes. Lots of other people here too, so it's hard to be private and romantic. Bring many many blankets and sweaters and gloves and scarfs. It's windy and cold, especially at night. But the view was actually breath taking. And parking available
author: Phan H.

description:
To summit up, Twin Peaks has beautiful views, definitely peaks worth a peek.  After all, they are among the last natural twin peaks left around this town ;)

One star off for the unmitigated late night nasty business taking place on them there peaks; underage drunks littering the place with broken glass and condoms, drugs, other nice activities and no cops ever checking in is pathetic.
author: GIR ..

description:
Amazing lookout spot at what feels like the top of SF. On a clear day (rare sometimes yes), you can see all of SF from this central vantage point. Bay Bridge, Golden Gate, Downtown, a clear view of market from start to finish... 

But - beware it's *f-f-f-f-f-freeeeezzing* up here. Since it's:
SF + Tall Hill = extreeemely windy. Whatever wind you might experience down below increase it exponentially. It feels ~30 degrees colder up here bc of the windchill.

The extraordinary views + the easy drive up here tho make it really worthwhile. I don't know how they did it, but for one of the biggest hills in SF, there's not a single stop light you need to worry about rolling back on :)
author: Stephen W.

description:
I've been around the world, and this one of the most remarkable views I've ever seen in my life!

I think it's even more impressive after dark, with all the city lights. Just be careful not to run over the pedestrians who walk back and forth across the streets in complete darkness. I couldn't believe how many people there were doing this.

Forget Coit Tower. Come here.
author: Timothy P.

description:
THE best views in the city. Take a "Twin Peaks Virgin" here and they'll remember you forever. The best part of it all, is that it's FREE. So c'mon, you cheapo, bring your date here after dinner (preferably on a clear night),  go stargazing, or get hypnotized by the lights down Market Street, then end it with a make-out sesh in the backseat of your jeep. 

Just remember to turn off your headlights.
author: Zell C.

description:
Absolutely gorgeous. if you go up on a clear night, you have a great view of the city, and the Golden Gate Bridge.

Bring your camera.

Bring your date.

Bring a sweater. It gets cold.

Bring a jacket to put on top of your sweater if you're going at night. It gets really cold.
author: Whiskey L.

description: Let's face it, for recreation and entertainment there's not much these days that is free.  Twin Peaks look out in San Francisco is free and the views are really awesome on most days.  To the south, you can see San Jose and to the East you can see the Oakland hills and Mt. Diablo. There are also great views of downtown, the bay and the Golden Gate Bridge to the north.  There are a few different routes to get up to the look out point; the best is by car with Google, a map or GPS.  Although rare, there have been reports of gang activity.  The place can get be a little on the rough side late at night so use caution after dark.  I'm and avid photographer and have been up many times after dark with no issues.  Be sure to take your camera and dress warm.
author: Chris F.

description:
I was gonna be all like, And what jagoffs exactly aren't giving this place 5 stars??, and then the first line of the first review I saw duly noted, "do not, i repeat, do not bother going on a foggy day." Oh. Right. Yeah there's that. And then she also wrote something about it being "always...ALWAYS, freezing"^ and I was immediately like, Oh yeah--that, too. 

Sigh. San Francisco, why do you have to be so nearly fatally flawed? I mean it. Because if you were fatally fatally flawed then I would leave you, kick you out, or something. I'd be back in Chicago, or god help me New York, someplace it gets hot for an ENTIRE ACTUAL SEASON. (Dozens of days and nights straight where it's hot hot HOT! A hundred days where this can and does happen at any given time! Think of it! The joy of sitting on your stoop at 10pm in your shirtsleeves, drinking a beer. No light sweater in your shoulder bag. No fear of what may be lurking on the other side of that hill. I hate you, fog, I hate you like I hate Dick Cheney and Ann Coulter. You ruin everything, and sometimes (it seems to me) you do it just to cause suffering, just to ruin good times....) But--sigh--San Francisco, Madame City by the Bay, you are, of course, indefatigably beautiful, you are the sweetest piece of metro ass on the whole goddam continent. And that is why I have not yet left you.

Shit--I haven't even gotten to reviewing this deal yet. Well, I just went up here tonight,* and even though I've seen it before, and even though I've lived in this city for six years at this point, seen it from Bernal and Mt. Davidson, from the Golden Gate Bridge and the Marin Headlands, from the Top of the Mark and Telegraph Hill and Golden Gate Heights and the steps that are Farnsworth Lane I did, yes, gasp a little bit when I got out of the car. Damn you, San Francisco; I'll probably never bring myself to leave you.



^Though having just gone up there tonight--the tail end of our annual "hot" spell--when it was only mildly cool, I would probably append to, "usually cold as shit, even in October."

*My one piece of advice to you, dear yelpers who have made it this far, is to go at night!
author: T U.

description:
People that have lived in the SF area all their life might take this for granted but when you come from the flatlands this is why you ran away from home.

I'm an ex Military and have see a lot but sorry I never was stationed in the Alps. I think that ended circa 1940-something.

This is the beautiful thing that becomes even more special with cold and fog.

Now I'm back in my homeland - Duluth, MN - cold and fog. And snow.

I always got the weird look walking around SF in shorts and a t-shirt in December but I digress.
author: Chuck F.

description:
WHERE THE HELL AM I?

Recently, I celebrated a friend of a friend's birthday on some sort of conversion party bus--you know, one of those buses you see driving around at Burning Man.

There's some weird loophole in the law that allows you to drink on these buses--kinda like RV's and limos I guess. Anyhow our awesome sober bus driver takes us up to Twin Peaks.

I stumble off the party bus after having had a few good swigs off the Patron Silver bottle and I think to myself, where the hell am I?? Holy crap. It's San Francisco. I've lived here for 3 years and I have never been up to Twin Peaks. It's so amazing at night! Definitely a must see--even without the booze and party bus.
author: Cindy P.

description: Raelllly pretty view, especially at night.  Definitely a good place to take some photos.
author: Celia B.

description:
came here again and yes it's so beautiful, the view of san francisco! 

great view and great companies = great times!! 

did you know there's a public restroom? it's also free!! the restroom is actually pretty clean consider that its a public restroom! woohoo!!
author: Valerie N.

description: First piece of advice - wear comfortable shoes, no need to wear heels or else you'll not be able to really enjoy this location and will keep worrying about falling over. You have to walk up wooden steps to get to the top of the hill and steps are narrow, path is rough and rocky. You can get good views of the city provided it's a clear day. And it can get a little windy and chilly depending upon the weather. I even saw folks taking their pets up here so feel free to bring an extra buddy along if you have one. No restrictions but exercise caution.
author: Anna A.

description:
INCREDIBLE. Seriously, this was the best thing I've seen in awhile. I came up here after a wedding ceremony at a nearby church on one of the nicest days in San Fran ever. It was warm, clear, and sunny. Fucking amazing. Unfortunately because I was wearing a dress for the wedding I think I ended up flashing a bunch of random strangers because of the wind factor. But, it was totally, totally worth it.

The day I went was Pride and we could see the Pink Triangle and balloons from the top down. I had noticed the Pink Triangle up on the peaks during the drive up to the wedding and it was really cool to be able to see it at the top. 

You can see the Golden Gate Bridge, and, well, basically everything in the Bay Area from up here. Fabulous view and I'd imagine it would be a really great place to have a nice romantic picnic. Just don't wear a flimsy dress.
author: Sarah H.

description: i lived in the bay all my life, i also hear so much about twin peaks but sadly i never been up there until last week. my boyfriend decided to take me up there to look at the city lights since i love looking at views. i had such a good time. i took away one star because of rude people who take advantage to drink and cuss up there and there were sooo many raccoons up there. it was actually funny seeing people scream HAHA
author: Winnie C.

description: Amazing views! Surprisingly, at 1 AM on a Thursday night there were quite a lot of people there. Friendly ones , too! Great place for tourists and even locals like me!
author: Chantel Y.

description: Day or night, when the fog has lifted, you will be taken aback by the picturesque beauty of San Francisco, the City and the Bay.  It's like a live framed portrait that mesmorizes you.  Pack a picnic basket, a glass of wine and wine glasses, and stay awhile to enjoy the view and your company.  One of the best things I've experienced next to many things I did or places I've visited when in the City.
author: Val B.

description:
I absolutely LOVE the view here at Twin Peaks! It's the best! I live in LA, but I try to go up north at least once a year to get away and discover new things in and around the city.

Every single time I come up to SF though I must stop by Twin Peaks. It's always breathtaking. I unfortunately haven't had the oppurtunity to come up at night yet, but this coming trip I think I will have to make the effort to do so.

I've been blessed with many memories here at Twin Peaks and I can't wait to go back and make many more!

I think it is definetely a MUST SEE whenever anyone is in town.
author: Khristine S.

description: Very nice....I was pleasantly surprised to see such a gorgeous view of the city.  it was a clear, sunny day.  The drive up there and back could be a bit scary (or maybe it's just me :) We had no problem finding parking even though there were loads of people there.  We hiked up the peaks and down..both of our thighs are sore now.  Anyway--this is a great place to bring people who are visiting SF.  Don't forget to bring a nice camera to capture the views.
author: sonya h.

description:
I've recently visited Twin Peaks on the night with the huge moon. It was a beautiful thing, the moon reflected onto the bay. 

Twin Peaks never disappoints me. I enjoy the view especially at night, with all the lights and all.

I also came here when "Lights Out SF" happened. The lights of GGB was out and most of the buildings DT was also out, but it was still nice.
author: Winnie L.

description:
A Very nice view of the city from Twin Peaks.
A Must go to bring anyone that hasn't ever been to San Francisco.
Please bring a camera!!
author: Ron C.

description:
My boyfriend brought me here on our 1 year anniversary. :) 

This place is definitely the best at night! Cos that's when all the street lights is on and you can see how brightly lit Market St. is. It's SO freakin' beautiful up here. I mean, there's no words to really describe it.. It's a romantic spot where couples come and just sit there and look out at the view. And then there are those group of people who come up here to take pictures of themselves. And there could be an occasional smoker who sits by himself and just breathe in and out slowly. 

I can't wait to come back here again. The view from this place is WAY better than just staying at home and watching TV or going on Facebook.
author: Jessica T.

description: Best place to hang with your friends after a super long day in the city. The view is beyond amazing. You can see absolutely everything! There's something really magical just sitting on the ledge and staring out into the city or playing I-spy haha. I love coming here because it's a great place to just talk the night away.
author: Andrew C.

description:
I can't believe in all my years of living in SF, I never ventured up to Twin Peaks just to take in the city.  I guess sometimes you don't really know what you had until you don't have it anymore..... and now I want it again!

Stunning.....simply stunning!
author: Myko L.

description: Gorgeous views! A must for visitors. But, it's soooo cold and windy up there. Wear layers and a hat.
author: Kimi W.

description: If the weather is nice and sunny, go here....you will be rewarded with simply beautiful views of the city, and great photo ops.  Just don't be an idiot and try to walk to here from MUNI, like we did....I would probably drive here next time, although the walk here was definitely great exercise!
author: Nina B.

description: Beautiful view, you realize you're ontop of the world in a sprawling metropolis!
author: Jon-o G.

description: Beautiful views! A totally different way to see SF. For sure gonna tell everyone that this is a must see.
author: Tay T.

description:
This is good, cheap fun in SF. When we had those unusually warm nights last week, my friend and I came up here to check out the view. It was clear as crystal and you could see the Bay Bridge stretching out to the east bay, and the mission and downtown spread out before you, like a beautiful twinkling tablecloth.
There are also what appear to be a bunch of makeout turnouts along the road.
author: Rennie L.

description:
Spectacular!  The lookout area has beautiful views down Market street and up to the Marina.  A nice grassy area to the west has views of the Sunset all the way to the Ocean (so that's why they call it the Sunset!).  

My only complaints are it's lack of warm beverage vendors (brrr that afternoon wind is cold!) and it's perpetually broken bathroom (yes, it would be better if it had no bathroom).

Every time I walk to Twin Peaks from the Castro I inadvertently take a different route which is remarkably longer than the last one.  Nonetheless it's worth the hike.  But I recommend a bringing along a map.
author: Tessa M.

description:
Another one...as a native how can you not love it here. 

The views are spectacular, best in the city. Having grown up in the sunset the fog and wind don't bother me. I love coming up here just to think and get away from things for a little bit. 

Plus, it holds a special place in my heart for all those high school weekend nights with friends doing things we shouldn't have been doing.

Then there's the occasions I've gone up there with the SO just to act like horny teenagers.
author: Maria M.

description:
It took me 8 years of living in the City to finally make it up to Twin Peaks.  Gosh damn, it is amazing up there.  I have to admit that the weather was perfect but I think that I could see all the way around the whole bay.  All the bridges and everything.  Just great.

I think that this place must be crazy at night with some back seat loving going on.  I mean, this is lookout point.  There have to be some kids steaming up the windows... its just too good not to.
author: Thadd L.

description:
The first time I went up to Twin Peaks was in 2003, during my very first visit to the Bay Area and one of my good friends took me on a whirlwind one day tour of SF.  That day it was super sunny and beautiful so the view was breathtaking and the wind was not as bonechilling.

Recently, I came back with my family and it was foggy and cooold.  Our overall visit was pretty foggy, so we couldn't help it.  The view is still breathtaking, although you see a bit less of the city and it's REALLY COLD.

The experience is hit or miss :)  But either way, you must visit at least once!
author: Diana N.

description: At night, even better!
author: Janet S.

description:
MEMORY LANE: Oh yeah, This was the place to go when I was younger.  I remember the times I would go & sneak of with the teenager bf(at the time)making the car windows steamy cause we were making out way too long(no, we weren't having Oingo Boingo, for you sickos' out there) & then only to get home & have my ass beat by my parents while trying to explain the hickey on my neck.
I told them that I was vacuuming the house with the dirt devil earlier & used the extension portion of the vacuum & I thought it would be funny to use the extension on my neck....did they buy that line?(the world may never know) cuz I got my butt whooped anyway!  Ahhh, the good old days:)
author: Victoria S.

description: There's a section of parking spots toward the end of the lot that has absolutely no view of the city in front of it. I've spent several innocent (and  immature) nights high beaming these cars. More times that not, I would undoubtedly shed light upon couples doing the nasty in their back seats. Whoops!!! ;)
author: Denise L.

description: Coming from a girl that lives in North Carolina, this place was absolutely breathe taking. It was a great easy ride up and down and no cost to park or enter so that a win-win situation. :) Great view over the city.
author: Jackie T.

description: Great to go when visiting the city. Awesome view. Dang that fog though
author: Landon T.

description: Twin Peaks offers a gorgeous night view and is a wonderful place to admire the city. It's especially nice for tourists who have gone everywhere else (Golden Gate Bridgge, Lombard Street, etc.) because you can see all those place from up here! But of course, it's a great place for anyone to come and take in the lovely view. It's quite chilly and windy however (I came on a March evening), so be sure to bring a coat or a blanket. This place isn't crowded which is surprising!
author: Jennifer F.

description:
I love, love, love, love coming up here. Especially at night - that has to be one of my favorite times to view the city.

Even better when it's a full moon and you can see it reflecting off the ocean's surface just beyond the city line. 

No matter how cold it is up here, I love sitting on the cement railing whether by myself or with someone holding my hand and looking over the twinkling lights of the night life. There's something serene about seeing how it looks from a bird's eye view.

It's calming to me. Soothing. If it wasn't such a drive, I'd be coming here everyday. But as it is, I make sure to come up here at LEAST once a month.
author: Thea G.

description:
This was my favorite place in the city; it had one of the most breathtaking views I've ever seen.

A downside of this place is that it was incredibly windy; make sure to bring a jacket!
author: X F.

description:
Hooray for Twin Peaks. I feel like this place doesn't get as much love as it should, which might be for the better, since you would have to compete with everyone on the curvy drive up and down here. Or, yeah, you could hike it too I guess.

Great views of the city, day or night. Come and see how much of the city is wrapped in fog in the morning, or see the city alight at night. This is one of the must see places a person should go while they're in the city. The price is right!
author: Roland C.

description:
Spell HEAVEN.

I drove tonight (yes, tonight--music to my ears) uphill, downhill and curving right to the edge of this scenic spot-on my PJ's. Came here to show my sister one of the city's pride. It was usually cool but wasnt as windy when I first got here on a night time. 

Enjoyed the city lights and they never change. First time i saw free parking spots right at the center,,,catch:  here was a limo for tourists parked  across the spots. Is that right? 

HS groupie with bottles and energy drinks having fun at one side (i pray the driver's not drinking), then the next minute it was a couples night. (aww..)

okay--i loved it over all, the scene, the driving, my playlist--only one thing: somebody's voice was trying to beat the music while i was enjoying the entirety of everything, LOL.
author: Athens r.

description:
i was here yesterday night.
it was me and the boyfriend's one year anniversary so he decided to take me there.. it was my first time.. so it was really pretty..
we went there at night and you get to see all the pretty lights.. it definitely worth to see.. the drive is short too.. it's not a crazy drive.. so there's no excuse..
since it was a monday it wasn't so busy with people.. just expect a lot of couples.. and maybe a few pot smokers here and there.. 
i enjoyed it.
author: Stephanie B.

description: One of the places we always take people who come to visit. You can pretty much see all of the city and across the Bay to Oakland. Outstanding view of the city, especially when it's clear. It does get cold up here, though, so if you go, either bundle up or don't plan to spend a lot of time enjoying the view. I usually don't have a hard time finding a parking spot. Also a good view of the ocean if you climb up the other 'peak'
author: Saunders C.

description:
My first review, and my absolute favourite place in San Francisco - if not all of California, or the whole United States of America (I stop short of "the world," because that honour is reserved for the Champ de Mars in Paris). Set near the geographical centre of the City, yet out towards the residential areas, it provides sweeping, epic views from the second-highest points in the City itself (first is Mount Davidson).  Since I was a child, this has defined the City for me, just as much as the Golden Gate Bridge or Lombard Street or the Transamerica Pyramid. It feels more "local" than any other tourist spot, being that it is in a residential area; if it wasn't for the tour buses up there every day, it would almost feel like a local secret to me. I like to take tourists here first because it's sort of like the table of contents/overview/abstract to their impending adventure.

Whenever I have visitors, and a car, this is the first place I take them. Whenever I want to relax with friends, and have a car, this is where I usually take them. Whenever I feel depressed, and have a car, this is where you can usually find me. Whenever I am happy, and have a car, this is where you can usually find me. Whenever I am contemplative, and have a car, this is usually where you can find me. I've even hiked here from the Castro (a mile and a half away, and steeply uphill), such is my love and dedication for this place. 

Point is, this is a beautiful place for everyone - local or visitor - and not just some tourist trap... although it is definitely the place to wow out-of-towners (when the view is clear). However, you can find me - a staunch local despite not residing within City limits - up there in any weather, from idyllic sun to dreamlike fog to torrential rain.
author: Joanne C.

description: Is it me or am I just mesmerized by the view from this place? But then again, there's so many places I've been to during my stay in San Francisco where I was easily mesmerized by the view.
author: Jordan N.

description:
If you haven't fallen in love yet, Twin Peaks is waiting for you.

Considering the altitude, though, do plan ahead and go when the skies are clear. Its nothing short of amazing. 


Whoever said the best things in life are free, was most def talkin about Twin Peaks.
author: Av A.

description: There is absolutely nothing in this world like sitting on top of the world and just being in awe of the most amazing city!  If you need to clear your head, this is a good place to check out.  The best view of the San Francisco for sure!
author: Heather B.

description: Best views in the city. Bring a sweatshirt! We went in July and it was incredibly cold and windy!
author: Adrienne A.

description:
SF is all about the views and this is one of the best in the city. On sunny afternoons and clear warm nights, this place is packed, very touristy, very loud. My favorite time to come is late, on a school night when there are less people around. The brisk wind reddens my cheeks and nips my ears. There's a slight amount of precipitation in the air, with the fog rolling in from behind, broken by the peaks, hazing around the buildings. 

The last guy I dated used to take me up here and we'd make out in the back of his car for hours. God I miss that. We came up here once during a rainstorm for a session; probably one of the most romantic experiences ever.
author: Leslie Ann R.

description:
Ah - the BEST views of SF from here. For some reason, it took us a looong time to make it up here after moving to the city. But boy sure glad we did, and we've been back several times. So far each time has been sunny, but not CLEAR. Always a slight foggy haze. Want to return at night to see the lights.

Worth a trip, and a great place to take your guests for a view of the whole bay area - point out where everything is.
author: Jen D.

description: Beautiful view looking over San Francisco.  Bring a jacket and a camera.
author: Carlene R.

description: Gorgeous. You can see a wonderful view of the city, golden gate bridge included. It gets super cold, so def bundle up but it's def a great spot to check out and get some fresh air.
author: Di L.

description:
Definately one of the coolest views of the city, bay, and bridges.  It's especially fun at night, when the fog is rolling in, gradually fuzzing & covering all the lights.
Sure, it's cold & windy, but I'm ok with that - it just makes your girl cuddle up that much closer!

But I have to take off one star because it's always SO crowded.  Great gorgeous views are even better when they can be enjoyed in relative solitude, but you'll never get that here, which is too bad.

As a fun sidenote, try to count the number of cars at night with fogged-up windows.  hmm...
author: Don H.

description:
The view from Twin Peaks is one of my favorites of the city.  Twin Peaks, especially at night, is always on my list when showing people around San Francisco.  You may need to bundle up since it can get chilly up there.

Another view I enjoy is from Treasure Island.
author: Jeff K.

description:
Whenever first-time visitors drop in from out-of-town, this is stop #1.  The entire city is laid out before you (and on clear days, the entire bay).  It may seem like it's crawling with tourists on weekends, but compared with the Wharf it's practically empty.  

Note that when the fog is rolling in you can't see anything from here:  I recommend going to Dolores Heights and then looking *back* at Twin Peaks; if you're lucky you'll see a breathtaking river of fog streaming down the mountain right in front of you.  It's especially atmospheric towards sunset...bring your iPod with the Blade Runner soundtrack and you'll see what I mean.
author: Wes M.

description:
Kisssssssssssssssssssssssssing.

Kiss smoochin.

Friends chillin.

Relaxing... living well.

I love it.  Not much else to say... I love it!
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
What an incredibly beautiful view, and a fun drive up to it.  Windy as hell, and the bathroom takes FOREVER (longest 55 second cleaning cycle on the planet), but wow.

Daytime, nighttime, dusk, dawn, whatever.  Just amazing!
author: Alex C.

description:
It really doesnt matter what time of day you come here, you are guaranteed to get an awesome, spectacular view.  IF you have any out of town family, take them here for the touristy photo opportunity.  
Note to everyone: Do not wear your favorite hat, as your significant other may have to climb halfway down the mountain to retrieve it.  
Also, dont forget to wear a jacket, cause its cold as hell, no matter what time of day you go.
author: Janet R.

description:
I think I'm really reviewing this because I'm delirious with sleep deprivation. 

Of course you should come here!
author: Alia D.

description:
very nice place to be.

Come a little before sunset and you'll get a spectacular view. Come any later then that, then you'll see a bunch of druggies. 

The only problem is that san francisco weather makes it limited for us to visit..
author: Eric Y.

description: Best view of SF, looking down Market Street. Real nice on a clear night. Lots of tour buses during the day, some rif-raf occurs at night. Small parking lot for about 30 cars. Best spot is in the front, if you're lucky to get one. I used to race coming up the narrow drive leading to the parking lot here. It can get real foggy and real windy up here, so bring a warm coat.
author: Larry G.

description: Absolutely the best view of the entire city from here.  I'm not used to driving in the hills, so I was a little nervous about the drive, but I would absolutely recommend Twin Peaks as a place to go to for a tourist.  It's free and it's a beautiful view of the city.  You'll see other tourists, but also locals stopping from their jog to enjoy the scenery from there.
author: Judy C.

description:
The best place to see the entire city...360 degrees.  On an especially clear day, you can see forever!

It amazes me that a such a place with such a view is not overly populated with tourists (well not at the times I was there).  It can be quite cold and windy while on top but it's worth the trip.  Bring a loved one to snuggle with.

You'll get exercise climbing those hills, the best panoramic view of San Francisco, and healthy doses of radiation from all those transmission towers *bump*.
author: Vvn W.

description: The view is exceptional, but there are always many people here.  Making the drive up and down the peaks is pretty interesting.  Its a nice "shortcut" to take if you are coming from Clarendon going to Portola(if there arent any other cars in your way).
author: andrew l.

description:
this place conjures one verse to my mind, and that is:

I'm gonna stop singing this song, because I'm high
I'm singing this whole thing wrong, because I'm high
And if I don't sell one copy I know why, (why man) 'cuz I'm high,
because I'm high, because I'm high

...yeah, Twin Peaks. ah, the memories.
author: Audacity L.

description: A breath taking and spectacular view of the city!  Don't leave San Francisco without coming here!
author: Monica J.

description:
It's funny because I live on Taylor Street downtown and since I could see twin peaks from my apartment, I decided to trek from my house up to Twin Peaks. I wore comfortable shoes but nothing prepared me for the agonizing walk that became a 3 hour ordeal.

What made the walk worse, was that I walked all the way around the place and took "panoramic way" up to the peaks which is a windy way to the top. There's a road that takes you directly up there. I also realized that no one else was walking up there and everyone was driving so that should have been a sign. 

I finally made it and took some fantastic photos but I will never try to walk this one ever again!
author: Adam C.

description:
This is where you take visitors on a clear autumn day to get THE view of San Francisco. It's also close to the Castro and the Mission, which are both spots visitors tend to overlook. 

I also love riding my bike up Twin Pks. Blvd in the evening, especially when there are a few pieces of fog overhead and mingling with the sunset. It's places like Twin Pks that separate this city from all the others. 

What's more, Twin Pks. is by far the most diverse place in San Francisco! Tour buses converge upon this little space hauling sight-seers who've come from all parts of the world to stand on a tiny, freezing, inspiring spit of land and stare down on your crappy two-bedroom apt. from on high. Delightful!
author: Andrew K.

description: One of the few places that both tourists and locals enjoy. Twin Peaks offers the best views of San Francisco, as virtually every corner of the city is visible. Along with the views of San Francisco you can also see the Bay, the Oakland Skyline and the Marin Headlands. Just make sure to come on a clear day otherwise you'll be disappointed. Its also makes for a romantic destiny at night.
author: David D.

description: Nothing beats the view from Twin Peaks. I've had quite a few out of town guests lately and went to Twin Peaks and Coit Tower back to back. I hadn't been to Twin Peaks in a few years and all I can say is WOW. NOTHING beats this 360 degree view of the city and the bay. Coit Tower's little windows that overlook a pretty limited portion of the city really pale in comparison to the truly awe-inspiring panoramic scene that Twin Peaks provides. This is the type of place where you really relax, breathe in the fresh air and appreciate the Bay Area's unique combination of city and nature. Twin Peaks made me fall in love with the bay about a hundred times more than I already was.
author: Talia D.

description: This place should be visited at least once in your life.  Great view of the city, just make sure it's not foggy that day and bring a jacket - it gets windy and quite chilly.
author: Priscilla L.

description:
Great place to go during the day or night, but for sure much more gorgeous and romantical at night. Will definitely be one of those places you can't forget. Bring your warmest jacket because it is windy like a mother-lover.

Live, Laugh, and Lunch
Patty
author: Patty N.

description:
Walk, don't drive to Twin Peaks, you lazy mother...

Even if the killer view of the city is too touristy for you, at least come to see the Hawk family that lives around the Peaks.  There's a family of four and you can bet your bottom dollar there's at least one Red-Tail Hawk coasting in the wind!

Remarkable!
author: Mennlay A.

description: Incredible beauty. I walked up Twin Peaks yesterday for the first time, and can't believe it's taken me so long to get around to it. There are four or five fun summits on the walk up Twin Peaks, each one  with a slightly more breathtaking view from the last. Afterwards I recommend walking around the water reservoir and through the path over to forrest knolls, and continuing on into the eucalyptus forest behind UCSF.
author: Soma S.

description:
Good for incredible sunrises and sunsets, but there are some drawbacks:
 - it can be dirty and littered,
 - a bit "touristy,"
 - crowded at sunsets, and
 -  I once went up there for the sunrise and walked past a couple having sex in their hatchback with the hatch OPEN! Get a room!

I prefer some of the less known, harder to get to points for a good view.
author: Brad C.

description:
Update!

Its the SF version of 'make-out point'! Came up here with a couple friends for some 3am tipple and there were at least 5 cars-a-rocking, including one lady walking out the backseat of a car in a VERY short miniskirt (with suspicious white spots) in 45*F weather, popping a squat, then shaking her ass back to the backseat for round 2. Classic!

----

Holy mother it gets windy up there!

I went up for the first time during Fleet Week to see the Blue Angels. I've lived here on and off for 20 years and that was my first time here. Its weird to finally see Sutro Tower up close and not just looming over SF.
